DOC.HEAD: Key Events in Thatcher's Political Career
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief chronology of key events in British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's political career: --- 1958 - Elected to the House of Commons, representing the north London suburb of Finchley. 1961 - Appointed a deputy minister for Pensions and National Insurance, serving until 1964. 1970 - Appointed education secretary in Cabinet of Conservative Prime Minister Edward Heath, serving until 1974. Feb. 11, 1975 - Defeats Heath in contest for leadership of the Conservative Party, then in opposition. May 4, 1979 - Becomes prime minister when Conservatives win parliamentary majority in general election. April 2, 1982 - Argentine forces invade the Falkland Islands, claiming the British colony as their own. Britain sends a naval task force and reclaims the South Atlantic islands June 14-15 after the Argentines surrender. The war cost 255 British lives and 650 Argentine. July 9, 1982 - Begins second term as prime minister after Conservatives win general election. March 12, 1984 - The National Union of Mineworkers, opposing plans to close 20 unprofitable mines, begins a strike that lasts 51 weeks - the longest and most violent strike in British history and a watershed in Mrs. Thatcher's effort to crush union power. Oct. 12, 1984 - Mrs. Thatcher escapes injury as Irish Republican Army bombs her hotel in Brighton during the Conservative Party conference. Five people are killed and 31 injured. March 3, 1985 - Miners vote to return to work without a settlement. Jan. 6, 1986 - Defense Secretary Michael Heseltine resigns from Cabinet in dispute over American-led takeover of Westland PLC helicopter manufacturer. Heseltine sought a British-European rescue bid. June 11, 1987 - Leads Conservatives to election victory, becoming the only prime minister of the 20th century to win three elections consecutively. Oct. 26, 1989 - Nigel Lawson, chancellor of the exchequer, resigns following conflicts Mrs. Thatcher over the monetary policy. Nov. 1, 1990 - Deputy Prime Minister Sir Geoffrey Howe, a former foreign secretary and the last of Mrs. Thatcher's original Cabinet, resigns over her stance toward European union. Nov. 13, 1990 - Howe tells House of Commons that Mrs. Thatcher is jeopardizing vital British interests and dividing the government. Nov. 14, 1990 - Michael Heseltine declares his challenge for leadership of the party and the prime minister's job, Mrs. Thatcher's first serious challenger after 15 years at the helm of the party and more than 11 in power. Nov. 20, 1990 - Mrs. Thatcher fails to defeat Heseltine outright in a party leadership election, forcing a second round. Nov. 22, 1990 - After talks with supporters, Mrs. Thatcher announces her resignation, effective after the election of a new party leader. She also dispatches 14,000 more British troops to the Persian Gulf, bringing Britain's component of the U.S.-dominated international force to more than 30,000.

DOC.HEAD: With Thatcher's Demise, US Loses Its Staunchest Ally
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: For almost a decade, Margaret Thatcher was regarded at the White House as America's best friend, the trusted ally whose strong views reinforced the conservative tone of administration policies. Among Western allies, she was alone at Ronald Reagan's side in 1986 in supporting the U.S. bombing of Libya. In the Persian Gulf crisis, she boldly joined with George Bush in sending troops to the Middle East. ``You always know where she was and what she believed,'' Bush said upon hearing of her decision to resign. ``She has always been an outstanding ally of the United States,'' he said. ``I will miss her.'' There were many doubters around the world when Reagan arrived in Washington with an economic program of free-market capitalism that seemed out of step with the times. Mrs. Thatcher wasn't one of the skeptics; she was advocating a similar program at home. They shared rocky relations with organized labor. Reagan successfully fired the nation's air traffic controllers, dealing a devastating blow to labor. She, too, smashed restive unions. On foreign policy, she frequently was more right wing than Reagan - certainly more so than Bush. Reagan never made any secret of his special affection for the British prime minister. They were ideological soulmates and called each other Ronnie and Margaret. At international gatherings, they usually were side by side. Two years ago as they met for the final time before Reagan left office, the president said he was leaving the White House with ``considerable satisfaction in the knowledge that Margaret Thatcher will still reside at No. 10 Downing Street.'' She later wrote him a ``Dear Ron'' letter in which she praised him as ``a great president, one of the greatest.'' Like Reagan, she was deeply suspicious of the Soviet Union. Together they advocated a hard line toward Moscow and championed military readiness - even though she was the first to recognize Mikhail S. Gorbachev as a leader she could do business with. Mrs. Thatcher encouraged the huge Pentagon buildup that Reagan nurtured under the theme of peace through strength. She was a big backer of U.S. efforts to install medium-range missiles in Europe and always seemed cautious - perhaps reluctant - when it came to disarmament. When Argentina and Britain clashed militarily over the Falkland Islands, the United States was forced to make a painful choice between two allies. Ronnie sided with Margaret. Washington's special relationship with London seemed to slip when Reagan left power. Bush and Mrs. Thatcher disagreed publicly last year over her government's decision to deport Vietnamese and Cambodian ``boat people'' who were fleeing their countries to Hong Kong. Bush, a veteran of world politics, knew many leaders around the globe. Mrs. Thatcher suddenly seemed to be just one of the gang. The Berlin Wall was collapsing and it appeared as if Bush found German Chancellor Helmut Kohl more interesting than Mrs. Thatcher. She was merely one in a parade of foreign dignitaries who got the prized invitation to visit Bush at Camp David this year. Nevertheless, Bush said he expected the ``special relationship'' between the United States and Great Britain to remain on a ``steady keel.'' Mrs. Thatcher did her part, demonstrating her loyalty. For awhile she and Bush were seemingly alone in their suspicions of Gorbachev's unilateral cutbacks in troops and arms in Europe, and appeared uncertain how to respond. Under intense pressure from Congress, Bush began to warm to the Soviet leader. Now they seem almost best of friends. On the Persian Gulf, Bush said he would not rule out possible military force, and ordered a huge buildup of troops to make his threat credible. Mrs. Thatcher, characteristically, was tougher. She said that unless Saddam Hussein got out of Kuwait soon, the West would have to use military force to dislodge him. She called Saddam ``a loser,'' and the state-controlled Iraqi news agency replied that she was an ``old hag.'' Now, she is leaving. No one suspects that Britain's new leadership - whoever it is - will take a soft line toward Iraq. Yet, if the going gets tough, it might have been comforting for Bush to be able to hear the tough old line from Thatcher.

DOC.HEAD: For Margaret Thatcher, the Road Ends at Buckingham Palace
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Britain-Politics
DOC.TEXT: Margaret Thatcher's long and often glorious career as prime minister will end with a short ride from 10 Downing St. to Buckingham Palace. When the 372 Conservative Party members of the House of Commons have chosen a new leader next week, tradition prescribes that Mrs. Thatcher submit her resignation to Queen Elizabeth II, the head of state. The queen then sends for the winner of the Conservative Party leadership race to confirm him as prime minister - providing the monarch believes that person commands sufficient majority in the House of Commons to be able to carry on Her Majesty's Government. The new prime minister will ``kiss hands'' on appointment. In past times, the new leader would actually have kissed the monarch's hands and walked away backwards, but now the term is only an archaic survival in the language of protocol. The meeting takes place in the second floor audience room of the palace where the prime minister meets with the monarch on Tuesdays to inform her about government business. The room has walls of duck-egg blue, armchairs and sofas in cream wood, and four paintings: two views by Antonio Canaletto and two portraits by Thomas Gainsborough, of King George III - who lost the American colonies at the end of the 18th century - and of the king's consort (wife), Queen Charlotte. Neil Kinnock, leader of the opposition Labor Party, is demanding a general election, arguing that the voters and not a few hundred lawmakers should choose the nation's leader. But there is no constitutional need for a general election until the government's maximum five-year term expires in mid-1992. The new prime minister can go to the monarch at any time and say he needs the support of the electorate to confirm his position. The monarch is then bound to call a general election. There are two recent precedents for the present situation. Harold Macmillan, the Conservative Prime Minister, called the queen to his hospital bedside in 1963 to announce his intention to resign. His chosen successor, Sir Alec Douglas-Home, was imposed on the party lawmakers by their leaders. The secret-ballot process which brought down Mrs. Thatcher was established as a result of the controversy over Douglas-Home's appointment. Douglas-Home lost the general election a year later to Labor Party leader Harold Wilson. In 1976, Wilson resigned, apparently because he felt worn out, and the party lawmakers chose James Callaghan as their leader. Callaghan served as prime minister until he lost the general election to Mrs. Thatcher's Conservatives in 1979.

DOC.HEAD: A Brief Look at the Three Candidates Running To Succeed Thatcher
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief look at the three Conservative Party officials seeking to succeed Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher as party chief - and thus the nation's leader: ---
DOC.HEAD: MICHAEL HESELTINE
DOC.TEXT: Heseltine, a former defense secretary, calls himself a Thatcherite. But if his leadership bid succeeds, his government would likely be as different in style and content from Mrs. Thatcher's as it's possible to be in the Conservative Party. Heseltine, 57, announced his leadership challenge on Nov. 14 and took a giant step toward becoming prime minister on Tuesday, forcing Mrs. Thatcher into a second ballot for the party leadership. To a large extent, his appeal to his fellow legislators was that he was not Mrs. Thatcher: that he would govern by Cabinet consensus, and that he could help them win re-election by modifying her unpopular new per capita community charge, commonly known as the poll tax, and because of his high standing in public opinion polls. One of the major themes has been his ideal of ``caring capitalism,'' which he has contrasted with the rigorous free-market approach of the Thatcher years. ``I find it difficult to reconcile with what I understand to be the core of Tory philosophy that there are people sleeping in the doorways of so many central London streets,'' Heseltine said recently. Although as a Conservative and a self-made millionaire Heseltine favors a market economy, he believes in a closer relationship between government and business. Heseltine has said he would continue Mrs. Thatcher's tough policy on the persian Gulf. He and his wife, Anne, have three children. ---
DOC.HEAD: DOUGLAS HURD:
DOC.TEXT: Hurd, the foreign secretary, has won respect for his calm handling of a crisis in the Persian Gulf and another crisis in the government. Hurd, 60, who had supported Mrs. Thatcher's campaign to stay in power, entered the race to succeed her as soon as she dropped out. ``I believe I can unite the party ... and that's why I'm putting my name forward,'' Hurd said Thursday. The silver-haired former diplomat was Northern Ireland secretary from 1984 to 1985, and Home Secretary from 1985 to 1989, in charge of law and order and immigration services. Mrs. Thatcher appointed him foreign secretary in October 1989 - fulfillment of an ambition Hurd had cherished through a long political career. Forthright, steely and calm, he played a central role in Britain's involvement in Persian Gulf. Hurd, who is fluent in Mandarin Chinese, began his working life as a diplomat, then turned to mystery writing and politics. The son and grandson of Conservative members of Parliament, Hurd was educated at Eton and Cambridge, where he received a first-class honors degree in history. Hurd and his second wife, Judith, his former secretary whom he married after a 1982 divorce, have two small children. He has three adult sons by his first marriage. ---
DOC.HEAD: JOHN MAJOR
DOC.TEXT: Major, at 47 the youngest member of the Thatcher government, won two top Cabinet posts within a decade of entering politics. The chancellor of the exchequer, or treasury secretary, is seen as one of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's personal choices as eventual heir. A high school drop-out and son of a circus performer, Major is the self-made man who symbolizes the changes in the Conservative Party that once was the bastion of Oxford and Cambridge-educated privilege. A onetime laborer, he is the only Cabinet member to have been on ``the dole,'' or welfare, for eight months. He has lived in suburban comfort and in the tough south London neighborhood of Brixton, where the family moved when one of his father's business ventures failed. Major's fortunes improved when he joined the Standard Chartered Bank, where he was an executive for 14 years. He was elected to Parliament in 1979, and in 1981 began a remarkable climb to the top through eight government jobs in as many years. After the June 1987 general election, Major was appointed chief secretary to the treasury, winning respect for his financial acumen and developing a reputation for quickly grasping figures and detail. Mrs. Thatcher chose Major as foreign secretary in July 1989 and he became the top treasury official four months later. His year has been a rough one for the British economy, with rising inflation, high interest rates and growing trade imbalance - all problems that existed before he took over. Tall, bespectacled and gray-haired, Major has a calm, modest manner that some call dull and others find engaging. He and his wife, Norma, have been married for 20 years and have a son and a daughter.

DOC.HEAD: British Political System At-A-Glance
With PM-Britain-Politics
DOC.TEXT: Some facts on how the leadership change in Britain will work now that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has announced her resignation: ---

HOW THE PRIME MINISTER IS SELECTED: Citizens of the United Kingdom do not vote for the prime minister, who is the head of government. They vote for a local Member of Parliament. The leader of the party with a majority in the 650-seat House of Commons is the prime minister. ---

RULES FOR ELECTION OF THE PRIME MINISTER: Each party has its own rules for electing a leader. The Conservative Party, which has a 98-seat majority in the Commons, will choose its new leader by a secret ballot on Tuesday. If no candidate wins a majority, there will be a final ballot on Thursday. ---

HANDING OVER OF POWER: Mrs. Thatcher remains prime minister of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland until the governing Conservative Party chooses a new leader next week. At that time, she will submit her resignation to Queen Elizabeth II. The party's new leader would meet the monarch soon afterward to be confirmed as prime minister, probably within an hour. ---

TERMS OF OFFICE: Parties are elected to govern for a maximum of five years, but a British prime minister can call a general election at any time. The present Conservative government's term runs out in mid-1992.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwaiti Soldiers, Volunteers, Refugees Star In Media Campaign
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.l
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Kuwaiti soldiers in tanks roar through blowing desert sand for the cameras. Kuwaiti volunteers practice lethal karate chops in front of photographers. Kuwaiti refugees tell reporters the horrors of life under the Iraqis. It's all part of a stepped-up media campaign by the exiled Kuwaiti government to keep the plight of Kuwait on newscasts and front pages around the world. ``I want this issue always to be in the minds of people because as time passes, people may forget,'' said Amal Al-Hamad, who was in charge of international media in Kuwait's Ministry of Information and is now running an information office at a Dhahran hotel. Nearly four months after the Iraqi invasion of their country, and with a growing anti-war movement in the United States, the Kuwaiti government has zeroed in on the hundreds of media representatives here covering the U.S. military buildup and allied deployment. In the three weeks since her office opened for business, scarcely a day has passed without a Kuwaiti event, all orchestrated with the help of The Rendon Group, a Washington public relations firm. ``What we try to do ... is to give the media a clear picture of what the Iraqis are doing. We are trying to make the world sympathize with us, sympathize with the truth,'' she said. Trips to see the remnants of the Kuwaiti army, talk to Kuwaiti pilots who flew here after the invasion, and watch Kuwaiti volunteers train are especially popular. The Ministry of Information has also brought government officials from their exile headquarters in Taif and keeps two people at the border, looking for fleeing refugees who can provide insight into the situation inside Kuwait. The refugees are then brought here to recount their tales of Iraqi repression, corruption and murder. Some, like Dr. Ali Al-Huwail, go on the record and make headlines. He told of burying more than 50 Kuwaiti children in one night with a colleague who witnessed the Iraqis pulling the plugs on some of their incubators. Others cover their faces and refuse to give their names because they are frightened of what might happen to family members left behind. Mrs. Al-Hamad, who left Kuwait with her family in early October, said she recognizes that not everyone produces a story: Some may only provide a few facts, but each adds a piece to the picture. The Kuwaiti operation has not always run smoothly, often because of poor logistics. The Kuwaiti government was late in starting a public relations operation, partly because many employees from the Ministry of Information are still in Kuwait and all its archives were stolen, Mrs. Al-Hamad said. It now has an office in Cairo and is planning new operations in London, Syria, northern Africa and other European countries, she said. ``Money is no problem,'' Mrs. Al-Hamad said, though she had no overall figure on the cost of the international media campaign. The Rendon Group was hired because it knew what the Western media needed, she said. John Rendon, the firm's president, said in a telephone interview that his company was mainly providing technical assistance in Saudi Arabia, Europe and Arab capitals to help the Kuwaitis get their message across. The first public relations campaign on behalf of Kuwait was launched in the United States in mid-August by Hill and Knowlton. It was hired by Citizens for a Free Kuwait, formed by private Kuwaiti citizens immediately after the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion. Lew Allison, Hill and Knowlton's senior vice president who arrived in Saudi Arabia on Aug. 22, said his main job has been to produce TV news of Kuwaitis and transmit it back to Washington. He said he had worked closely with the Kuwaiti government, especially when it had no public relations operation here. Al Mattern, 40, of Alexandria, Va., who started up Rendon's Saudi operation, said he felt he was doing ``something worthwhile for mankind rather than just raise money for political candidates at home.'' Mrs. Al-Hamad said the Kuwaitis who staff an office here are all unpaid volunteers like herself, though some are getting living expenses. ``We are ready to sacrifice,'' she said. ``Even if I succeed in only 3 percent of what I expect, I think I have done something for my country.''

DOC.HEAD: Egyptian President's Gamble Paying Off in Gulf Crisis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Hosni Mubarak, Egypt's prudent president, took an uncharacteristic political gamble in leading Arab opposition to Iraq's Saddam Hussein. That gamble appears to be paying off, experts say, as Mubarak hosted Bush for a 19-hour visit starting Thanksgiving night. Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and ignited the crisis that has close to three-quarters of a million soldiers - Iraqi vs. U.S. and its allies - ready for battle on the Saudi peninsula. Until the invasion, Mubarak's leadership style was cautious and hesitant - many said plodding. But he had laboriously ended a decade's isolation from the Arabs and was trying to cement Cairo's position as the natural Arab leader when Saddam undercut him. Mubarak, 62 and president for nine years, moved quickly to marshal Arab forces against Iraq's takeover of its tiny neighbor. He has stayed in the forefront of the anti-Iraq resistance. Alliances were reshaped where necessary. He scrapped a political and economic grouping with Iraq, Jordan and Yemen. He downgraded relations markedly with the Palestine Liberation Organization. Mubarak said recently that Egyptian soldiers would not enter Iraq, even if Bush sent in U.S. troops against Saddam and asked Mubarak to follow with peacekeeping forces as the Americans withdrew. But the Egyptian leader's comment was merely a restatement of his policy since he sent the first of 14,000 Egyptians in mid-August to defend Saudi Arabia from possible Iraqi attack. Arab politics being what they are, it was a clever move, said political science professor Earl Sullivan of American University in Cairo. It cost him nothing as long as his troop stay on the front line in Saudi Arabia, and it ensured that Saddam could not proclaim to the Arabs that their brother Mubarak was a traitor to the Arab cause. ``In terms of domestic politics, he's more respected, in a stronger position to lead the country. Internationally he looks like a statesman and a leader, not a follower,'' said Sullivan, who has followed Middle Eastern politics since coming to the university in 1973. Lucius D. Battle, U.S. ambassador to Cairo during the 1960s, praised Mubarak for holding the course despite billions of dollars the crisis has cost Egypt's strapped economy. The experience has not been all negative. The United States has shown its appreciation by writing off almost $7 billion in military debts. Saudi Arabia and other gulf Arabs forgave another $7 billion. And Cairo is expecting a receptive ear next week in Paris when it asks further debt relief from mainly Western creditor nations that would put Egypt's foreign debt at half the crippling $50 billion it was on Aug. 1. Despite that, said Battle, Egypt's economy has suffered a net loss since the turmoil began. Battle, retired director of Washington's Middle East Institute, said Mubarak has performed ``extraordinarily well'' in difficult circumstances. ``He has a real need for a relationship with United States, partly economic and partly political,'' Battle said from his home in Washington. At the same time, he said, Egypt cannot surrender leadership of the Arabs to Saddam or anybody else. ``I think he has had economic incentive, yes, and political incentive to exert himself in the Arab world in a leadership role. I think that's in their interest, and I think it's in our interest,'' said Battle. ``A much-needed requirement for us is stability in that area. Mubarak is sensible, he's moderate, as steady and as sturdy as we're likely to get there,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Walesa, Mazowiecki Battle For Poland's Presidency
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CX2 Nov. 22.
DOC.TEXT: Two years ago, Lech Walesa and Tadeusz Mazowiecki were sharing strikers' rations and walking arm-in-arm to topple Communist rule. They won the war but lost each other. On Sunday, 27 million voters in Poland's first popular presidential election will write the final chapter to Eastern Europe's most celebrated political divorce - deciding which of them will hold the nation's highest office. The polls say Walesa is far ahead. The strong-willed Solidarity chairman who inspires some and frightens others is striving to cap his amazing biography by succeeding his former Communist nemesis, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, as president. Mazowiecki, the cautious and equally stubborn prime minister, is opposing him. And now a dark horse has emerged. A wealthy, mystery-shrouded emigre businessman, Stanislaw Tyminski, has returned after 21 years in Canada and Peru. His fresh face, free-spending campaign and sharp attacks on familiar leaders have garnered him enough support to overtake Mazowiecki in at least one pre-election survey. Three remaining candidates - ex-Communist Wlodzimierz Cimoszewski, Peasant Party hopeful Roman Bartoszcze and Leszek Moczulski of the rightist Confederation for an Independent Poland - have failed to generate significant backing. If nobody wins a majority, the contest goes to a runoff Dec. 9. The president will be sworn in before the National Assembly by Christmas. The election is the first in Eastern Europe in which the electorate is not voting primarily against the former Communist system. Rather, it is choosing between differing visions of the new democratic system. Walesa, the technical-school educated electrician who has led Solidarity from its birth in 1980 and won the 1983 Nobel Peace Prize for his defense of workers' rights, is dynamic and volatile. His opponents say he could become a dictator or at least destabilize the country. Mazowiecki is a Catholic journalist and ex-political prisoner who in August 1989 with Walesa's backing became East Europe's first non-Communist head of government. His opponents say he is reluctant to take action and will not move fast enough to satisfy public moods, risking a social explosion. Walesa and Mazowiecki were allies until the dissolution of their former common opponent, the Communist Party, in January. Over the next few months, Walesa began agitating from Gdansk to replace the president and the 65 percent of the lower parliament chamber that has been conceded to the Communists in a power-sharing bargain by Solidarity last year. Adopting the slogan of ``acceleration,'' he also demanded quicker privatization of the 80 percent of the economy owned by the state, removal of the old Communist elite from powerful positions and speedy withdrawal of the Soviet army. Mazowiecki responded that he shared the same goals, but that everything must be accomplished gradually through the building of a state of law. Mazowiecki's supporters in Warsaw accused Walesa of acting out of personal ambition and suggested he leave the running of Poland to experts. By the summer, Walesa had openly declared ``war at the top.'' His backers and Mazowiecki's began forming new parties. Solidarity effectively split up. Workers and farmers tended to stay with their blue-collar champion, Walesa, and the Solidarity union itself has been a powerful engine in his energetic presidential campaign. Government officials, professionals, the more educated and more affluent - including nearly all of Walesa's former intellectual advisers - sided with Mazowiecki. Behind the bitter personal conflict are differing concepts of democratic leadership in a country where the term, after a half century of Nazi or Communist rule, is still hazy. Walesa says Poland needs a leader with ``an ax,'' ready and determined to chop out vestiges of the old system and intervene when he sees injustice. He says he can be a powerful cheerleader for change. But Mazowiecki says he fears such a ``charismatic leader ... accountable to no one.'' He wants the president to be a guarantor of stability. Also at stake is the government's yearlong shock economic reform program that has restored stability to the Polish market and quenched hyperinflation. But the plan also cut Poles' real income by 35 percent, brought on a deep recession and created 1 million unemployed. Walesa says he supports the tough plan and its architect, Deputy Prime Minister Leszek Balcerowicz, who might even be offered the premiership if the Solidarity chief wins. However Walesa wants faster privatization and more government support to give private enterprise a jump start. Mazowiecki responds that his privatization timetable is the fastest possible for selling half 7,000 state enterprises within three years. He says the election of Walesa could upset Poland as it is rounding a dangerous curve, threatening all the hard-won domestic and international achievements of the past year and slowing down the country's integration with the rest of Europe. If defeated, Mazowiecki says he will resign as prime minister and move into political opposition. Walesa has said if defeated he will quit as Solidarity chairman and retire until the Polish nation needs him again. But he does not expect to lose. ``I was born only for victory,'' he declared in an interview.

DOC.HEAD: Avon Calling, This Time to Populous China
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report; version also in financial report.
DOC.TEXT: Avon is calling, Chinese-style. Instead of knocking on doors in the American tradition to sell beauty supplies, Avon salespeople in China will use the time-hallowed Chinese custom of working through personal contacts. The first selling job Avon faced in China was with Chinese officials, said John Novosad, vice president for the Asia-Pacific region of Avon Products Inc. ``The first thing we heard was, `What's direct selling?''' Novosad said Wednesday in a telephone interview from his Hong Kong office. ``They had great difficulty understanding why we thought this was a good idea.'' Avon in a joint venture with the Guangzhou Cosmetics Factory began selling beauty products this month in the southern city of Guangzhou, also known as Canton. The company has 25 supervisors, all Chinese, who have recruited about 800 people to sell beauty supplies on a commission basis, Novosad said. ``We expected to have to spend a lot of time teaching these people about profit incentive and the selling methods,'' Novosad said. ``You're talking about a country that we all believe doesn't know about these things. Well, it wasn't that way. The first question we heard was, `How much commission do I get?''' Avon, which already sells its products in more than 100 countries, is selling skin-care supplies, perfumes, cosmetics and personal hygiene items in China. They will be made in China with imported ingredients. The company's traditional image in the United States is of an ``Avon lady'' ringing doorbells and spending leisurely afternoons with her customers. ``Here, we're telling the representatives to build networks, talk to their sisters, talk to those they work with and so on. There are no limits, so it can be done door-to-door if they feel comfortable, or it can be done by taking brochures to work. It depends on the ingenuity.'' Novosad said Avon will test the method in Guangzhou before trying other parts of China, which has a population of about 1.1 billion people. Avon supervisors receive a base salary, but also get a 2 percent to 6 percent commission on the sales of the representatives they recruit, Novosad said. The salespeople will receive a 25 percent commission on their sales, he said. ``We think it will work here and let us develop a base for all of China. China, once it gets economically going, will be a fabulous market of tremendous proportions,'' Novosad said. ``We don't expect to make millions at first.'' Prices for Avon products sold in Guangzhou average about $3. That's one-tenth the average monthly income of a Chinese worker, but Guangzhou workers are generally better off than those elsewhere in the country. Customers are most likely to be single young women, who tend to have relatively high disposable incomes.

DOC.HEAD: Couple's Indian Artifacts Fool Even Some Collectors
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Kevin Costner strove for authenticity in his film ``Dances With Wolves,'' shot with many Indian actors on the South Dakota prairie, but for some things he went to a couple in southern Illinois. Bill and Kathy Brewer's reproductions of American Indian artifacts, good enough to fool serious collectors, won them a place on the movie's closing credits. ``It started out as a $15,000 order for weapons,'' Ms. Brewer said. But once the film's producers saw the Brewers' work, they ordered more and more. The couple said they ended up making more than 200 props for the film, and billed the movie makers $37,000. ``They sent us a script and then the set director called and said, `What does the inside of a medicine man's teepee look like?' And then a chief's teepee. They ordered everything Bill drew,'' Ms. Brewer said. Ordinarily they use authentic materials, such as horns purchased from buffalo ranchers. But they were pressed for time on the movie and only one of the eight buffalo-horn headdresses they made is made of real horn, she said Thursday. The other seven are painted plastic. So convincing are their products that collectors of Indian artifacts are learning to ask ``Is it real or is it a Brewer?'' before plunking down thousands of dollars. The Brewers urge prospective buyers to look closely for their ``BKB'' mark on pieces offered by dealers or at auctions. They say they are starting to get a bad name for making reproductions that are too good. ``We were chewed out at a recent auction in Santa Fe by some dealers,'' Ms. Brewer recalled. ``They said we had no business making stuff as good as we do.'' What started as Brewer's boyhood hobby has become a cottage industry for the couple, who work out of their modest one-story house in this small community about 40 miles east of St. Louis. Ms. Brewer, 36, said they get details for their works mainly from genuine artifacts in museums, and that her 37-year-old husband also has built up an extensive collection of books and journals. In addition to ``Dances With Wolves,'' the Brewers said they produced props for ``Son of the Morning Star,'' a television miniseries about the private life of George Armstrong Custer. It stars Gary Cole and Rosanna Arquette and is scheduled for broadcast in February. Demand and prices for Indian artifacts have soared in the past year since a Navajo chief's blanket fetched $500,000 at an auction house in New York. But some collectors have gotten burned by buying items advertised as authentic that turn out to be Brewer originals. ``We made a painted Apache gun case that ended up at Sotheby's,'' Ms. Brewer said. ``It got sold - $7,000 - because we didn't get the (auction) catalog until later.'' The Brewers wrote to Sotheby's about the mistake and enclosed a photograph of the piece in progress, she said. ``They had to give the lady her money back,'' Ms. Brewer said. ``She called us, and we made her a case just like it for $250. Because some of the prices are so high, they're creating a market for reproductions.''

DOC.HEAD: Contract Signed To Republish Will Rogers Works
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: A new generation of readers will be able to relish Will Rogers' wit under newly signed agreements to republish some of the Oklahoman's works. ``Will Rogers wrote some 2 million words. We think it's a major achievement with Oklahoma and the world that wants to know more about this guy,'' said Joe Carter, director of the Will Rogers Memorial honoring the humorist who died in 1935. Officials of the University of Oklahoma Press and the Will Rogers Memorial signed contracts Wednesday for two separate works of Rogers' writings from the 1920s and 1930s, Carter said. Under the first contract, the Press will publish a manuscript entitled ``The Cowboy Philosopher: A Will Rogers Anthology.'' Carter said the work will include Rogers' early works on Prohibition and politics. William Savage Jr., a University of Oklahoma history professor, will work with the memorial to edit and produce the anthology, Carter said. The second contract is for a new two-volume edition of Rogers writings. Carter said a $158,800 grant from the Sarkeys Foundation in Norman will subsidize printing that work. The first volume is set for 1992 and the second for 1993. ``We're now having a national search for an editor, a scholarly type editor,'' Carter said. ``This will be the complete, collective writings of Will Rogers,'' he said. ``It will be sold worldwide.'' Carter said the republished works will be coming out at just the right time. Recently, 20th Century Fox announced it is re-releasing 50 Will Rogers' movies. A new Broadway play also is on the horizon, titled ``Ziegfeld Presents Will Rogers.''

DOC.HEAD: Army May Halt Discharges at US Bases to Assure Gulf Troop Strength
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of soldiers could be forced to stay in the Army under a policy change being considered as a way to beef up potential troop reinforcements for the Persian Gulf. The Army has been studying changes in its so-called ``stop loss'' rules governing what officers and enlisted personnel may be kept on in the service, even if they are ready to retire or their enlistment has expired and they don't want to sign up again. ``There are policy changes under consideration,'' Army spokeswoman Judy Johnston said Thursday. And one Pentagon official, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said an announcement on the subject was being prepared. Since August, under President Bush's order sending troops to Saudi Arabia, the armed services have had authority to retain people on duty in the gulf who reach their retirement or re-enlistment dates. Capt. Barbara Goodno, an Army public affairs officer working on the issue, said that in the Army, this also has applied to some specialists in support units in the United States. Lt. Col. Stuart Wagner, a Defense Department spokesman, said the Army had been working on a ``conceptual plan'' regarding this authority that he understood would ``expand it to include virtually everyone.'' Each year, 10 percent of the Army corps of approximately 105,000 officers and 20 percent of the more than 625,000 enlisted men reach voluntary retirement. The New York Times, quoting officials whom it did not identify, said in Thursday's editions that the Army had decided to halt about 1,500 retirements and enlistment expirations a month. The Washington Post, also quoting unnamed sources, said the policy change was expected to take effect Dec. 1. Ms. Johnston said the changes being considered also would trim vacations for trainees. Depending on the final decision, she said, such vacations could be reduced in length or eliminated. Officials quoted by the Post said the policy change also would put an end to transfers unrelated to the situation in the gulf. Wagner said he did not know whether the other services were contemplating similar action. An estimated 120,000 Army troops are now deployed in Saudi Arabia. Earlier this week, the Army called 20,129 more reservists to active duty. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has authorized activation of up to 125,000 reservists from all services. Bush announced recently he was doubling U.S. troop strength in the gulf region to about 400,000 so that the forces there could be ready to go on the offensive if necessary.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Big Agriculture Importer - Even Feathers and Castor Oil
DOC.TEXT: Besides being a huge exporter of agricultural products, the United States also is one of the biggest importers. Even castor oil and feathers are on the list, says the Agriculture Department. Total commodity exports in the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30 were at a nine-year high of $40.2 billion. Department analysts say exports may be down a bit, but don't bet that imports will follow suit. Imports in the 1990 fiscal year were at a record $22.5 billion, according to a report by Stephen R. Milmoe of the department's Economic Research Service. That was up $1 billion from the previous high set in 1989. As a result, that squeezed the U.S. agricultural trade surplus - the difference in value between exports and imports - to $17.7 billion, compared with $18.2 billion the previous year. Back in 1972, when U.S. farm exports were loafing along at $8.2 billion, the import value that year was $5.9 billion. The agricultural trade surplus was $2.3 billion. Exports took off after that, rising to a record $43.8 billion in 1981 before turning down during most of the 1980s. In those heady years of the late 1970s and early 1980s, the farm trade surplus steamed along at more than $20 billion a year. In the year that ended on Sept. 30, some of the big-ticket import items included $2.85 billion worth of meat and meat products, nearly $2 billion worth of coffee, $1.2 billion worth of fresh or frozen vegetables, $925 million worth of bananas, $921 million worth of wine, and $588 million worth of tobacco. Not to mention 12,000 metric tons of feathers and down valued at $69.8 million. The 39,000 tons of castor oil was worth $36.3 million. Essential oils that smell good, fresh mangoes, pistachio nuts, tea, chestnuts, nursery stock, sesame seed, palm oil, canned mushrooms and hops were among the import items. Farm exports were largely concentrated in the value of huge bulk items such as grains and feed worth $15.7 billion; animals and animal products, $6.55 billion; soybeans and other oilseeds and products, $6.1 billion; cotton, $2.7 billion; vegetables and their products, $2.08 billion; fruits and various preparations, $1.86 billion; and tobacco, $1.37 billion. Within those categories were some items just as exotic as those on the import side. For example, last year's U.S. exports included 55,000 tons of horsemeat valued at $147.5 million; 39.7 million baby chicks, $80.3 million; 5.1 million mink pelts, $115.7 million; and 49,000 tons of lard. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - A rise in the use of feed grains to fatten livestock is being more than offset in an expected decline in exports, according to an Agriculture Department report. Overall, the total supply of feed grains - corn, sorghum, oats and barley - is forecast at 276.9 million metric tons in the 1990-91 marketing year, down 11.5 million tons from 1989-90. Production rose but not enough to offset a drop in inventories at the beginning of the year. Total U.S. use of feed grain is expected to decline 5 million tons from 242 million tons in 1989-90 as a result of the export decrease, the report said. Even so, total use is forecast to exceed production, meaning a drop in feed grain inventories at the end of the 1990-91 season. A metric ton is about 2,205 pounds and is equal to 39.5 bushels of corn. It is the favored unit in measuring total feed grain supplies. ``World production of coarse grains (such as corn and sorghum) is forecast to rise 2.5 percent in 1990-91 to 820 million tons, the highest in four years,'' the report said. ``Foreign production is expected to advance 2 percent to a record 590 million tons, with the Soviet Union and China accounting for much of the gains.'' Global feed grain use was put at 825 million tons, indicating some draw-down in world inventories during the year. Foreign use is expected to fall slightly for the first time in five years. ``The most significant declines are expected in Europe, where corn production is down significantly,'' the report said. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - With some exceptions, pastures and livestock across the nation were reported in ``mostly fair to good'' condition as of mid-November, according to a government report. The Joint Agricultural Weather Facility - an operation of the Agriculture and Commerce departments - said in this week's review that pastures in California, North Dakota and Utah were in ``mostly poor'' shape. Water for livestock in the southern two-thirds of California was said to be in short supply.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: U.S. Campaign Against Iraq Needs Moscow's Help
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The off-again, on-again attitude of the Soviet Union on using force to liberate Kuwait is a problem for the Bush administration. Moscow's support is vital, and November is drawing to a close. The significance of the calendar is that the United States is president of the United Nations Security Council this month. Then it's Yemen's turn, and the Arab nation has opposed most of the resolutions aimed at Iraq since the August invasion. Running the Security Council gives the Bush administration a tactical advantage. Once Yemen is in the chair it would be that much tougher to win adoption of a resolution to use force as a last resort to liberate Kuwait. ``There's a lot of ways to get thoroughly wrapped around the axle of the United Nations,'' a senior State Department official said recently about the intricacies of the world organization. ``There are a whole host of other things that can come up. So it's important to try and do it during the period of our presidency of the council.'' Which explains why Secretary of State James A. Baker III decided to go to Yemen this week. But Yemen's president, Gen. Ali Abdullah Saleh, rebuffed Baker's efforts Thursday to win his country's support for a resolution authorizing the use of force. Saleh criticized the military buildup in the region and called for an Arab solution to the crisis. ``We knew it was going to be a very tough nut,'' said a State Department official who demanded anonymity. The need for Soviet support has been the case from the outset. Bush administration policy makers consider themselves fortunate that the Cold War thawed before Iraqi President Saddam Hussein decided to annex his smaller, oil-rich neighbor. The Soviets are more inclined than the United States to stress seeking a peaceful resolution of the Persian Gulf crisis. And yet, they have gone along with the Bush administration on all resolutions so far. Even at the Paris summit, when President Bush failed to get Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's concurrence on using force, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater was able to report the two leaders had ``reaffirmed their unity and commitment'' to have Iraq withdraw from Kuwait. Now the question is whether the Bush administration's determination to threaten Saddam with the prospect of an attack can be meshed with the Soviets' desire to give diplomacy more time to work. And the Soviets are not alone in that view. Several nations in the makeshift alliance against Iraq agree with Moscow, and so do many members of Congress. Whether Bush would actually pull the trigger and go to war over Kuwait is anyone's guess at this point. But there is no question that disagreement within the alliance on the issue would strengthen Saddam's hand. The Soviets, of course, have the power to block a resolution with a veto. While no one expects such a situation to arise, the Bush administration wants to be sure of more than cautious support from Moscow on using force. And Soviet leaders have been cautious and ambiguous. Asked in Paris on Monday if he thought ``force or patience'' would resolve the crisis, Gorbachev ducked. ``Well, I think we all need patience,'' he said. ``But that does not mean we are going to weaken, that we are going to retreat. No, we are going forward in a very resolute way.'' Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze was equally cautious - and imprecise - when he was asked in Moscow earlier in the month if Baker had convinced him that force might be necessary as a last resort. ``Whether or not the use of force could be ruled out - probably this could not be ruled out - and a situation may emerge which effectively would require such a move,'' Shevardnadze said. Only a few hours earlier, the Soviet foreign minister called the use of force ``undesirable.'' So with the clock ticking, and Saddam watching, the Bush administration hopes to cobble together a resolution Moscow can support - and get it passed before the end of November. --- EDITOR'S NOTE: Barry Schweid heads the AP's State Department staff.

DOC.HEAD: Dermatologists Call for Warnings on Ads
DOC.TEXT: Ads with sexy bronzed models should be required to carry health warnings that tanning can cause skin cancer, medical specialists said today. The advertising, fashion and marketing industries are irresponsibly promoting tans, counteracting efforts to encourage Australians to reduce their skin-cancer risk, the Australasian College of Dermatologists said. ``I believe that each of these pictures should in fact carry a warning, similar to those found on cigarette packets: suntanning is a cancer hazard,'' Dr. Alan Cooper, the college's honorary secretary, told a news conference. ``When I see parents with very young babies on beaches with no protection, I think that is child abuse,'' he added. Cooper called for a concerted effort to promote the image that ``the pale Australian is in, and the bronzed Aussie is out.'' Tell that to fans of Crocodile Dundee.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Actor Dennis Quaid is back in Hollywood after taking off a year to travel, get engaged and get clean. ``I guess I'm straight all the time. Rather than checking out of the world, I check into the world,'' Quaid says in the Dec. 10 issue of US magazine. ``I'm much crazier than I thought. It's all about how you go through life.'' Of his battle with drugs and alcohol, he says: ``You have a very hard, fast-paced life, and there's a lot of tension and pressure. And, at the end of the day, you find another way to deal with it. Which is to check out with drugs and booze.'' While moviegoers earlier this year saw him in ``Postcards from the Edge,'' Quaid was traveling in Europe and got engaged to actress Meg Ryan. Quaid says his next film, ``Come See the Paradise,'' a movie about the internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II, tells an important story. But he doesn't expect it will be a box-office smash. ``Certainly everyone would like to do movies that make all the money, but I can't make that my consideration in choosing a role,'' he said. --- PLYMOUTH, Mass. (AP) - Peace activist Dick Gregory began a fast to protest military action in the Persian Gulf and said he'd maintain it until all U.S. troops are returned home. Gregory began the fast Thanksgiving morning with a prayer vigil at Plymouth Rock. ``Thanksgiving is the day that we in America set aside to be thankful for the abundance of our land,'' Gregory said. ``It is hard to be completely thankful with war in the Persian Gulf casting a shadow across our country.'' Gregory was a civil rights activist in the 1960s and marched with Martin Luther King Jr. and Malcom X. The one-time stand-up comic is now considered a diet guru, for a liquid diet plan he created. President Bush recently ordered U.S. troop strength in Saudi Arabia doubled to about 400,000. The troops are part of a multinational force to contain possible aggression by Iraq, which invaded neighboring Kuwait on Aug. 2. --- FORT CAMPBELL, Ky. (AP) - Country star Tammy Wynette will perform a free Christmas concert Dec. 19 for soldiers, reservists and family members at Fort Campbell. ``This is her special tribute to the soldiers and family members of Operation Desert Shield,'' post spokesman Bill Harralson said Thursday. The entire 101st Airborne Division, about 19,000 soldiers, began deploying to Saudi Arabia in August. About 3,500 soldiers remain at the post and some reservists also are stationed there. The concert, organized by CBS Records, probably will include other entertainers to be announced later, Harralson said. Wynette is best known for her 1960s hits ``D-I-V-O-R-C-E'' and ``Stand By You Man.'' --- GUADALUPE, Spain (AP) - King Juan Carlos marked the 15th anniversary of his coronation with a visit to the Guadalupe monastery where his ancestors agreed to finance Columbus' voyage into the unknown. It was a fitting place to commemorate the start 15 years ago Thursday of his reign, which at first appeared such an unsure proposition that the head of the Communist Party nicknamed him Juan Carlos ``The Brief.'' Juan Carlos took over the government two days after the death of Gen. Francisco Franco, dictator for nearly four decades. But Franco miscalculated when he chose Juan Carlos to prolong his regime. The young monarch promptly presided over major democratic reforms, including the legalization of political parties and trade unions. Within two years, Spaniards had voted in their first free elections since 1936. By 1978, they adopted a constitution. His staunch backing of the constitutional government during a February 1981 military coup attempt helped foil the plot. In recent years, Juan Carlos, now 52, has kept a low political profile. But he continues to draw praise as a goodwill ambassador, along with Queen Sofia, easing Spain's entry into the European mainstream under a Socialist government.

DOC.HEAD: Alaskan Villagers Weep as Search for Independent 80-Year-Old is Called Off
DOC.TEXT: Villagers wept when the search for an independent 80-year-old man, who hunted and trapped his own food, was called off. Milton R. Trump, a towering, white-haired, white-bearded man, likely became lost or disabled in the snow while trying to hike into town when his snowmobile wouldn't go any farther, officials said. Alaska State Troopers called off the rescue effort this week after three days of fruitless searching. ``It doesn't look real good, unless he made it to a cabin,'' said Trump's 27-year-old son, Jim. The weather was mild Nov. 16, the last day Trump's daughter talked with him by radio. But a snowstorm dumped 8 inches of snow the following day, obscuring any tracks. More snow fell Monday, leaving a 1-foot accumulation on the ground. Trump's snowmobile was found parked along the Talkeetna River outside of this town about 75 miles north of Anchorage. Searchers speculated Trump abandoned the machine and tried to walk to town when it would go no further in the sparse snow cover. ``He had walked out before,'' said neighbor ``Trapper'' George Sanderlin, 58. ``He was a tough old son of a gun.'' Troopers flying over area cabins saw no signs of Trump. Family members and neighbors feared he might have fallen into the river. Trump lived in a cabin seven miles outside of town that he built himself 10 years ago, chopping his his own wood, and hunting and trapping his own food. ``He was a crusty old soul with a heart of gold,'' said Pam Rannals, who works at the Talkeetna Roadhouse. ``He acted like he was 35 years old,'' bush pilot Doug Getting said. ``He was always like a big kid.'' Many of Talkeetna's 600 residents showed up in September to help Trump celebrate his 80th birthday with a party featuring an exotic dancer. Trump, a retired mailman from Cleveland, also was a popular photographic subject with tourists, whom he charged for the privilege. A color spread from a Japanese magazine showing Trump in a stream holding a king salmon hangs on the wall of the lodge where his daughter, Nancy, works. He also posed in long underwear on Mt. McKinley for a foreign commercial. ``He was such a good looking Alaskan, you'd have thought he'd been here forever,'' Rannals said. In fact, Trump moved to Alaska with his three children in 1970 after retiring from his postal job.

DOC.HEAD: Singapore Cracks Down On Uncleanliness
DOC.TEXT: The government is cracking down on uncleanliness, ordering people who litter to undergo counseling and fining people who don't flush after using public toilets. A fine of $17 (U.S.) will be introduced from Dec. 1 for those who neglect to flush, the Environment Ministry said. Incorribile non-flushers may have to pay as much as $588 for three or more offenses. The ministry said littering was getting worse despite fines of up to $588. Counseling for litterers is to consist of a 15-minute pep talk in which the culprit will be told how such an antisocial act can harm the environment. The authorities have mounted regular drives since 1968 to raise civic consciousness to keep Singapore clean. What was once one of the filthiest cities in Southeast Asia is now spotless by comparison with most municipalities.

DOC.HEAD: Army Families Share Thanksgiving Dinner on Post
DOC.TEXT: Families who missed their soldier kin during Thanksgiving dinner in Fort Campbell mess halls expect Christmas will be even lonelier. Lorraine Gould said her husband, Staff Sgt. Henry Gould, never missed a birthday, Thanksgiving or Christmas with his family during 14 years in the Army until he was sent to the Persian Gulf. Instead of sharing turkey dinner with their husband and father on Thursday, Mrs. Gould and her three children sat down with 3,000 other family members and friends of soldiers. ``We've already mailed Christmas presents to Saudi Arabia,'' Mrs. Gould said. ``It's hard for the kids to understand because he was always here for the holidays.'' Her oldest, Jason, celebrated his eighth birthday the day before. He was given a set of encyclopedias, and the first thing he did was look up Saudi Arabia, to find out where his father was. ``There was a map and Saudi Arabia was just a little shape,'' he said. ``It's real far away.'' Jason said he understood why his father was away. ``It's because of Saddam Hussein. He's stealing oil to make lots of money. He stole Kuwait and he has to give it back.'' The relatives and friends who crowded into four mess halls at Fort Campbell paid $2.45 for a meal almost identical to the one soldiers ate in the desert. ``This way everyone can gather around and meet other people that have husbands in the Persian Gulf. It helps them feel less alone,'' said cook foreman Sam Tugadi, who began decorating cakes and preparing 144 pounds of boneless turkey two days earlier. A similar meal is planned for Christmas. The dinner started with shrimp cocktail and ended with a choice of 12 types of pie. In between there were turkey and dressing, ham, and cornish hen. Fruits and nuts and cakes were spread across long tables. The four mess halls hummed and clattered with activity, but the rest of the post was nearly deserted. The entire 101st Airborne Division, about 19,000 soldiers, went sent to the Middle East in August and September. About 3,500 soldiers still remain at the post on the Tennessee-Kentucky line, post officials said. Lynn Quinlan, 41, said she came to the mess hall to spend Thanksgiving with other Army wives while her husband, Lt. Col. Kenneth Quinlan, was in the desert. ``The unit's support is every bit as wonderful as my family at home,'' she said. ``This is also my family here.'' Meggin Garrett, 18, said she couldn't imagine Christmas without her father, Col. Thomas Garrett, dressed in his Santa Claus suit, entertaining the children at a giant family get-together. ``He's only been away one time at Christmas, when he was in Vietnam,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Rotting Schooners Allowed To Stay, But Some Fear Decay
DOC.TEXT: Two schooners on the National Register of Historic Places will not be moved from their muddy moorings to make way for a new marina. But some fear the sailing ships will allowed to crumble into the river. Abandoned, rotting and moss-covered, the two schooners that have been mired in the water at the edge of this coastal town for nearly six decades were targeted for removal as part of an effort to rebuild the area. ``If they touch the schooners they'll be dead,'' First Selectman Lawrence Gordon said after the board Tuesday scuttled the plan to move the ships from where they've been since 1932. Gordon said the selectmen would never let the town Waterfront Committee's recommendation come up for a vote at a town meeting. The committee worked for more than a year on a five-year plan for the banks of the Sheepscot River, where the venerable Luther Little and Hesper schooners are visible to thousands of tourists who drive by on U.S. Route 1. The panel's first priority was to remove the ships to make room for a marina, a waterfront walkway and possibly a dock for cruise ships or windjammers. The committee hoped the ships would be preserved in Maine's maritime museums. Now, Waterfront Committee Chairman Daniel Thompson worries that the last four-masted, World War I-era coal schooners on the East Coast will left to decay and rot in the river. But Selectman Benjamin Rines Jr. said he was offended that anyone would consider taking the schooners out of the river. ``Those ships are part of a family and you just don't put them in a museum,'' said Rines. The ships are on the National Register of Historic Places and are part of the town's historic district. Wiscasset, a town of 3,800 about 35 miles northeast of Portland, has been home to the Luther Little and the Hesper since they were towed up the Sheepscot River by Frank W. Winter, who wanted to use them to haul lumber from a northern Maine mill to Boston and New York. But the scheme fell victim to the Great Depression and Winter's death. Trains that were to carry the lumber never rolled and the ships were never removed. The Luther Little, which was launched in 1917, and the Hesper, which was launched in 1918, have been ravaged by fires and nature over the years. The Hesper has lost its masts, and trees have sprouted through holes in its hull. The Luther Little still has its masts, but parts of its hull have rotted away.

DOC.HEAD: Presidential Candidate Lech Walesa Predicts More Unrest in Poland
With PM-Poland-Election
DOC.TEXT: Polish presidential candidate Lech Walesa was quoted today as saying he expects new unrest in his homeland. In an interview in Die Welt, a respected Bonn newspaper, the Solidarity leader predicted a ``big struggle'' because ``our reforms are not making progress. ``There are still no private owners,'' he was quoted as saying. ``The majority of businesses are still in state hands.'' On Sunday Walesa challenges Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, a former friend and ally, in Poland's first popular presidential election. The country shed its four-decade-old communist government in August last year. Walesa has demanded quicker privatization of the economy, while Mazowiecki has taken a slower approach which he says must be based on law. Walesa told the newspaper he considered it ``unlikely'' that he would lose the election, and public opinion polls have him in the lead. ``But it is always possible,'' he said. ``Winston Churchill won the war, but then lost the election.''

DOC.HEAD: Kids Dress Up Magazines For Troops in Saudi Arabia
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: American teen-agers in Germany have launched a ``cover-up'' mission for Persian Gulf soldiers yearning for reading material. Using marking pens and an eye for what may offend Saudi sensibilities, the teens have been drawing over pictures of scantily clad people and advertisements for alcohol and tobacco products. ``The original plan was that they were just going to cut out the pictures, but after the first three magazines they had edited out, there was nothing left,'' said U.S. Air Force 2nd Lt. Bryan Stokstad, who organized the magazine drive. Stokstad, of Des Moines, Iowa, said he got the idea after reading an article in the unofficial military newspaper Stars and Stripes ``that the morale down there was just a little bit low'' because troops didn't have enough current publications. ``They were receiving the Stars and Stripes, but they were getting issues a week late, and just for them to circulate around it would take even longer,'' Stockstad said Thursday. He said the project was started in mid-October, and as of last week the volunteers had sent out 2,500 pounds of magazines to Saudi Arabia through the military postal system. ``We have about 750 pounds of magazines that are left and ready to go out, and I'm hoping we'll be able to send them off soon,'' said Stokstad, who works in the command post of Sembach Air Base near Kaiserslautern, about 60 miles southwest of Frankfurt. At first, he said he set up collection points at the base recreation center, the shopping center and the chapel at the air base, asking for donations of current news magazines. Then he contacted a base teenage group called LIFE, which stands for Life is for Everyone, to ask for help in editing pictures that the Saudis might find offensive. The nearly 20 youths in the group range in age of 12 to 18. He said that one of the teen-age girls came up with the idea of drawing clothes on the pictures. ``That way if there was an article on the back of a page it wouldn't be disturbed,'' said Stokstad. ``It kind of took over from there, and basically that's what we're doing. Drawing clothes and covering things up with markers.'' ``There was a lady that was in an advertisment for brassieres, and one of the girls drew a blouse on her. It looked real good,'' he added. ``We've also been covering up anything associated with alcohol and tobacco.'' The magazines sent include Time, People, U.S. News and World Report, and sports and car magazines, Stokstad said. ``It's amazing the amount of magazines we have received,'' Stokstad said. ``Magazines are expensive. One box that came in had a collection of 40 to 50 National Geographics all in perfect condition.''

DOC.HEAD: Saddam's Babylonian Dream Dashed by Invasion of Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: The chief archaeologist was picking dates from a tree to kill time and ease her boredom in the legendary gardens of Babylon, where Saddam Hussein wants to rebuild one of the wonders of the ancient world. Shafeka Mohammed Jaafar has no work because Iraq's invasion of Kuwait stalled efforts to restore the glory of Babylon, whose kings ruled an empire that stretched over most of the Middle East. Saddam, the self-styled ``Knight of the Arab nation,'' fancies himself a modern-day Nebuchadnezzar, Babylon's most famous king. Iraqi laborers, many of them military reservists, have been called up to bolster Saddam's army facing more than 330,000 multinational troops massed in the deserts of Saudi Arabia. Also, thousands of Sudanese and Egyptian laborers fled Babylon after the Aug. 2 invasion. An estimated $100 million was spent on the project over the last decade. But funds have became scarce as Saddam juggles a cash squeeze brought on by the U.N.-supported embargo on Iraqi trade and oil exports. A lone soldier with an AK-47 rifle now stands guard at the entrance to Nebuchadnezzar's partially rebuilt Babylon. ``Before, our president used to visit us regularly, but after he liberated Kuwait, he has not come even once,'' said Mrs. Jaafar, 47. ``He's very busy now fighting Zionist and imperialist forces,'' she added, nibbling at her freshly collected dates. More than 2,500 years ago, Babylon rose in the land of Mesopotamia on the Euphrates River. Under Nebuchadnezzar, Babylon entered its golden age. Its Hanging Gardens, one of the so-called ``seven wonders of the world,'' long ago crumbled to dust. An artificial lake has been dug to irrigate the future gardens. For 1,200 years, the Babylonians ruled an empire that flourished as a cultural, religious and commercial center. According to some traditions, the Garden of Eden in the Bible was in this land between the Tigris and Euphrates rivers. Under Saddam, a new Babylon has begun to rise again. An estimated 15 million bricks, baked as they were centuries ago, have been used to rebuild the city's monuments. The plans are based on archaeological evidence, cuneiform texts of Babylonian characters and descriptions from ancient historians. Every 100th brick bears the name of Saddam in Arabic proclaiming the Iraqi leader's efforts to reconstruct Babylon. To Saddam and many Iraqi officials, restoring Babylon is more than an archaeological venture. ``After centuries we've got Saddam, a great leader who's going to restore the past glory of our land. It's only Saddam who can do that,'' Mrs. Jaafar said as she guided reporters through the ruins of the 8-square-mile city. Iraqis are constantly told that Saddam can restore the lost glory of Babylon. The state-owned news media and dozens of books stress that Babylon once controlled the land that is now Iraq, Syria, Jordan, Lebanon, Kuwait and Israel. Reminders of Saddam are everywhere in Babylon, as they are in the rest of Iraq. On the 55-mile journey from Baghdad south to Babylon, past oil refineries and anti-aircraft batteries, Saddam's portraits appear on almost every building, at gasoline stations and fruit stands. The road to Babylon branches off the highway before the town of Hilla. At the entrance to modern Babylon, a small town of one-story houses, stands a huge portrait of Saddam wearing an Arab keffiyeh headdress with a white dove of peace fluttering over his head. ``Saddam is no ordinary leader and no ordinary president,'' said Mrs. Jaafar. ``He is the new Nebuchadnezzar.'' Portraits of Saddam and Nebuchadnezzar are displayed side-by-side in Babylon and Baghdad. In the souvenir shop at Babylon, pamphlets and books carry portraits of Saddam after the title page. Nebuchadnezzar is hailed for his dual role as a civilian and military leader. The same image is projected in Baghdad in portraits showing Saddam in fatigues or in Western suits. The Iraqi media refers to Saddam as ``father-leader,'' ``hero of national liberation'' and ``standard-bearer of Islam.'' Nebuchadnezzar is projected to Iraqis as the defender of the ``Arab nation,'' even though he lived 1,000 years before there was such a concept. Nebuchadnezzar conquered Jerusalem, took the people of Israel into captivity for 50 years and fought for years against the Persians - not unlike Saddam's 1980-88 war with Iran, the modern-day Persia. Nebuchadnezzar died in 562 B.C., 24 years before the city was captured by the Persians.

DOC.HEAD: Cranberries in Short Supply Over Holiday season
DOC.TEXT: Canned cranberry sauce was a common item on Thanksgiving dinner tables because a weather-damaged crop left growers with few fresh berries to sell this year. ``Fresh cranberries? Forget it. The fat lady sang two weeks ago,'' said John C. Decas, an owner of Decas Bros. in Wareham, a major cranberry grower and marketer. The crop of sour berries dropped 30 percent statewide from last year's harvest. Wholesalers usually sell berries to retailers up to a few days before Christmas, but this year they began rationing sales for the Thanksgiving holiday and ran out altogether earlier this month. The cranberry shortage was caused by inclement weather. The December 1989 deep freeze damaged some vines, and an 8-inch, bog-flooding rainfall on Cape Cod and adjacent areas in late July was devastating, leading to rot. Massachusetts traditionally is the nation's biggest cranberry grower, accounting for half the U.S. crop. Wisconsin might take over the top spot this year once this year's figures are in. It had only a slightly below-average crop. Not surprisingly, the shortage has brought higher prices. ``I saw our berries on sale at a local store at $1.59 for a 12-ounce pack - amazing,'' Decas said. Last year the price was in the 89 cents to $1.09 range. Retailers are getting more out of the shortage than those who raise the berries, he said. ``Growers got a much more modest 10 percent price increase for their berries,'' Decas said.

DOC.HEAD: In Survey, Children Choose Most Expensive, Most Action-Packed Toys
With PM-Christmas Sales, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Gone are the days of spinning tops and building blocks. Nowadays, children favor noisy, action-packed toys and games, and have an uncanny knack for choosing the most expensive, a survey found. Topping the list of favorites were an electronic bowling alley costing $140 and a $50 fire engine with realistic horn and siren sounds, the Third Annual Duracell National Toy Survey found. Nearly 600 children between the ages of 5 and 9 recently ``play-tested'' 22 toys at their local YMCA after-school programs for at least one hour per day over 10 consecutive school days. Children in 30 programs nationwide voted for their favorites both on the first and the last day of play. Not all the toys used in the survey require batteries, the Bethel-based battery giant was quick to point out. But the top three toys chosen by the children do. Most popular were top-ranked Power Alley Electronic Bowling by Marchon, an electronic extravaganza designed to turn a playroom into a bowling alley, and the Sound Machine Water Cannon fire engine by Nylint. One 6-year-old boy described the appeal of the fire engine perfectly, saying he liked it ``because it makes a lot of noise,'' the survey said. Another 6-year-old called the bowling game ``fun, big and automatic.'' The third most popular toy was Sound FX by Mattel, a wrist speaker that produces sounds and music when cued by body movements. The survey, analyzed by TrendSights, a consumer research and evaluation company, found a marked difference in the selections of boys and girls. While boys voted in large numbers for the heavy action and mechanical toys like the top three, girls tended to favor low-intensity competitive group games and the more intellectually challenging games, the survey said. The fourth and fifth most popular selections - Super Dough Magic Show, a game in which children perform magic tricks with modeling clay, and Rattle Me Bones, a hand-eye coordination game in which players must carefully remove objects from a skeleton without disturbing it - were heavily favored by girls, the survey said. The top 12 list contains one or two variations on longtime childhood favorites. Monopoly Junior by Parker Brothers - a simplified version of the classic board game, which revolves around life at an amusement park - was the sixth most popular toy on the list. Lights Alive - a high-tech, multicolored version of the ever-popular sketchboard, in which children can create pictures on a magic screen that can be easily wiped cleaned - ranked 11th.

DOC.HEAD: With Beat-Up Truck, Woman Delivers Holiday Cheer, Free Food
DOC.TEXT: As many overfed Americans try to recover from their Thanksgiving feasts, Nancy Jamison will nurse her ailing truck back into the city's poorest neighborhoods today to hand out food to the needy. On Thursday, Jamison pulled her dilapidated yellow truck up to the Pilgrim Congregational Church in Boston's Dorchester section to deliver bread, onions and carrots to people who didn't have turkey for Thanksgiving. It was just another day for Jamison. Today, assuming the temperamental transmission on her truck doesn't seize up entirely, Jamison will return to the church to hand out surplus food again. ``Millions of pounds of food, darlin', are dumped every day while people are starving,'' she said Thursday. ``Mayonnaise sandwiches are a reality, my dear.'' A 40-year-old former fashion designer, Jamison is a one-woman food program, delivering vegetables and bread to the city's neediest people. Her ailing truck is always met at the Pilgrim church by a crowd of hungry people. Thursday, a throng of handicapped people, Cape Verdean immigrants, elderly and homeless filed past her, stuffing paper bags with food other people deemed unacceptable to sell. ``Peace to you sister,'' Jamison said, reaching out to one elderly woman. ``Go on, get a bag,'' she said to a hesitant patron who whispered she had no money for a donation. ``Ah, it's free today sister. You go get the old ladies and bring `em out here.'' ``This helps me,'' said Florence St. Marie, a 67-year-old retiree who cares for her handicapped son. ``I run short on money. Without her I wouldn't know what to do.'' Jamison often wonders why she spends her days traveling Boston's most poverty-stricken areas, feeding the least fortunate. ``I get up every Thanksgiving and curse myself,'' she said. ``I ask myself, `Am I nuts or what?''' Tired of fashion design and frustrated ``seeing all those people pay 1,200 bucks for coats,'' Jamison turned to community service in the mid-1970s. She did everything from political organizing to gathering wood for fuel for the poor. Two years ago, upset by the poverty she saw on Boston streets, Jamison decided to start the group Fair Foods. She and a handful of volunteers deliver 40,000 pounds of surplus food to 45 churches and community centers each week. Fair Foods relies on the Best Foods bakery chain for much of its supply. Wholesale produce outlets donate slightly damaged vegetables. Clad in faded jeans and a down vest, graying hair tied in a ponytail, Jamison describes herself as ``a rich honky.'' She is frustrated that her ``liberal friends from the 1960s'' won't jump on the bandwagon - or truck, so to speak. ``We have been hiding our poor people very effectively for the last 10 years, but the depths of their suffering have increased dramatically,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Twins Brothers Separated for First Time By Gulf Conflict
DOC.TEXT: Folks have been getting the Polasky twins confused for years. But during this holiday season, they can tell which is which. Tom is the one on duty in the Persian Gulf. Tim is the one left at home on the family's dairy farm. The 20-year-old brothers are separated for the first time in their lives by half the world and an Army regulation that allows only one at a time to be sent overseas. ``I was glad I didn't have to go, but I wish both of us could have stayed home,'' says Tim, who wears an Operation Desert Shield T-shirt. Even though he has exclusive use of the car he and his brother always shared, Tim says it feels strange and lonesome - especially during the holidays. The family's traditional Thanksgiving dinner wasn't the same without Tom and Jeanne Polasky says her son sounds depressed when he calls from Saudi Arabia. ``There's nothing to do,'' she says. ``They play a lot of cards and spend half their time sleeping.'' The twins joined the North Dakota Army National Guard last winter. The Army kept them together for basic training and boot camp, and both were assigned to the 132nd Quartermaster Detachment of Cando, about 60 miles northeast of their farm. ``We requested they go together,'' says their mother. ``They wanted to go together.'' When their unit was activated Sept. 10, Mrs. Polasky prepared to say goodbye to both. Instead, Tom was put on a bus to Fort McCoy, Wis., and Tim was transferred to another outfit. Mrs. Polasky's first letters to her son said ``See you at Christmas.'' Now, she counts on him being back for his sister's wedding in June. By then, it could be Tim's turn to ship out.

DOC.HEAD: For Thatcher, The Fall Began In Rome
With PM-Britain-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's decline has been happening slowly for years, but the crisis erupted less than a month ago in Rome. The occasion was a summit meeting for the 12 leaders of the European Community, which began Oct. 27. Mrs. Thatcher, often at odds with continental leaders, was again alone in an 11-1 vote in favor of setting up a European central bank and working toward a common currency. At home, Deputy Prime Minister Geoffrey went on a television interview show and predicted the prime minister would eventually fall into line. There had been other fights, Howe said, and Mrs. Thatcher usually came around. She returned home saying the other 11 European leaders were living in ``cloud cuckoo land.'' On Oct. 30, Mrs. Thatcher was at the center of particularly rowdy session in the House of Commons, rejecting any thought of surrendering sovereignty to a European super-state. ``No, no, no!,'' she shouted.
