Neil Kinnock, leader of the opposition Labor Party, needled Mrs. Thatcher by inviting her to affirm her support for Howe. She passed. On Nov. 1, Howe resigned. That revived talk of a Conservative Party revolt against Mrs. Thatcher, and inevitably interest turned to Michael Heseltine, widely regarded as a prime minister in waiting ever since he resigned from the Cabinet in January 1986. As he had so many times before, Heseltine said he could not foresee the circumstances in which he would stand against Mrs. Thatcher. Wary of a possible challenge, Mrs. Thatcher on Nov. 6 moved up the annual leadership election, which could have been held as late as Dec. 5. She moved it to Nov. 20. On Nov. 8, the Conservatives suffered a humiliating third-place finish in a special parliamentary election in Bradford, a district the Conservatives had won in the early 1980s. That reinforced the message of the opinion polls, which for months had shown Mrs. Thatcher's party trailing the Labor Party. But the polls also began to show that voters were more favorable toward the Conservatives with Heseltine as leader. The Conservatives, or Tories, were burdened by public unhappiness over high interest rates, double-digit inflation and rising unemployment. Above all, Mrs. Thatcher's government had infuriated legions of voters by replacing the property tax with a flat tax on every adult, the same rate for millionaires as for street-sweepers. On Nov. 13, Howe delievered a scathing indictment of the prime minister - a speech as remarkable for its content as for its author, the long-suffering, soft-spoken last survivor of Mrs. Thatcher's original Cabinet of 1979. The next day, Heseltine said he would challenge Mrs. Thatcher for leadership of the party and the government. Confident of winning, Mrs. Thatcher went ahead with plans to attend the European security summit in Paris, and that's where she was Tuesday when she learned that Heseltine had stopped he short of an outright victory on the first ballot. She said she would fight on. The next day, she returned to London, consulted with party leaders and told the nation, ``I fight on. I fight to win.'' But Cabinet members told her she did not have the votes to win. On Thursday morning she decided to resign. Press Association, the domestic news agency, said Mrs. Thatcher informed aides, who in turn telephoned Buckingham Palace and notified President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher, in Waning Hours of Rule, Presides Over Emotional Session
With PM-Britain-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Hours after Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher announced her resignation, she tore into the opposition in Parliament and gave them a taste of what they have lost. ``I'm enjoying this! I'm enjoying this!'' she shouted during one interruption by opposition Labor Party members. And so, it seemed, were the lawmakers who packed the seats and spilled into the aisles and stairways of the House of Commons. ``You can wipe the floor with those people!'' Tory colleague Toby Jessel shouted in encouragement. Conservative lawmakers, including those who voted against her in the party's leadership battle, were on their feet and waving their agenda papers as Mrs. Thatcher came in for her regular Thursday session answering questions. Her opponents, at first, paid tribute to a valiant adversary, defeated but clearly unbowed. Though she will still be answering prime minister's questions at least until Tuesday, this was clearly a last hurrah. Liberal Democrat leader Paddy Ashdown rose to tell the house ``No one can doubt ... her courage, conviction and the determination that she has brought to her premiership.'' ``She amounts to more than those who have turned upon her in recent days,'' said Neil Kinnock, who had traded innumerable insults with her in his eight years as leader of the opposition Labor Party. But when the house began debating a motion of no confidence submitted by Kinnock, the gloves came off. ``The government is riddled with distrust, just as the Conservative Party is racked with disagreement, which cannot be healed under any leader at any time,'' said Kinnock. ``In the present circumstances there really isn't much of a government in which to have no confidence.'' ``Windy rhetoric,'' Mrs. Thatcher replied, and several hours later the governing Conservatives easily defeated Kinnock's motion. Mrs. Thatcher's attack was often severe, but there were frequent moments of laughter. Any mirth was lost, however, on Bernard Ingham, the prime minister's glowering press secretary, who moped in the gallery, head in hands. Mrs. Thatcher said the Conservatives had ``rescued Britain from the parlous state to which socialism had brought it,'' 11 years ago. ``Once again Britain stands tall in the councils of Europe and of the world,'' she said. ``We have given back control to people over their own lives and over their livelihood.'' Aside from a brief coughing spell, her voice did not waver until she spoke of Britain's strong response to the Persian Gulf crisis. ``When good has to be upheld, when evil has to be overcome then Britain will take up arms,'' she said. ``It is because we on this side (the Conservatives) have never flinched from difficult decisions that this house and this country can have confidence in this government today.'' On Thursday, Mrs. Thatcher ordered an additional 14,000 British troops to the Persian Gulf, bringing Britain's total to more than 30,000. When she sat down, most of the Conservatives stood, shouted and rattled their papers. ``This is the saddest day of my political life,'' said Conservative member Cranley Onslow, who counted the votes in the leadership election. Fighting to control his emotions, Onslow said Mrs. Thatcher's achievements ``must not be overlooked in our tears of rage.''

DOC.HEAD: Mubarak Remains Pessimistic About Gulf Crisis
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 4th graf to reflect that Mubarak made informal remarks; conform `Kubbah' to style; INSERTS grafs 5-10, bgng, However xxx etc., with further Mubarak quotes; Picks up 5th graf pvs, bgng, Bush got xxx etc.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, trying to tighten the Arab coalition against Iraq, held talks today with Egypt's Hosni Mubarak after an exhilarating Thanksgiving visit with U.S. combat forces at remote desert outposts. ``We won't pull punches,'' Bush promised troops in Saudi Arabia. The Egyptian president put aside his cautious style of leadership to lead Arab opposition to Iraq after its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Bush rewarded Mubarak by requesting - and obtaining - congressional legislation waiving more than $7 billion in Egyptian military debt to the United States. Neither Bush nor Mubarak issued any formal statements today as they commenced their talks at Kubbah Palace, an ornate guest house for foreign officials visiting Egypt. However, during a picture-taking session, the Egyptian president said that all peaceful means to end the crisis should be exhausted. He declined to say when or if force should be used. ``Kuwait should be liberated by all means,'' Mubarak told reporters. ``We will try all the peaceful means. If there is no other way ... It depends on the Iraqis.'' Asked how much time Iraq should be given to pull out from the country it invaded on Aug. 2, Mubarak said: ``We will discuss this with the (U.S.) president.'' He said he was pessimistic about a peaceful solution because Iraq was not willing to compromise. ``I am by nature very optimistic but at this time, to a certain extent, I am very pessimistic,'' Mubarak told a television crew. Asked whether Egypt was wavering in its anti-Iraqi stance, he replied, ``There is no change. We are firm.'' Later, he explained his pessimism, saying ``there is no slight move from the other side. We have to wait and see.'' Bush got a red carpet greeting, bands played the two countries' national anthems and the two leaders posed briefly for pictures before plunging into discussions about the Persian Gulf crisis. Later, Bush was flying to Geneva - his last stop on an eight-day trip - to confer with Syrian President Hafez Assad, a bitter foe of Iraq's Saddam Hussein. Bush is the first U.S. president since Jimmy Carter in 1977 to meet with Assad, whose government has been denounced by the United States as a supporter of terrorism and oppressor of human rights. The president said he was seeing Assad simply because of their common stand against Saddam. Bush's difficulty in maintaining an Arab coalition was underscored Thursday when Secretary of State James A. Baker III was rebuffed in efforts to get Yemen, the only Arab nation on the United Nations Security Council, to support a resolution authorizing the use of force against Iraq. Yemen's president, Gen. Ali Abdullah Saleh, criticized the military buildup in the region and called for an Arab solution to the crisis. Yet, a State Department official said, ``They didn't say no'' to a new U.N. measure. Bush was in high spirits Thursday after hop-scotching by helicopter across eastern Saudi Arabia to spend Thanksgiving with troops who someday may be ordered to war to drive Iraq out of Kuwait. The president, accompanied by his wife Barbara, came within 65 miles of the border with Kuwait, stopping at an encampment for U.S. Marines. Bush called it ``an unforgettable experience.'' It was a scene of endless desert, marked only by clumps of camouflage netting that concealed combat vehicles and other equipment. Altogether, the president saw about 5,000 to 6,000 of the 230,000 American troops in the Persian Gulf. ``We won't pull punches,'' the president promised. ``We are not here on some exercise. And we're not walking away until our mission is done, until the invader is out of Kuwait. ``And that may well be where you come in,'' he pointedly told the troops, who responded with hoots of approval. The Bushes, joined by the four top congressional leaders, ate two Thanksgiving dinners with troops at desert outposts and attended worship services on a ship in the Persian Gulf. Bush also spoke to a combination of American, British, Saudi and Kuwaiti troops at an air base in Dhahran. ``I think the waiting is a difficult part of this,'' Bush said, expressing understanding for the troops' anxiety and frustration. ``But I sense a certain resolve on their part. They want to do something and they want to do it fast, and get it over.'' ``It was a very emotional day,'' Bush said. ``These are the ones doing the heavy lifting. God bless them all.'' Some troops expressed impatience to get home. ``Let's go get him (Saddam) now so we can go home,'' Army Spec. 4 Gwendolyn Page shouted at Bush at Dhahran. Army Reserves Capt. Don Shiarla, a financial planner from Salem, Ore., who had to leave his business to serve in the gulf, expressed frustration that Bush was not rotating reservists and that his call-up had been extended for a second 90-day period. ``We'll stay until the job's done, but let's just get going. I think it's time to make a statement,'' he told a reporter. Bush emphasized several times that Iraq soon could be a nuclear power, though experts put the timetable at five years or more. It was the first time he'd raised the issue as a key component of his anti-Iraq policy. ``No one knows precisely when this dictator may acquire atomic weapons or exactly who they may be aimed at down the road. But we do know this for sure: he's never possessed a weapon he didn't use,'' Bush said. Bush's journey took him through Europe and the Middle East. Before flying to Paris last week for a 34-nation summit, he stopped in Prague, becoming the first U.S. president ever to visit Czechoslovakia. After a weekend at Camp David, Bush will depart Monday for an overnight visit in Mexico.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Kill Japanese, Note Links Murder To Fujimori's Background
DOC.TEXT: Maoist rebels with machine guns shot and killed a man believed to be a Japanese citizen, leaving a note saying the man was slain because he and Peruvian President Alberto Fujimori are of the same race, police say. The attack in an eastern jungle late Wednesday would be the first killing of a Japanese citizen in Peru's 10 years of political violence that hs left more than 20,000 people dead. The same rebel group earlier Wednesday killed the wife and mother-in-law of an official in the same village, police said Thursday. Hours later in the same area, police killed 10 rebels when they ambushed a large column of Shining Path guerrillas. Two policemen died in the firefight. Police identified the Japanese citizen as 45-year-old Wakamiya Makamori. They said he was visiting Peruvian friends who own farms in the area. The village where Makamori was killed, Alto Paureli, is located 20 miles southeast of Satipo, a jungle town 170 miles east of Lima. Police said Makamori was shot by six rebels armed with machine guns. The rebels stopped Makamori's car as they were leaving the village after killing the two women, police said. The rebels left a note next to Makamori's body that said he was killed ``for being Japanese, like Fujimori.'' Police said Makamori's money, passport and other documents were taken by the rebels. His body was identified by the friends he had been visiting, police said. Makamori's body was taken Thursday to Satipo, police said. It was to be flown to Lima today, they said. The reports were issued by police in Huancayo, a mountainous state capital 120 miles east of Lima. The Japanese Embassy Thursday said it had not yet been informed of the attack. Government officials have said the number of Japanese tourists to Peru has increased since Fujimori was elected Peru's president in June. Fujimori parents were both born in Japan. About 60,000 Peruvians trace their heritage to Japan. The colony is the second largest in South America, after Brazil. Police said their clash with the rebel column took place outside Gloriabamba, a village 15 miles southeast of Satipo. Police said there were about 150 rebels in the column. The firefight lasted over four hours, they said. More than 20,000 Peruvians have been killed in political violence since the Shining Path took up arms in 1980.

DOC.HEAD: Thanksgiving 1990 Tinged with Sadness
DOC.TEXT: Americans gorged themselves on turkey and watched parades and football on Thanksgiving, but the dy for family get-togethers was bittersweet for those with loved ones in the Persian Gulf. ``We'll all be aware of the empty place at the table,'' Vernon Hunt, 56, of Des Plaines, Ill., said before his family sat down to dinner. Hunt's son, Stephen, is a Marine stationed on a battleship in the Persian Gulf. The holiday was gloomier for diplomats and others held captive by Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein. Embassy staff in Kuwait dined on canned tuna fish washed down with water salvaged from a swimming pool. Some hostages in Iraq were treated to lavish Thanksgiving feasts attended by news reporters before they returned to detention at strategic sites or virtual house arrest in Baghdad. President Bush was upbeat while visiting troops in the Persian Gulf. First lady Barbara Bush wore desert camouflage gear and waited in a military chow line with the president for helpings of turkey. Stateside, soldiers destined to join those overseas enjoyed a parting taste of home cooking and family time. ``We're just really thankful I'm here for this one. We're cutting it real close here,'' said Marine Sgt. Gerald Pennington, a reserve from Connecticut whose unit is being activated Sunday for possible Persian Gulf duty. More than 200,000 American troops have been sent to the Middle East since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, and their numbers are set to double in coming months. Also growing are the numbers of needy as the nation's economy sours. ``We're seeing a big increase in the number of people who need food and shelter this year because of the recession and layoffs,'' said Maj. Carl Ruthberg of the Salvation Army in Cincinnati. ``In many cases, these are people who have never been laid off before and don't know how to deal with it.'' Ruthberg said his organization doubled the number of Thanksgiving dinners given out last year. Similar increases were reported nationwide. Civil rights activist Hosea Williams estimated 25,000 people got a hot meal at his 22nd annual Thanksgiving dinner in Atlanta. The Salvation Army cooked turkey dinners for 10,000 in New York City. In San Francisco, 6,000 people showed up for a holiday meal at Glide Memorial Methodist Church. ``Things are definitely different this year,'' said the Rev. Cecil Williams of the Glide church. ``There's been the recession, the crisis in the Persian Gulf, the uncomfortable inconsistencies of the charitable givers ... and the children, more than we've ever seen.'' Even one of the most festive Thanksgiving traditions - the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade in New York City - was tinged with sadness this year. A giant helium-filled balloon of Kermit the Frog returned to the parade in honor of Muppets creator Jim Henson, who died this year. ``Kermit makes me sad,'' said Paul Oppold, 27, who lost his smile when the green frog came into view. And at the end of the parade, about 20 AIDS activists unfurled banners that read, ``4,752 AIDS Deaths 'till Christmas'' and ``Ask Santa Claus for National Health Care.'' More than 1 million people lined the streets to watch the marching bands, floats and balloons in the 64th annual Macy's parade. Joining the helium-filled cartoon character balloons this year was Bart Simpson, barreling down Broadway on a 35-foot-long skateboard. St. Louis moved its Christmas parade up to Thanksgiving this year. It featured three 60-foot-high helium balloons, including one of Cecil the Seasick Sea Serpent. More than 150,000 people watched a Thanksgiving Day parade in Detroit, but only a pilot flying at 5,000 feet got to see the 30-foot-long helium balloon of Chilly Willy the penguin. The flightless bird took to the sky the nigh before when it broke free of its moorings. The $15,000 balloon was recovered later from a lake 35 miles away. Detroit also was home once again for one of the traditional Thanksgiving day football games watched on television by millions nationwide. The Detroit Lions beat the Denver Broncos 40-27. In Dallas, the other traditional Thanksgiving day combatant, the Cowboys, beat the Washington Redskins 27-17. While many Americans were too stuffed with food to make it off the living room couch, 30,000 people ran a marathon in Atlanta over a course mapped for the event in the 1996 Olympics. Four of the country's 10 oldest road races are run on Thanksgiving, according to Runner's World magazine. They are the 5-mile Turkey Trot in Buffalo, first run in 1896; the Thanksgiving Day 5-Mile Race in New Orleans (1907); the Elks Thanksgiving Day Race in Cincinnati (1908); and the Berwick 9-Mile Race in Berwick, Pa. (1908). ``Now I know I can justify eating a lot of turkey, drinking some beers and eating some cake because I've got my workout in,'' Sean McCrossen said after finishing the Buffalo race.

DOC.HEAD: Rain from South into Midwest and Northeast
DOC.TEXT: Rain was widespread across the Deep South today and was scattered across the Midwest and northeast. Rain and rising temperatures melted snow across much of the higher elevations in western Washington state, causing rivers to rise and bringing scattered flood warnings. Advisories for locally heavy rain were in effect. Warnings for gale-force winds were posted for the Washington and Oregon coasts. High wind alerts were issued in eastern Wyoming, the Columbia basin of Oregon and the Idaho panhandle. Gusts of 70 mph were recorded in eastern Wyoming on Thursday while 55 to 60 mph gusts were widespread in eastern Montana. Snow was expected in the northwest mountains of Montana. Blowing, drifting snow was forecast for the north-central mountains of Wyoming. Rain dampened broad sections of Louisiana, Arkansas, Alabama, Georgia and Tennessee. Rain today also reached into Kentucky, the lower Midwest and western Pennsylvania. New York and Maine had widely scattered showers. The high temperature for the nation Thursday was 88 degrees at McAllen, Texas. DOC.HEAD: China Replaces Top Hong Kong Official In Bid For More Control
DOC.TEXT:
In a move to increase central control over Hong Kong, China has replaced its top official responsible for the British colony, the government said today. Since the June 1989 crackdown a pro-democracy movement in Beijing that was popularly supported in Hong Kong, Communist China has sought to tighten control over the territory before it reverts to Chinese rule in 1997. Tens of thousands of the colony's residents concerned about Communist control have sought permission to move out. A spokesman for the Hong Kong and Macao Affairs Office said that Lu Ping, who has been deputy director since 1987, will take over the directorship. He replaces Ji Pengfei, who headed the office for the past eight years. Ji, a former foreign minister with close ties to China's top leaders, exercised a degree of independence in formulating policy for Hong Kong, the capitalist port bordering south China. The Hong Kong and Macao Affairs Office is under the State Council, China's Cabinet, and is the highest government organ dealing with the two territories. Lu, 63, has been involved in Hong Kong affairs since 1978 and was deputy secretary-general of the Basic Law Drafting Committee, which wrote the mini-constitution for Hong Kong after it reverts to Chinese rule. He is considered to have a greater understanding of Hong Kong issues and to be more open and approachable than his predecessor, who visited the colony only once during his tenure. However, Lu lacks Ji's status among Chinese leaders. Since the military attack on pro-democracy demonstrators in Beijing, he has been careful to follow the Communist Party line and has been less outspoken on issues concerning Hong Kong. The pro-Beijing Wen Wei Po of Hong Kong said Ji and Li would retain their posts as chairman and vice-chariman of the Macao Basic Law Drafting Committee. Macao, a Portugese colony, is to return to Chinese rule in 1999. As part of a 1984 agreement, China promised to maintain Hong Kong's freewheeling economic and social system under a program it calls ``one country, two systems.'' But after the June 1989 crackdown on pro-democracy groups in China, many in the territory lost faith in China's promise. Hong Kong people also question British assurances of its support up until 1997, when Britain's 99-year lease on the colony runs out. The British government is offering about 225,000 Hong Kong residents the right to live in Britain. According to Hong Kong immigration officials, about 3.5 million of Hong Kong's 5.7 million people are eligible for consideration under the package.
Already more than 1,000 people a week are emigrating, mainly to Australia and Canada, because they fear a loss of rights and opportunities when Hong Kong comes under Chinese rule.

DOC.HEAD: California City Bans Cold Beer Sales at Gas Stations
DOC.TEXT: Gas station owners say the city's latest move to curb drunken drivers is about as appealing as warm beer. Uncooled beer and wine are the only alcoholic beverages gas stations can sell now, thanks to a recent ruling by the city's planning commission aimed at making chilled spirits less convenient to drivers making pit stops. ``It's going to hurt business,'' said Mehrzad Hamzeh, owner of a Shell station located next to a grocery store that can sell cold beer. ``People don't want to take warm beer home and then wait for it to get cold in the freezer. This is a ridiculous law.'' City officials defended the rule, arguing that the rising incidence of drunken driving requires drastic countermeasures. ``The city is trying to send an appropriate message - alcohol and gasoline don't mix,'' Planning Commissioner Mike Gorman said. Walnut Creek is a San Francisco Bay area city about 10 miles east of Oakland.

DOC.HEAD: EC 1992 Drive Lags Behind in Several Key Sectors
DOC.TEXT: The European Community's drive to create a unified internal market by the end of 1992 is lagging behind schedule in key areas, according to an EC Commission report. A delay not only would affect EC businesses and citizens, but also American and other foreign investors who anticipate a borderless EC market after Dec. 31, 1992. ``We cannot allow failure,'' the commission said in a statement Thursday. Nowhere has progress been slower in streamlining member states' policies than in the area of Value Added Taxes and excise duties, the commission said in the report it released Thursday. It also blamed tardiness in many EC states to adapt national laws to EC legislation. In contrast, it said progress was being made in other areas such as liberalizing capital movement, the banking sector, stock exchanges and insurance. But it warned that delays in setting up the internal market would affect the European drive for economic and monetary union after 1992. The commission's attempts to replace often-contradictory national laws with unified rules often clash with national aspirations of the member states. The Commission proposes EC legislation that must be adopted or amended by the 12 EC states to take effect. The commission criticized the 12 EC governments for slow progress in harmonizing VAT taxes and duties. Despite commitments to set up a unified VAT system and excise duties, ``no precise measure has been taken,'' said the statement. The Commission said it ``regretted the lack of ambition of the 12 (governments).'' In the EC's view, the drive towards a single market is vital to EC businesses that have already invested heavily in an EC-wide strategy. In 1989 alone, there were 1,300 cross-border acquisitions valued at a total of 30 billion European Currency units ($41.7 billion.) A single market is also seen as important for attracting foreign investors to the Community. Direct investment in the trade bloc by U.S. companies surged to $126.5 billion in 1988 from $84 billion in 1985. During the same period, Japanese investments rose to $8.3 billion from $2 billion, the commission said. The commission urged a speeding up of the drive for a single market, saying that ``confronted with a panoply of police and custom checks (at the EC's internal borders) the European citizen has the right to question, barely two years before the end date, the political promises.'' To make progress in that area, the commission wants to strengthen controls at the trade bloc's external borders and coordinate the fight against international terrorism, drug trafficking and clandestine immigration.

DOC.HEAD: China, Soviets Meet On Gulf Crisis, Remain Firm Against Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with Shevardnadze leaving, details. Pick up 6th graf pvs, `The United...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Chinese and Soviet foreign ministers today reiterated their countries' demand that Iraq end its occupation of Kuwait, after meeting in a remote border town. But Qian Qichen of China and Eduard Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union did not say whether they had reached agreement on the next step to defuse the crisis. ``Both sides are firmly opposed to Iraq's invasion and annexation of Kuwait and demand that Iraq withdraw from Kuwait as soon as possible,'' China's official Xinhua News Agency quoted Qian as saying. It said Qian reported the two men ``shared many points in common,'' but did not elaborate. Soviet Embassy spokesman Yuri Lyssenko said he had no information on the talks in the Chinese city of Urumqi, near the two countries' Central Asian border. Xinhua said Qian and Shevardnadze first met for 90 minutes, each accompanied only by an aide and a translator. Talks then were expanded to include officials of each side's foreign ministry. Shevardnadze left for Moscow later today, the Soviet Embassy said. He arrived in Urumqi this morning for the meeting, which was announced only a day before. The United States has been lobbying for a U.N. Security Council resolution authorizing the use of force to drive Iraq from Kuwait. But both Moscow and Beijing have stressed the need to seek a peaceful solution. As permanent members of the Security Council, both countries have veto power over any resolutions. The United States, France and Britain are the other permanent members. On Thursday, Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Li Zhaoxing said the question of using force ``should not be hurried through.'' ``As long as there is still a gleam of hope for a peaceful settlement, unremitting efforts should be continued for this,'' he said. Foreign journalists were not allowed to cover today's meeting in Urumqi, 1,500 miles west of Beijing. The venue may have been chosen in part for its privacy. It was the second time Shevardnadze has flown into China for consulations since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait Aug. 2. The first meeting was in Harbin on Sept. 1, and it signaled a new, pragmatic working relationship between the two neighbors. China and the Soviet Union, both ruled by Communist parties, were close allies in the 1950s but split in the 1960s over ideological and strategic differences. They normalized relations only last year with a summit in Beijing, and political, economic and military contacts have greatly increased since then.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
News conference underway
DOC.TEXT: President Bush met with Egypt's Hosni Mubarak today and said the international coalition demanding Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait ``will not rest'' until the task is achieved. ``There is complete identity of views'' between the United States and Egypt, Bush said, and Mubarak's words echoed his own. ``The Iraqi invasion must be reversed and Kuwait must be liberated,'' the Egyptian leader said. Bush, who met with U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf on Thanksgiving Day, was leaving the Middle East after the news conference. He was traveling to Geneva for a quick meeting with Syrian President Hafez Assad to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis before heading home for Washington. Bush has been seeking support for a United Nations resolution authorizing the use of force to evict Iraq from Kuwait. ``I can assure you that the world still has violent disapproval of what Saddam Hussein has done and that they will be supportive of any action this coalition takes,'' he said.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Report Raises Questions About Death Row Inmate's Guilt
DOC.TEXT: A 13-year-old police report raises questions about whether a death row inmate committed the murder for which he was condemned, a newspaper reported today. Two experts hired by The Dallas Morning News - a former police officer and a former FBI agent - said Tyler police apparently drew the wrong conclusions from evidence found at the murder scene and later presented an improbable version of events at Kerry Max Cook's 1978 capital murder trial. Cook, who maintains his innocence, was sentenced to die for the 1977 slaying of Linda Jo Edwards, 21, of Tyler. The News reported today that the June 14, 1977, police report, which the newspaper obtained from a confidential source, cites evidence that may have pointed to other possible suspects. Among the evidence was four hair samples. One of Cook's attorneys said prosecutors never told the defense about that evidence. ``The physical evidence, particularly foreign hairs on her body, reports of those should have been submitted to us,'' said John Ament, one of two attorneys who represented Cook. Tyler lawyer A.D. Clark III, who was Smith County's district attorney at the time of the trial, said his office turned over everything it was required to. He also supported the police theory of how the crime took place. Police say Cook snuck into Ms. Edwards' apartment through an unlocked patio door, saw her sleeping on the couch, picked up a statue and began beating her with it. The News' experts were skeptical. ``I would definitely say the wrong conclusion was reached,'' said Phil Ethridge, a former Tulsa policeman who teaches at the University of Texas-Pan American. Ethridge and Jerry Dowling, a former FBI special agent now with Sam Houston State University's criminal justice program, say the police report does not support the police theory that Ms. Edwards was sleeping when she was attacked. The report said police found the television on with the ``volume in a normal listening area'' when they entered Ms. Edwards' bedroom. Officers also found a hot iron upright on an ironing board in the bedroom, the report said. Ms. Edwards pants, the only item of her clothing not torn or bloodstained, lay nearby. The report also noted that there was blood on the top of the ironing board. The professors questioned whether the woman would be sleeping with both the television and the iron on. The blood on top of the ironing board indicates she may have been standing when the attack began, they said. ``None of the physical evidence inside the crime scene really links (Cook) to the crime,'' Dowling said. ``There's a lot of blood, but you don't get his fingerprints on the weapons, you don't have blood on his clothing or whatever. ``I don't know whether the guy did it or not, but I'm not overly impressed with what evidence they say suggests that he did it.'' The Texas Court of Criminal Appeals is considering whether to throw out Cook's conviction and sentence because of constitutional questions surrounding the testimony in the punishment phase of his trial.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
CAIRO, Egypt: he said.
DOC.TEXT: Speaking at a joint news conference, Bush said, ``We're getting tired of the status quo, and so is the rest of the world. Mubarak has been a front-line partner in the United States' effort to force Iraq's withdrawal, sending several thousand troops to Saudi Arabia as part of the effort to deter further aggression. ``For us it's a matter of principles and moral values,'' he said. Mubarak also used the news conference to call for greater international effort to deal with the ``plight of the Palestinian people.'' He added. ``The holy shrines of Jerusalem muyst be respected and protected.'' Bush, asked about the subject, said the United States is eager for an overall Middle Eastern peace agreement. But, he swiftly said, ``What I am equally determined to do is to keep these two questions separate. There is no linkage.''
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Strong Earthquake Hits Western Japan
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake shook an area along Japan's western coast this evening, but there were no immediate reports of damage or casualties, the Central Meteorological Agency said. The temblor, which struck at about 7:42 p.m. (5:42 a.m. EST), had a preliminary reading of 5.0 on the Richter scale, the agency said. The epicenter was about 400 miles southwest of Tokyo in the western Tottori prefecture, a moderately populated coastal area. Police in Tottori, contacted about a half hour after the quake, reported no injuries or damage. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded by seismographs. Every increase of one means a tenfold increase in magnitude. An earthquake of five on the Richter sale is considered ``very strong.'' A quake of magnitude 5 can cause considerable damage in populated areas.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Rises Against Most Currencies, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against most major foreign currencies today day in early European trading. Gold prices were lower. In Tokyo, markets were closed for Labor Thanksgiving Day, a national holiday. In London, the dollar was quoted at 127.15 yen, up from Thursday's Tokyo close of 127.35. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Thursday: -1.4842 German marks, up from 1.4786 -1.2530 Swiss francs, up from 1.2490 -5.0040 French francs, up from 4.9890 -1.6740 Dutch guilders, up from 1.6670 -1,115.00 Italian lire, up from 1,109.50 -$1.1590 Canadian, down from $1.1602 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.685, compared with $1.9700 late Thursday. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $380.00 per ounce at midmorning, unchanged from late Thursday. In Zurich, the bid price was $380.25, down from $380.50 late Thursday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $1.16 to close at a bid $379.25. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.12 a troy ounce, from Thursday's $4.13.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Traffickers Offer To Surrender, With Conditions
DOC.TEXT: The Medellin cocaine cartel says hundreds of its members are willing to accept a government offer not to extradite them if they turn themselves in. But the members still refused to confess to crimes. A cartel statement Thursday to President Cesar Gaviria also said the members wanted special protection and would be willing to stay in a special compound guarded by the army. The traffickers' statement did not indicate if the offer to surrender applied to Pablo Escobar, the Medellin cartel's leader. Such a surrender by between 200 and 300 cartel members ``implies the end of all activities related to drug trafficking or narcoterrorism,'' the statement said. The government, seeking to end a 15-month-old war with drug traffickers that has left more than 500 people dead, responded to the communique by extending an olive branch. Justice Minister Jaime Giraldo outlined a series of legal guarantees drug traffickers would enjoy if they surrendered. In September, Gaviria offered to prohibit extraditions and reduce jail sentences of drug traffickers who surrendered and confessed their crimes. In Thursday's statement, the traffickers were apparently accepting Gaviria's offer, with conditions. These included trafficker's request that they not be required to confess, as the Gaviria offer demands. They said such confessions would constitute self-incrimination, ``prohibited even in the United States.'' ``A confession of all crimes committed is not required, just some of them,'' said Justice Minister Giraldo. He said surrendering drug traffickers ``can be sure they will not be extradited.'' The traffickers said they would expect, upon turning themselves in, special army protection and vigilance by international human rights organizations. The Medellin cartel has been blamed for the deaths of around 550 Colombians since the government and drug traffickers declared war on each other after a political assassination in August 1989. During the past three months, traffickers have kidnapped nine journalists, some of whom belong to the country's most influential families. Drug bosses have said the abductions are a response to human rights abuses by police in Medellin, the cartel's home city. They are also apparently trying to pressure authorities to grant them a pardon. In Thursday's statement, the drug lords said they should not be treated like common criminals.

DOC.HEAD: Report: JFK Jr. Has His Day in Court
DOC.TEXT: John F. Kennedy Jr., who recently passed the state bar exam on his third try, has argued his first case in court, a published report said today. Kennedy, an assistant Manhattan district attorney, argued for 10 minutes Wednesday before three judges in the state appellate court that a purse-snatcher's conviction should not be overturned, the New York Post reported. The judges will hand down a verdict in January, the newspaper reported. The 29-year-old son of the late President Kennedy went to work for the district attorney in August 1989. The New York University Law School graduate failed the grueling New York bar exam twice and was in danger of losing his prosecutor's job if he flunked a third time. But he took the test again in July and learned earlier this month that he passed.

DOC.HEAD: Government Ends ``Gladio''-Style Force
DOC.TEXT: A secret Swiss resistance force that would have mounted guerrilla warfare against foreign occupiers has been ordered dissolved, the government said today. The government was responding to a report by a parliamentary commission that said the clandestine resistance group was set up by military officials outside political control. The force also was supposed to be used against domestic subversion. But the danger of invasion is receding with the democratization of eastern Europe and the government ``is ready to abolish the vestiges of the Cold War,'' the seven-member federal executive said. It said it formally abolished the force, codenamed P-26, last week. Switzerland's announcement followed recent revelations of a clandestine network of guerrilla units and arms caches, organized in NATO countries in the 1950s, that would have coordinated resistance in case of a Warsaw Pact invasion of western Europe. Today's parliamentary report said it found no evidence that the Swiss group had ``direct links'' with NATO's paramilitary network. But it said the unit cooperated with an unidentified NATO country in developing telecommunications equipment. About 400 people participated in P-26, most of them weapons, telecommunications and psychological warfare experts, the report said. The group, secretly financed by the defense department, maintained a network of mostly underground installations throughout Switzerland. Its commander was a private citizen who could mobilize the force without consulting army or government. The parliamentary commission said a parallel undercover military intelligence network was set up in 1980. But it dismissed its reports as no more valuable than what could be gained by a careful reading of daily newspapers. The parliament investigation centered on Switzerland's Defense Ministry. The probe was launched after revelations that the ministry, along with other government offices, kept secret files on citizens.

DOC.HEAD: Students Protest U.S. Demands for Korea to Open Trade Markets
DOC.TEXT: Radical students fought riot police with firebombs and rocks today and demanded an end to U.S. pressure to open Korean trade and agriculture markets. The nation's top opposition leader, Kim Dae-jung, warned of more political unrest over the issue. But Deputy Premier Lee Seung-yun took a conciliatory tone and said South Korea would try to ease tensions with the United States. The nation's major dissident and radical student organizations said they would hold more demonstrations on Sunday. Police said illegal protests would be blocked and security would be tightened around U.S. facilities. About 4,000 students at 16 universities in Seoul staged rallies today and battled riot police, news reports said. At Sogang University, about 500 students hurled hundreds of rocks and firebombs, and police fired volleys of choking tear gas from armored vans. Another 400 students clashed with police in southern Kwangju city, the reports said. There were no reports of arrests or injuries. Opposition leader Kim told Parliament that the nation would face major unrest unless Roh halts ``suppressive rule'' using security organizations to crack down on dissidents, workers and students. Kim also said the country should ``sternly cope with America's unrealistic pressure to open its markets, especially farm products.'' It was Kim's first speech to the National Assembly since his group, the Party for Peace and Democracy, ended a four-month boycott and returned to Parliament Monday. All 78 opposition legislators walked out of the 299-member Parliament in July, charging the governing party with railroading bills and reneging on democratic reforms. Dissidents and farmers have staged violent anti-government and anti-American protests, denouncing U.S. pressure on South Korea to open its agricultural markets wider. South Korean consumer and civil groups have threatened to launch a nationwide boycott against U.S. goods. In an address Wednesday, U.S. Ambassador Donald Gregg said negative views of America have become widespread in South Korea and threaten to poison economic and political relations between the countries. Deputy Premier Lee, also the economic planning minister, said the government will try to end trade controversies with foreign governments, especially Washington.

DOC.HEAD: `Modern Mythology' Museum Considering Move From San Francisco
DOC.TEXT: Minnesota may become the home of Mr. Clean, Charlie Tuna, the Michelin Man and other icons and critters of Madison Avenue. An executive at the Museum of Modern Mythology, which features advertising characters and mass market trademarks, talked to city officials Tuesday about moving the museum from San Francisco to St. Paul. ``We think it would be a good place for the museum - the Twin Cities is a creative arts mecca,'' said Ellen Havre Weis, the executive director and co-founder of the popular culture museum. The museum is based on the premise that advertising characters and slogans have so infiltrated the subconscious minds of modern-day Americans that they are the closest things we have to myth. Advertising also offers interesting examples of the development of art and social attitudes over the past century, according to museum officials. The mythology museum was forced to close when the earthquake in the San Francisco Bay area in October 1989 ruined its building. Since then, museum officials have been looking for a new home. Although other cities have expressed interest, St. Paul and Berkeley, Calif., are the two sites under active consideration, Weis said. The Twin Cities would be a good home for the museum, Weis said, because it is a nationally known advertising community and has a reputation for corporate philanthropy. Weis said it is hoped that the decision on a new location can be made within six months. The museum was started in 1982 by Weis, graphic artist Jeffrey Errick and media consultant Matthew Cohen.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqis Host American Hostages At Thanksgiving Dinner
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to fix typos, add dropped word; Pickup 8th, `Stevenson, 54...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: In a bizarre Thanksgiving celebration at an exclusive country club, a dozen American hostages and a few relatives who came to see them sat down to eat with their Iraqi captors. The hostages, who were being held as ``human shields'' at various strategic sites, were brought Thursday to Baghdad's Hunting Club in the fashionable Mansour district of the capital. Iraqi government officials joined the Americans for lunch - turkey, chicken, ham and cranberry sauce - which was arranged by the American Red Cross Society. The Iraqis provided the wine for the meal. The hostages were brought from unidentified strategic locations as far away as 280 miles west and north, officials said. No guards were seen at the club. Bill Stevenson said he, his brother, James, and sister, Mary Trundy, came to Baghdad to speak of peace, to see their brother John and to take him home with them. The first two they have done; the third and most important will have to wait. Iraqi officials did release some hostages on Thanksgiving. But none of them was American. Stevenson, 54, was among several Americans who have flown to Baghdad since Saddam Hussein invited relatives of captives to visit them. He said he got no encouragement for his private mission from his neighbors, co-workers or the government. He said he had to quit his job in Panama City, Fla., to travel to Iraq. His brother, John, 44, a computer specialist who had worked in Kuwait for more than 10 years, was picked up in October in Kuwait and eventually taken to a military site in Iraq. ``We are a very close, tight-knit family,'' said Bill. ``I am here for my brother.'' Despite the circumstances, the atmosphere at the Hunting Club was convivial. Some hostages had known each other in Kuwait before they were seized during the Iraqi invasion Aug. 2. They embraced each other as they met for the first time since then. They mingled on the well-manicured lawn outside the club, sipping soft drinks before moving into the dining room for lunch. Some passed on the wine, and ordered beer. The Iraqis gave them presents of bottles of liquor. More than 100 Americans are among 600 Westerners, including Britons and Japanese, held at key military and industrial sites to prevent any attack by U.S.-led forces arrayed against Iraq in the Persian Gulf following its invasion. Among those brought to the club was Donald Whitely, 49, of Shreveport, La., who is believed to be the first American seized by the Iraqis less than 30 minutes after they invaded Kuwait. Whitely said he was sleeping in the Kuwait Oil Co. camp in an oilfield near the border when the Iraqis stormed in. He was held with three other American drillers. ``I've a legitimate reason to go home,'' he said. ``My father's very ill and I want to see him before he dies.'' He said he suffered from an ear ailment and needed urgent surgery. Whitely disclosed that he has been held at a telecommunications center near Baghdad, but received ``adequate food'' and was able to receive telephone calls from his family in the United States. Billy Rodebush, 53, of McAlester, Okla., who was also seized in Kuwait Aug. 2, said: ``On Thanksgiving Day we should be reunited with our families. This is what the day is for. Nobody should be detained against his will.'' Nigel Nightingale, another hostage, was reunited with his wife, Jean. She said she has appealed to Iraqi officials to let her husband go, but so far has received no response. The Iraqis have allowed them to stay together in a Baghdad hotel for a few days before he is taken back to the strategic site where he has been held. Mrs. Nightingale said she has been treated well since she arrived in Baghdad a few days ago.

DOC.HEAD: Slovaks Begin Voting in Tight Contest for Local Councils
DOC.TEXT: Nationalists in Slovakia, Hungary's ethnically troubled rural republic, tested their political strength today in local council and mayoral elections. The two days of balloting in Slovakia and one day of voting in the Czech republic on Saturday will complete the nation's transition to democracy by replacing councils dominated by Communists for four decades. Ninety-sevn parties fielded more than 232,000 candidates for about 100,000 seats on local and regional councils in both republics. About 2,700 towns in Slovakia also will choose mayors. Polling ends in both republics Saturday night, and the first results are expected late Sunday. Civic Forum, the loose democratic coalition founded by President Vaclav Havel, is the clear favorite in elections in the Czech republic. But Public Against Violence, its counterpart in Slovakia, is facing a stiff challenge from Christian Democrats and the nationalist Slovak National Party. The last pre-election poll indicated Public Against Violence would win about 29 percent of the vote, followed by the Christian Democrats with 27 percent and the nationalist party with 17 percent. Elections are expected to be close in southern Slovakia, where most of the nation's ethnic Hungarians live. Last month, the Slovak parliament passed a law allowing the 600,000 ethnic Hungarians in the republic to use their language in official communications in areas where they represent more than 20 percent of the population. Angry nationalists responded with a wave of street protests. Hungarians make up more than 10 percent of Slovakia's 5.5 million people. Many Czechoslovaks who voted this summer to oust Communists and replace them with democratic forces have become disillusioned with what has been accomplished since. ``This time the idea is to choose the best people on the basis of their ability to do something for the community,'' Slovak radio said in a commentary today hours before polls opened. ``But in the big cities, where people do not know each other, their party allegiance will be all that matters.'' There have been concerns that voter turnout would be low, but recent polls indicated up to 70 percent of the voters would participate. A record 97 percent voted in the June parliamentary elections. ``Maybe we are all tired, but right now we cannot afford to sleep late, because we still have to wake democracy up,'' Slovensky Dennik, the Christian Democratic daily, said today.

DOC.HEAD: Criminal's True Identity Discovered Nearly 5 Years After Sentencing
DOC.TEXT: A man who was imprisoned for nearly five years under a false name even though authorities suspected he was lying about his identity was finally tripped up by an offhand reference to Hawaii, authorities said. Authorities didn't know much about the man who was sentenced as Joseph P. Caldwell in early 1986 in Pierce County Superior Court. Because his history was a blank, he received a lighter sentence than he might have if is criminal past had been known. The man went to extraordinary lengths to hide his identity for four years - including using an iron to burn off four tattoos, authorities said. But an investigator found out earlier this year that Caldwell is really Randall J. Peters, a man who had prior convictions for robbery and burglary in Hawaii and Texas and faced rape charges in Skagit County. Monday, Peters will be resentenced in Superior Court for the 1985 shooting and robbery, based on his true criminal history. At the time of his 1985 trial, authorities were suspicious Peters wasn't who he claimed to be. He appeared younger than 40 - the age he told them - and he'd given police a bogus address. But the man's fingerprints weren't in state records, and he had no peculiar marks that could aid in identification, said Bruce Jackson, chief criminal investigator for the Pierce County prosecutor. After Peters' conviction, Judge E. Albert Morrison handed down an exceptional sentence of 20 years for the armed robbery and shooting. But the state Court of Appeals overturned the sentence, saying neither the nature of the assault nor the man's apparent unwillingness to give his true name justified the exceptional punishment, said deputy prosecutor Doug Hill, who originally tried the case. Peters received a new sentence of 4{ years for first-degree robbery and 8{ years for first-degree assault. He was sent to the state prison at Walla Walla. Prison officials also were suspicious of the man's identity, said Tim Anderson, an investigator for the Pierce County prosecutor. The inmate never got mail or visitors, and he never talked about his past. When Peters refused to allow X-rays during a routine dental visit, prison authorities began collecting every file and bit of prison intelligence they had on him and sending it to the Pierce County prosecutor's office. Anderson sifted through the box of information and came upon an offhand reference Peters made to Hawaii. On a hunch, Anderson sent a copy of Peters' fingerprints to the Honolulu Police Department. ``I thought it was a long shot. But Honolulu came back with a match,'' Anderson said. ``They said they knew him, but under another name. ... I couldn't believe it when I got the fax from them. I called the (Honolulu) detective back and said, `Is this really the same guy?''' It turned out Peters had two convictions for robbery in Hawaii and two theft convictions in Texas. He also was wanted in Skagit County, Anderson said. Peters was then turned over to Skagit County, which convicted him on two counts of first-degree rape and one count of third-degree indecent liberties for attacks that happened before the Tacoma crimes, Hill said. He was sentenced to 33 years. Hill says he'll recommend on Monday that Morrison sentence Peters to 20 years, the maximum allowed under the law for the Tacoma shooting and robbery.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Developments At-a-Glance
With PM-Gulf-Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are the latest developments in the Persian Gulf crisis: --

President Bush met today in Cairo, Egypt with President Hosni Mubarak, who has led Arab opposition to Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Bush said he was closing in on an agreement for a U.N. resolution authorizing the use of force in the Persian Gulf crisis. Mubarak was non-committal on the issue. Bush later flew to Geneva to meet with President Hafez Assad of Syria. ---

Congressional leaders said today President Bush would have a far better chance of getting Congress to approve the use of force in the Persian Gulf if the United Nations first backed such a move. House leaders said they had no commitment from Bush to seek congressional approval before ordering a military action in the Persian Gulf, should the president choose that option. ---
The United States today made an ``urgent'' appeal today to its NATO allies to help ship and fly additional U.S. troops and equipment to the gulf region. ---

The Chinese and Soviet foreign ministers held talks today on the gulf crisis. Later, the two reiterated their opposition to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and their demand that it withdraw. Neither Qian Qichen of China nor Eduard Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union disclosed whether they had reached agreement on the next step to defuse the crisis. ---

Saddam paid a morale-boosting mission to Iraqi troops in Kuwait, telling them he is ready to fight ``the evil blasphemers'' if attacked. The Iraqi president used his visit to Kuwait, his second since the invasion, as the scene for new threats to the U.S.-led alliance. ---

Iraqi authorities have lifted a curfew in Kuwait, the Iraqi News Agency reported today. The report indicated the Baghdad government wants to convey that conditions in Kuwait City and its environs have quieted down. --- The Kuwaiti community in Egypt appealed for action to force Iraq's armies to leave their homeland. The Kuwaiti League for Popular Action, which represents about 25,000 Kuwaitis in Egypt, took out an ad in a major newspaper today to plead their cause.

DOC.HEAD: Supermarket Pulls Turkeys After Cyanide-Injection Threat
With PM-Thanksgiving Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of people returned turkeys to Tucson-area Smith's supermarkets in the wake of the scare created when a man called a television station saying he had injected some birds with deadly cyanide. The supermarket chain had removed all turkeys from its Tucson stores and offered refunds or exchanges to customers who recently had purchased turkeys after Wednesday night's call. Ninety to 95 percent of the customers asked for a refund on Thursday, store officials said. Some of the returned turkeys were already cooked. Barry Holinski, meat supervisor for the chain in Tucson, said he didn't know how many birds were pulled from the shelves, how many were returned, or how much the incident will cost Smith's. But at one store alone, more than 2,000 turkeys were returned. The withdrawal was limited to the four Tucson-area stores, a Smith's official said Thursday. ``It's sad that it happened on the Thanksgiving holiday,'' spokesman Ken Findley said in Phoenix. Tucson police said Thursday that no evidence had been found that any turkeys sold by Smith's Food and Drug stores actually had been injected with the poison. Reporter-anchor Barbara Grijalva of KOLD-TV took a call Wednesday from a man who said he ``had a problem with Smith's,'' KOLD producer Rob Daniels said. The man said he had injected some of the turkeys on sale at Smith's with cyanide but did not say which Smith's stores were involved or when he allegedly poisoned the turkeys. He said he injected the turkeys ``to prove a point,'' and declined to elaborate. Sgt. Roberto Villasenor, spokesman for the Tucson Police Department, said police had no suspects. All turkeys returned to Smith's will be taken to a landfill for disposal, said James Robertson of the Pima County Health Department.

DOC.HEAD: Outpouring of Praise for Departing Thatcher
With PM-Britain-Politics, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with reaction from Ryzhkov, Havel, China. No Pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Leaders around the world hailed Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's achievements, with President Bush calling her an outstanding ally and the Soviets praising her for helping end the Cold War. But Iraq said it is not displeased she is going. Mrs. Thatcher, who on Thursday announced her plans to step down, got a call from Bush, who was visiting U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia. He told her ``we love you'' and said he was ``very upset'' she was quitting, said a spokesman at her 10 Downing Street office. The spokesman said Bush told Mrs. Thatcher in the 10-minute call that she had served not only Britain but the cause for which they both stood with distinction and strength. The spokesman said Mrs. Thatcher told Bush about her government's decision the same day to send 14,000 more armed services personnel to the Persian Gulf to bolster the international force confronting Iraq. The move will boost the number of British ground troops, sailors and air crews to 30,000. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's government, in a recent blast, called Mrs. Thatcher a ``hag.'' But Iraqi information minister Latif Nassayif Jassim said Thursday that while Iraq was not displeased she was going, it was not hostile to her personally. In Moscow, Soviet Prime Minster Nikolai Ryzhkov told reporters: ``I'm very sorry that she has resigned, because she was a very strong, very prominent politician.'' The British Broadcasting Corp. today quoted an unnamed Soviet spokesman as saying Mrs. Thatcher was a historic figure who had helped bring the Soviet Union closer to Europe. Mrs. Thatcher, on first meeting Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev in 1984 declared: ``I like Mr. Gorbachev. We can do business together.'' In her 11{ years as prime minister, Mrs. Thatcher traveled widely and established herself as a leading world stateswoman, as much at home on U.S. television as among crowds of enthusiastic well-wishers on Soviet streets. Dubbed the ``Iron Lady'' by the Soviets before the ending of the Cold War, she was a close ally of former President Reagan. Reagan, who was president from 1981 to 1988, said in a message following her resignation announcement: ``Margaret Thatcher is truly a world statesman,'' he said. Vitaly Ignatenko, spokesman for Gorbachev, told the Interfax news agency: ``Political, economic and cultural ties between our countries have become of greater importance'' under the Thatcher era. ``Our relations during this period were marked by constructivism and dialogue.'' Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel telephoned Mrs. Thatcher's office today and told her: ``You're always welcome in Czechoslovakia.'' NATO secretary-general Manfred Woerner said: ``The success of our alliance in the last decade would not have been possible without her vision, courage and steadfastness.'' Mrs. Thatcher resolutely backed the deployment in Britain and other NATO countries of new U.S. missiles in the 1980s in response to a build-up of Soviet weapons. The move was seen in NATO as crucial in bringing the Soviets to the negotiating table. Jacques Delors, president of the executive commission of the European Common Market, spoke of his high esteem for Mrs. Thatcher despite their differences. She and Delors repeatedly clashed over her hostility to plans for monetary and political integration in the 12-nation Community. Valery Giscard d'Estaing, president of France from 1974 to 1981 with whom she also clashed, said: ``She deserves our applause. It must be said ... that the Iron Lady was a great lady.'' Sir Rex Hunt, governor of the Falkland Islands at the time of the 1982 war with Argentina, said: ``Her departure is a tragedy for Britain, for the Falklands and for the world.'' Mrs. Thatcher, who sent a task force to restore the Falklands to British rule, has consistently refused to discuss Argentina's sovereignty claim to the South Atlantic colony. The Chinese Foreign Ministry, in a statement released by the official Xinhua News Agency, praised Mrs. Thatcher for having made: ``positive contributions to the development of Sino-British relations and especially the settlement of the Hong Kong issue during her tenure.''

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Resolution Would Improve Chances Of Congress Support For Force Against Iraq, Congressional Leaders Say
With PM-Gulf-Bush Bjt
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto WX6, congressional leaders at news conference
Eds: RETRANSMITTING to add headline, LaserPhoto note
DOC.TEXT: President Bush would have a far better chance of getting Congress to approve the use of force in the Persian Gulf if the United Nations first backed such a move, congressional leaders said today. ``It would have some significant impact if the United Nations granted such a resolution,'' House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., said after arriving home from a Thanksgiving visit to U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia. Foley and other leaders said they had no commitment from Bush to seek congressional approval before ordering a military action in the Persian Gulf, should the president choose that option. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell said a U.N. resolution authorizing force against Iraq would improve Bush's chances but not necessarily guarantee congressional approval if the president sought it. ``It would depend upon the circumstances that exist at the time,'' the Maine Democrat said. Senate Republican leader Robert Dole said he would urge Congress to reconvene immediately if the United Nations endorsed force to free Kuwait from Iraqi occupation. ``Then I would hope Congress would reconvene and take similar action,'' the Kansas Republican said. In addition to joining Bush for Thanksgiving dinner with U.S. forces at several posts around Saudi Arabia, the congressional leaders met Thursday night with Saudi King Fahd. They described the king as grateful for the U.S. deployment and said he indicated no impatience with the stationing of hundreds or thousands of foreign troops on Saudi soil. Dole said Fahd told him he planned to visit soon with some of the American troops. The leaders said they came away from their trip impressed with the readiness of U.S. troops and their morale after more than three months in the Saudi desert and other gulf areas. ``It was a morale booster for us,'' Dole said. ``We found their readiness to be excellent and their morale to be high,'' Foley said. The speaker said he did not believe Bush planned any imminent policy switch. Dole agreed with that assessment but said he believed conditions at the U.S. embassy in Kuwait, where diplomats are running low on food, could be a ``flashpoint'' in the crisis in the coming weeks. Democratic leaders Foley and Mitchell gave Bush high marks for his handling of the crisis to date, although Mitchell said he had ``grave reservations'' about Bush's meeting with Syrian President Hafez al Assad. Mitchell said Assad's Syria has `condoned terrorism and engaged in terrorism and he certainly has an absymal human rights record.'' Neither Dole nor House Minority leader Robert Michel of Illinois expressed outright support for the meeting. But Michel said it made sense because of Syria's role in the multinational force in Saudi Arabia and because it borders Iraq and would play a huge role if any hostilities erupted. Dole said Bush needed to be ``very careful in our dealings with him'' but added that the meeting in the Saudi desert made some sense because ``we happen to be on the same side'' in the gulf crisis.

DOC.HEAD: Boy Finds Gun, Critically Wounds Self
DOC.TEXT: A 3-year-old boy found a loaded gun in his grandfather's motor home and shot himself, and he was in critical condition today, authorities said. David Riggs shot himself on the right side below his rib cage on Thanksgiving, said Jacksonville sheriff's Lt. D.G. Gueterman. No decision had been made whether the gun's owner would be charged under a state law that makes it a felony to leave a loaded handgun within the reach of a minor who uses it to kill or cause serious injury, said Detective Fred Bachert. David's grandfather, Ken Riggs, said the family had finished Thanksgiving dinner and he and a friend, John Dickey, went to pack up their motor home. Dickey said he had left his .380-caliber semiautomatic pistol in a zippered case hidden in the motor home. Riggs and Dickey were inside the garage when they heard a shot. ``We ran and I caught David running out the door,'' Riggs said. ``He was crying and he was shot.'' The gun had been stored in a case under a day bed, and Dickey had put bags of clothing over it, Bachert said. ``Did he make a reasonable effort to hide the gun? That's going to be the question,'' Bachert said. David was in critical but stable condition at University Medical Center, a hospital spokeswoman said.

DOC.HEAD: Christmas Season Under Way for Uneasy Retailers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with quotes from morning shoppers. Picks up 7th graf, `Stores generally...'. A version moved on financial lines.
DOC.TEXT: Shoppers lined up early, some of them in the rain, for today's unofficial start of the Christmas shopping season, which retailers are viewing uneasily amid the troubled economy and the Gulf crisis. ``There are three things you can count on: death, taxes and a big day after Thanksgiving,'' said Steve Podalsky, manager of the Marshall's department store at Sawgrass Mills, a discount shopping mall in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Podalsky said the newness of the mall, which opened in October, and the appeal of discount shopping have gotten the store off to a start ``beyond our expectations. It's as if there's nothing wrong with the economy.'' But most retailers don't expect business to boom, not with the flagging economy and the Middle East crisis. Many shoppers are expected to browse, not buy, this weekend. Phil Sawyer, manager of a J.C. Penney branch in Richmond, Va., predicted sales would slack off after a burst of buying today, similar to the business his store had during a previous economic slowdown. Wanda McNamara of New Cumberland, Pa., said today she has not been personally threatened with layoffs or loss of income. Still, she is taking the recession talk seriously and this shopping season will be different for her. ``I'm watching my dollars,'' she said this morning while waiting for Boscov's Department Store to open in Harrisburg, Pa. ``I'm more careful, more selective. I'm looking for sales. I'm cutting down on the Christmas list. I don't want to overcharge too much.'' Stores generally make half their annual profits during the Christmas season. The Thanksgiving weekend isn't quite as crucial for retailers as it once was, though. Shoppers setting out after getting their fill of turkey and football games used to give retailers their biggest three-day take and set the tone for the rest of the Christmas period. But in recent years, as more women joined the workforce, consumers have been shopping later and later. Now, the last 10 days before Christmas matter most - though Thanksgiving weekend sales help determine retailers' strategy for the rest of the season. Retailers' biggest hope this season is to avoid the steep markdowns that decimated earnings last Christmas. Many companies competing with the department stores owned by Campeau Corp. had to slash prices after Campeau's units, in a futile attempt at staying out of bankruptcy court, took heavy markdowns to bring in sales. Christmas 1989 devastated some retailers, most notably R.H. Macy & Co, which was among those forced to take markdowns and ended up with a $39 million loss in the second quarter of its fiscal year. Analysts believe there will be some markdowns this year, but just how severe the price cuts will be depends on how the season progresses. Edward Johnson, an analyst with Prescott Ball & Turben, said stores began taking markdowns a few weeks ago, but ``they're still not as bad as they were last year.'' If this weekend goes poorly, Johnson said, retailers may begin their markdowns early in hopes of increasing sales. Manufacturers also are concerned about the success of this weekend. They're waiting to see how well their products sell and whether stores that have stocked their shelves conservatively place reorders.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Resignation Leaves Three Battling To Succeed Her
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with quotes from challengers, campaign launch, Thatcher messages; EDITS to tighten. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY4,5,7
DOC.TEXT: Two Cabinet ministers launched campaigns today to succeed Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and they emphasized unity in low-key appeals to a Conservative Party in shock after dumping its leader. ``Against everybody's wishes in the party we've got ourselves into a mess,'' said Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd. ``We can only get ourselves out of the mess by rallying everybody, by healing the wounds.'' Hurd, 60, and Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major, 47, joined the race on Thursday, both hoping to block ex-Defense Secretary Michael Heseltine. Heseltine's strong solo challenge to Mrs. Thatcher in a first-round vote this week precipitated her dramatic resignation Thursday. That opened the way for Cabinet ministers to run in the next ballot among the 372 Conservative legislators in the House of Commons. While the contenders battled for her job, Mrs. Thatcher remained at her 10 Downing Street office. Messages of support and good will poured in from the world's leaders, her aides said. ``She's very well; she's feeling fine,'' said Conservative Party chairman Kenneth Baker as he emerged from the building. President Bush telephoned on Thursday and told Mrs. Thatcher ``we love you'' in a 10-minute conversation. Mrs. Thatcher is considered a staunch U.S. ally whose tough free-market policies dismantled much of Britain's welfare state and sold off government industries. The British Broadcasting Corp. reported that Mrs. Thatcher and her husband, Denis, began arranging to remove personal belongings from Downing Street, where she has lived for 11{ years. Reporters and television crews camped otside No. 10 and No. 11 Downing Street, the home of Major, the chief treasury official. He is widely regarded as being the most right-wing of the three candidates, and thus closest politically to Mrs. Thatcher. Hurd and Major argued today there was scant differences in their views. Both promised ``improvements'' in an unpopular local services tax on every adult. Heseltine has pledged what he calls a full-scale review. That tax and high inflation and interest rates have hurt the Conservatives and Mrs. Thatcher's government. In addition, Mrs. Thatcher's long tenure, her combative attitude on Europe and what critics called her dictatorial manner alienated some close Cabinet colleagues. In a first round of balloting for the party leadership post on Tuesday, Mrs. Thatcher needed to beat Heseltine by 15 percent of the eligible voters but fell four votes short. This precipitated the second round of balloting, scheduled for next Tuesday. If no winner emerges on a simple majority, a third and final round is scheduled for Nov. 29. A prime asset for Heseltine has been a series of polls showing that the Tories' 16-month lag behind the Labor Party in ratings would narrow, or even disappear, with him as party leader. Mrs. Thatcher resigned after Cabinet ministers and her campaign manager told her in private interviews Wednesday that she would lose to Heseltine in the second round, where a simple majority is required. The Independent reported today that a tearful Mrs. Thatcher told the Cabinet she had been forced out despite her three general election victories and widespread support among Conservative Party members outside the Commons. The London newspaper said the strong-willed Mrs. Thatcher, once dubbed the ``Iron Lady'' by the Soviets, was reported to have added wryly: ``It's a funny old world.'' Despite the domestic drama, the Cabinet also decided to send 14,000 more troops to the Persian Gulf, bringing the British forces there to 30,000. In a bravura performance in the House of Commons Thursday afternoon, Mrs. Thatcher defended her government's record and led a nearly unanimous Conservative Party in defeating a Labor Party no-confidence motion aimed at her government. Outside Downing Street, 250 left-wing demonstrators sang, danced and chanted anti-Thatcher slogans as her limousine swept past on Thursday night. Police reported 13 arrests. Mrs. Thatcher's son, Mark, told reporters at Downing Street today that he felt no bitterness. ``I think it's very wrong to criticize the system which got us elected 15 years ago just because it did not produce the result we wanted,'' he said. Rebellion against Mrs. Thatcher had been building for years, but news she had walked away from a fight surprised the world. She was Britain's first woman prime minister, Europe's longest-serving prime minister in this century and the only one to win three consecutive elections.

DOC.HEAD: Lukanov Defeats No-Confidence Motion
DOC.TEXT: Premier Andrei Lukanov today defeated a no-confidence motion pressed by political opponents seeking to oust his Socialist government. The opposition won 159 votes for the motion in a secret ballot in the 400-seat Grand National Assembly, but 201 deputies voted with Lukanov. The vote came a day after lawmakers approved Lukanov's austerity budget in a vote boycotted by the opposition. Lukanov had threatened to resign if the budget failed. The Socialists, the former Communists, won June elections, have 210 seats in Parliament. Prior to the vote, Lukanov defended himself against charges by the opposition that his government was ineffective in implementing reforms. There have been growing demands for Lukanov's resignation. On Thursday, about 50,000 people demonstrated outside the Parliament building. Alexander Yordanov of the opposition Union of Democratic Forces called Thursday for a new government, and said his group was prepared to take over if necessary. The inability of the government to improve the rapidly deteriorating economic situation and supplies of scarce foodstuffs and consumer goods has fired anger among the country's frustrated citizens. Opposition eaders claim they would triumph in new elections, and that Bulgaria would win greater international support under an opposition-led government. But Lukanov told the house that international support ``does not depend on the color of the government.'' The premier, who returned to Sofia Thursday from a 34-nation Paris summit, said recent international contacts let him see that no one would help a country ``in which there is no stability, in which the reforms are not decisively implemented.'' The opposition has repeatedly rejected Lukanov's requests to join a broad Socialist-led coalition government, insisting instead on naming the premier and holding key ministries.

DOC.HEAD: Government Says Troops Killed 100 Tamil Rebels in Raids
DOC.TEXT: Government troops backed by helicopter gunships raided a Tamil rebel camp in the northern jungles today, killing at least 75 guerrillas, military officials said. In another area of the north, troops killed 26 rebels in two operations, a Defense Ministry statement said. It said three soldiers were killed and 31 injured. The claims could not be independently confirmed. There was no immediate response from the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, the rebel group that is fighting to set up an independent nation in northern and eastern Sri Lanka. The military officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the 75 guerrillas were killed in Mankulam, 133 miles north of Colombo, in a counterattack after rebels ambushed and killed four soldiers. Residents of Vavuniya, 25 miles south of Mankulam, said they heard a series of explosions after seeing aircraft and helicopters flying overhead. The residents said they saw many wounded soldiers being transferred to ambulances from helicopters that landed in Vavuniya. They were contacted by telephone and spoke on condition of anonymity. The military officials did not mention any government casualties in the counterattack. The Defense Ministry statement said the other two battles occurred near Telippalai and Kaduwan, both in the rebel stronghold of the Jaffna Peninsula, 185 miles north of Colombo. The statement said 23 rebels and three soldiers were killed in Telippali and three militants were killed in Kaduwan. It did not give details.
