Tamil separatists began their campaign in 1983, complaining of discrimination in jobs, education and the use of Sinhala language by the government. Sinhalese make up 75 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people and control the government and the military. Tamils comprise 18 percent and Moslems account for 7 percent. At least 14,000 people have been killed in the 7-year-old insurgency.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Members Try To Revive Cambodian Peace Plan
DOC.TEXT: Cambodia's warring factions remained far apart today as diplomats held talks to revive a United Nations peace plan aimed at holding free elections in the nation. ``The sole difficulty at this point comes from the Cambodians themselves,'' a Foreign Ministry spokesman said as representatives of the five permanent U.N. Security Council members met behind closed doors. They were joined by representatives of Indonesia and U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar for two days of talks. The stalled peace plan envisions putting Cambodia under U.N. administration while elections can be organized. It would be the first time for the United Nations to fully administer a country. Cambodia would be guided during this period by a Supreme National Council of six representatives of the Phnom Penh government and six from the three-faction guerrilla resistance coalition. The plan is deadlocked, however, over who will lead the council. The resistance groups back former ruler Prince Norodom Sihanouk. The government wants Prime Minister Hun Sen. Sihanouk, the coalition's nominal leader, arrived in Paris on Wednesday for what he called a private visit ahead of the talks. The U.N. Security Council members participating are the United States, Soviet Union, France, Britain and China. It is Sihanouk's first visit to Paris since September 1989, when an international conference on Cambodia collapsed over his refusal to spurn the brutal Khmer Rouge, the strongest guerrilla faction in the resistence. Sihanouk lunched Thursday with former Cambodian prime minister Son Sann. The two men lead the other guerrilla factions fighting Hun Sen's Vietnamese-installed government. Son Sann announced late Thursday that he would try to end the current impasse by giving up his claim for a seat as vice chairman on the Supreme National Council ``to set a good example.'' The Cambodian war began when Vietnam invaded in late 1978 and drove the Khmer Rouge from power. The Khmer Rouge had ruled for three years, during which hundreds of thousands of Cambodians died. Vietnam withdrew troops last year and has been cooperating in the peace talks.

DOC.HEAD: Environmental Chief Said Ready to Veto Colorado Dam
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New thruout with EPA comments; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The Environmental Protection Agency has decided to veto construction of the Two Forks Dam in Colorado, the largest non-federal water project in the West, it was reported today. The Washington Post said EPA Administrator William K. Reilly is expected within a few days to announce a decision to block the billion-dollar dam, which the city of Denver had sought to increase water supplies for its suburbs. But EPA officials said today that while action will be taken soon on a review board's recommendation that no dam be built at the site, no decision has yet been made. The officials, who commented on condition they not be identified by name, said Riley will not make the decision himself but has delegated it to LaJuana S. Wilcher, the EPA's assistant administrator for water. One official confirmed that Ms. Wilcher is ``working on a document'' but added: ``Until it is final it is inappropriate to tell you what's in it.'' The dam has been the focus of an intense battle between environmentalists and supporters of increased development. The proposed project called for flooding much of Cheesman Canyon, a wilderness area between two forks of the South Platte River. The Post said it obtained a draft of the decision, which said the dam would lead to ``unacceptable adverse effects,'' including loss and damage to fisheries and recreational opportunities. Denver has ``practicable, less environmentally damaging alternatives'' to provide water for the new suburbs in the front range of the Rocky Mountains, Reilly is quoted as saying. Monte Pascoe, a Denver Water Board commissioner, told The Post the decision is ``unbelievably shortsighted. You're saying squeeze more out of the existing system and get right up to a drought before you recognize the problem.'' The Army Corps of Engineers in March 1989 approved a permit to build the dam, and former Reagan administration officials had indicated support for the project.

DOC.HEAD: Reagan Heaps Praise on Thatcher as She Heads Off Into Political Sunset
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites throughout to restore courtesy title on second reference to Mrs. Thatcher. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Britain Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan thanked British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher for backing him up when other allies backed down, heaping praise on his political soulmate as she heads off into the sunset. ``Margaret Thatcher was a completely reliable ally and partner of the greatest personal integrity,'' Reagan said in a statement after Mrs. Thatcher announced her impending retirement. ``I could always count on her wise counsel, her firm support, and her loyal friendship,'' Reagan said. Mrs. Thatcher on Thursday succumbed to the challenge mounted by Michael Heseltine, who resigned as her defense minister in 1986. Reagan and the prime minister dubbed the Iron Lady formed a formidable duo in the 1980s and made no secret of their mutual regard. They often stood side-by-side at international gatherings and called each other Ronnie and Margaret. Two years ago, as they met for the final time before Reagan left office, the president said he was leaving the White House with ``considerable satisfaction in the knowledge that Margaret Thatcher will still reside at No. 10 Downing Street.'' Reagan, who spent Thanksgiving with friends at his Bel-Air home, called her resignation in the face of strong opposition a ``selfless and courageous decision in what she believes is the best interests of her country.'' The former chief executive was always grateful to Mrs. Thatcher's support of his conservative approach to foreign affairs during his own eight-year tenure. In 1986, when the U.S. bombing of Libya was criticized by world powers, Mrs. Thatcher was the only ally who supported Reagan and allowed the bombers to fly from British bases. When Britain fought Argentina for the Falkland Islands, the United States was forced to choose between two allies. Reagan sided with Mrs. Thatcher. She also encouraged Reagan's nurturing of the huge Pentagon buildup, and backed U.S. efforts to install medium-range missiles in Europe, despite opposition from NATO allies. Both leaders adopted a hard line toward the Soviet Union, but were quick to warm up to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev as the Cold War thawed. Reagan credited Mrs. Thatcher's ``resoluteness'' for playing a key role in ending the tensions between the Western democracies and the Eastern Block. ``She stood up to the Soviets and let them know she meant business,'' he said. Both were ardent advocates of the free market and private enterprise. While the United States became mired in debt in the era of Reaganomics, the British economy thrived on Mrs. Thatcher's radical policies during her nearly 12-year rule. Average earnings were up by nearly one-third and more Britons owned their homes during her tenor. Like Reagan, however, Mrs. Thatcher was accused by liberals of widening the gap between the rich and poor in her country, and both clashed with organized labor.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Will Take Globe-Trotting Mission to South America
With PM-Gulf-Bush Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf `Since leaving...' with Baker meeting Malaysian officials in Los Angeles
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker is winding up a trip to the Persian Gulf region after failing to win Yemeni support for a U.N. resolution authorizing the use of force against Iraq. Yemen, the only Arab nation on the 15-member council, was disinclined to sign anything that might cause a military clash in the region. With Baker at his side Thursday, Yemeni President Ali Abdullah Saleh criticized the presence of foreign troops in the region and warned that if war breaks out, ``there will be no winner.'' Baker acknowledged that the two governments differ on the best way to achieve a political solution. Yemen has abstained from voting on five of the 10 Security Council resolutions against Iraq since Aug. 2. Baker plans to meet Saturday with senior officials in Colombia, which is a member of the Security Council. That body would have to approve a measure giving advance authorization to drive Iraq out of Kuwait. He will leave Bogota on Saturday for Los Angeles, where he will hold talks with Malaysian officials. Since leaving Washington last week, Baker has met with foreign ministers of nine nations on the council. Colombia and Malaysia will be Nos. 10 and 11. Cuba also has abstained from some votes and cast a ``no'' ballot on one. Yemen's place on the council takes on increased importance because it will assume the group's chairmanship in December, taking over from the United States. The Bush administration would like to get the resolution through the council by the end of the month, just a week away. French President Francois Mitterrand predicted Wednesday that a use-of-force statement would be adopted by mid-December. Baker joined President Bush in Paris earlier in the week at a 34-nation East-West conference. While there, he talked at length with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. Afterward, Shevardnadze said it was time to return to the Security Council to ``take stock of things.'' He said resolutions approved so far have not achieved their purpose of getting Iraq out of Kuwait. However, he did not specifically endorse a use-of-force resolution. On Thursday, Soviet envoy Alexander Belonogov told the United Arab Emirates news agency that the Kremlin would like the council to set a deadline for an Iraqi pullout, without raising the military option. Since leaving Washington, Baker has met with the foreign ministers of the following council members: Ethiopia, the Ivory Coast, Zaire, Romania, Finland, the Soviet Union, Britain, France and Yemen. He previously conferred with officials from China and Canada. The only two council members he hasn't met with personally are Cuba and Malaysia. Efforts to meet with Malaysian officials while in the Gulf didn't work out. The United States, France, the Soviet Union, Britain and China are permanent members of the council empowered to veto resolutions. Baker will return to the United States late Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Company Withdraws Cookies With Nude Models
DOC.TEXT: A bakery has recalled from stores near elementary schools fortune cookies that contain pictures of women whose bikinis can be scratched off, the head of a children's association said Friday. Parents demanded the withdrawal of the cookies after their children began collecting pictures of the nude models, said Lin Tse-kuei, head of the Women and Children Protection Association. The pictures are inserted inside the cookies. The bikinis can be scratched off with a coin. Pin Fa Bakery said it made 100,000 cookies for a Hong Kong night club but the order was later canceled and it sold them to Taiwan stores for about 3 cents apiece. It said about 50,000 cookies were sold, many to children. It said it had recalled the remaining 50,000 cookies and would look for another market.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Government To Repair Roof Of Church Of The Nativity
DOC.TEXT: Israel said Friday it would repair a leaky roof at the Church of the Nativity, built at the site where tradition says Jesus was born, because feuding Christian sects can't agree on who is responsible for upkeep. Repairs at the church in the occupied West Bank town of Bethlehem will begin in a few days and should be completed by Christmas, said Shmuel Hamburger, a military government official. ``The roof is in such bad shape that the last time we had rain two weeks ago, it was pouring inside the church,'' he said. He said there were gaping holes in the wood-and-tar roof. Last Christmas, buckets for rainwater were set out inside the basilica. The dispute stems from the intense rivalry between Christian sects over custody of the holy sites. Rights of worship and maintenance are spelled out in minute detail in a set of rules dating back to the 1850s. However, jurisdiction over the roof of the Church of the Nativity is not specifically mentioned in the rules. In the past, area authorities - the Ottomans, the British, the Jordanians and finally the Israelis - fixed the roof periodically to prevent squabbles among the sects. But this year, the Greek Orthodox Church insisted on fixing the roof, saying it traditionally cleaned the roof and therefore should be allowed to do the repairs. The rival Armenian and Roman Catholic churches protested, saying the roof should be fixed by all three groups - or not at all. The Israelis stepped in several months ago with an offer to do the repairs, but the Armenians and Roman Catholics asked that the work be postponed. The offer came at a time when the Christian communities in Jerusalem were incensed that the government supported Jewish settlers trying to take over Greek Orthodox Church property near the Church of the Holy Sepulcher where tradition says Jesus was buried. Hamburger said that since then, the Armenians and Roman Catholics have changed their minds. ``Now they want us to repair the roof,'' he said. He said he has not contacted Greek Orthodox church officials in the past few months, and didn't know whether they also had a change of heart. However, Hamburger said Israel had a right to carry out the repairs even if the Greek Orthodox opposed it. But the Greek Orthodox appeared insistent that they should have custody of the roof. Twice in the past week, Greek Orthodox sneaked onto the roof to start repairs. Both efforts drew protests from the other sects, and the army intervened. Bishop Palladios, who answered the phone at the Greek Orthodox Patriarchate in Jerusalem, said he could not comment on the case. He referred all calls to the patriarch, who is visiting Athens. The patriarch could not be reached for comment in Greece. The Church of the Nativity, on Bethlehem's Manger Square, was built by Constantine in the year 330 and restored and enlarged in the sixth century by Byzantine Emperor Justinian. The structure, believed to be the oldest Christian church in continuous use, was erected over a grotto believed to be the site where Jesus was born.

DOC.HEAD: Legislature Acts To Keep Union Together Through Temporary Agreements
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with Supreme Soviet adopting package of resolutions on keeping union together, endorsing Gorbachev's government restructuring plan, other details; pickup 11th graf pvs, `So far...'
DOC.TEXT: The national legislature today asked its chairman to begin talks with the 15 Soviet republics to reach temporary agreements to prevent the further breakup of the country and stabilize the economy. Acting on a package of proposals, the lawmakers also endorsed for a second time inh a week President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's proposed restructuring of the government. It called on the Soviet leader to act quickly to improve food supplies. The lawmakers asked Gorbachev to act within two weeks to assure that there will be enough food this winter. In the past month, he has been touring Western Europe in search of foreign food aid, and he has received several offers. The resolution contained a gloomy assessment of the nation's economic and political affairs. ``The situation in the country continues to worsen and is approaching a crisis condition,'' it said. Another resolution passed recommended that Gorbachev take all steps ``authorized by law, up to extraordinary measures'' in cases where there is a threat to human life, health or property. That measure removed a requirement for the president to consult with leaders of the republics before taking such measures and gave the KGB responsibility for dealing with what it called ``economic sabotage.'' In a 10-minute speech, Gorbachev told the 542-member legislature that ``every day is precious'' and urged them to move swiftly toward a new union treaty to replace a 1924 accord uniting the republics. The legislature voted to ask its chairman, Anatoly Lukyanov, to urgently begin negotiations with the leaders of the parliaments in the 15 republics for a temporary series of agreements to keep the country together. Legislative work on a union treaty is going slowly and the country's republics increasingly are disregarding Kremlin authority. The resolution said provisional agreements with the republics would help stabilize the ``social and economic situation in the country.'' So far, each republic has acted independently in introducing reforms to switch to a free market economy. All but one of the country's republics have declared sovereignty from the Kremlin. The result has been what many call a ``paralysis of power'' that has hindered any reform and caused a breakdown of the country's political and economic life. The Supreme Soviet said in its resolution that agreements should be reached with the republics to stop legal contradictions. In their drives for sovereignty or outright independence, the republics have passed laws that ignore or even contradict national legislation. Some politicians have suggested a temporary moratorium on republican legislation that contradicts national laws. Gorbachev's main political rival, Russian Federation President Boris N. Yeltsin, has urged the republics not to wait for approval of a new union treaty and to create their own economic structure. Russia, the biggest republic, has signed four bilateral treaties with other republics that bypass the Kremlin and govern trade, cultural and political ties. In his speech, Gorbachev appeared to take a swipe at Yeltsin. Gorbachev warned the lawmakers that ``there are forces that don't want to normalize the situation.'' He blasted people who criticize his reforms as an attempt at ``dictatorship, an attempt to go for the jugular ... to take advantage of the situation.'' Opponents, he said, really want to ``let the paralysis of power continue.'' Gorbachev's proposals to restructure the government are aimed at ridding the power structure of officials resistant to radical reform and bringing in representatives of the republics. Today's resolution also endorsed Gorbachev's proposal to eliminate the Council of Ministers, or Soviet Cabinet, and make another body the highest state organ. That proposal has a number of other legislative hurdles before it becomes law. The lawmakers told the president today to submit more concrete definitions of what each new government body would do within two weeks. Under the outline, the Council of Ministers would be replaced by several bodies under direct presidential control. The principal ruling body would be the Federation Council, grouping representatives of the republics. Many of Gorbachev's proposals will require constitutional amendments, which must be adopted by the Supreme Soviet's parent body, the Congress of People's Deputies.

DOC.HEAD: Tourists Stage Sit-in Protest
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of foreign tourists angered by a long flight delay staged an hourlong sit-in on an airport tarmac, an airport official said Friday. A Garuda Indonesia Boeing 747 carrying 300 tourists was unable to proceed Wednesday because of engine trouble after refueling at the Polinia airport in Medan, North Sumtra. The jumbo jet had been en route from Bali to Abu Dhabi. The tourists had to spend the night in the airport lounge because all hotels in the North Sumatra capital were booked, the airport official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. By Thursday afternoon the tourists walked to the tarmac and sat down, threatening to block flights unless the airline could immediately arrange their flight or provide suitable accommodations, he said. The tourists ended their protest when the airline provided a new plane, the official said. A Garuda official refused to comment beyond saying: ``We regret that incident.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Recover Stolen 2,100-Year-Old Artifact
DOC.TEXT: Police have recovered a tiny 2,100-year-old piece of bronze inscribed with edicts from both emperors of the short-lived Qin Dynasty, an official report said Friday. The bronze piece was used as a counterweight when weighing other objects. It is 4 inches long and weighs nearly 3 pounds, the official Xinhua News Agency said. It is inscribed with edicts from Emperors Qin Shihuang and Qin Ershi on unifying the system of weights and measures. Xinhua said the counterweight was found in August 1989 among scrap materials purchased by a shop in the western city of Xian. Shop assistant Zhang Yulong took it home and showed it to a relics smuggler, Wang Tianyin. Later, he discovered it was missing and told police, Xinhua said. Police recovered it Nov. 11 in the southern coastal city of Guangzhou, also known as Canton, when a man named Li Shiyong tried to smuggle it out of China, the report said. Li also was trying to smuggle out more than 8,600 ancient coins, it said. Xinhua said Wang stole the bronze weight and sold it to Li for about $3,270, but did not say how much experts estimated it was worth. Archeologists have declared it a first-class national treasure.

DOC.HEAD: Arab Couple Wanders into Wrong Garden
DOC.TEXT: An Arab couple out for a moonlit walk got in trouble with the law for wandering in the wrong garden, newspapers reported Friday. The couple, both residents of Arab east Jerusalem, were walking in a park and slipped through an opening in a fence into an adjacent garden, the Hebrew daily Yedioth Ahronoth said. The garden turned out to be on the grounds of the Israeli Parliament, and guards there were not pleased to see intruders. The two, in their late twenties, were released after police questioning determined their intentions were romantic and not revolutionary, the newspaper said. Their names were not made public.

DOC.HEAD: Pensioners Sell Medicines on Drug Market, Police Says
DOC.TEXT: Several retired people have added to their pension by selling sleeping pills and other state-subsidized medicines on the drug market, police said. ``Mind you, this is not the average retired person doing this ... the people involved are those who have had problems with drugs themselves,'' said Thor Carsten Pedersen, a senior police official in Kristiansand, a town in southern Norway. ``They have sold sleeping pills and tranquilizers ... the sleeping pills at about 10 kroner ($1.70) per pill,'' Pedersen said. He said one pensioner had been caught and would probably be fined. Police had been tipped of a few others involved. Kristiansand, a coastal town of about 65,000 people, has in the past decade had growing problems with heavy drugs, including heroin. Prescribed medicines are heavily subsidized in this welfare state and retired people are big consumers. Pedersen said the biggest problem in Kristiansand was not pensioners selling medicines in the street, but doctors prescribing too many sleeping pills and tranquilizers to young people with problems.

DOC.HEAD: Army Reserves Helicopter on Night Training Mission Crashes in Lake
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with pilot among the survivors, divers searching this morning for the missing crew member, add background on goggles. Picks up 5th graf, `The helicopter was ...'
DOC.TEXT: An Army Reserves helicopter on a night training mission crashed into Lake Ellsworth and five crew members were pulled to safety aboard a fishing boat. A sixth was missing, authorities said today. The pilot, who was among the survivors, was wearing night goggles for an over-water training exercise when the UH-1 helicopter crashed Thursday night, said Fort Sill spokesman Maj. Chuck Pope. ``The news is good about the five,'' Pope said early today. ``We don't know about the sixth.'' ``Two have a bit of hypothermia, one was shaken up a bit and the other two are fine,'' he said. Divers in wet suits searched the southwestern Oklahoma lake this morning for the missing soldier. A helicopter like the one that crashed was parked on the lake shore so the divers could study it before taking to the murky water. Comanche County Undersheriff John Stowe said the helicopter was in about 15 feet of water. Authorities thought the missing crewman might be inside the helicopter, Stowe said. The use of night vision goggles, which electronically enhance moonlight, has come under fire in recent years because some pilots say they limit peripheral vision and cause other problems. The Army says it has improved the goggles after they were blamed for a 1988 crash at Fort Campbell, Ky., that killed 17 soldiers. The helicopter was part of 374th Air Ambulance Company based in Little Rock, Ark., Pope said. The lake is about 15 miles north of the Army post. The medical evacuation company had been activated for Operation Desert Shield in the Persian Gulf and had arrived at Fort Sill earlier this month. After lake residents rescued the five crew members, authorities later ordered all boats out of the water so helicopters using searchlights could fly low to look for the missing crew member. The cause of the crash was under investigation. Shoreline residents reported hearing an explosion before the crash. Barbara and Kevin McCray went outside to investigate. ``We could hear them moaning in the water,'' said McCray, who joined a neighbor on his boat to rescue the five crew members. ``If one of those guys hadn't had a little blue beacon light, we wouldn't have found them,'' McCray said. ``There were pieces of helicopter scattered all over the water. ``The five were wrapped around the rotor and they said one hadn't come up,'' he said. ``First I started to panic,'' Spec. Mike Pierce said later, wrapped in a blanket in a shoreside home. ``Then I thought, `Stay calm,' and I reached for my seat belt and floated out.''

DOC.HEAD: Five Miners Die in Methane Gas Accident
DOC.TEXT: An accidental outburst of methane gas and coal killed five miners in a Siberian mineshaft, the Tass news agency said Friday. The accident happened Thursday night at the Anzherskaya coal mine, part of the Severokuzbassugol production complex, Tass said. It occurred during drivage work, according to mining specialists quoted by the news agency. A state commission was sent to the mine to investigate the accident.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. First Lady on Stage: Chatting with Children in Cairo
With AM-Gulf-Bush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: As Barbara Bush looked on, girls in billowy pink and blue pants gyrated to Arabic music. Others, wearing fancy leotards, demonstrated aerobics. A serious little boy read poetry in Arabic. While their husbands conferred about the Persian Gulf crisis, Mrs. Bush and her Egyptian counterpart, Suzanne Mubarak, toured a children's library. The children had several questions for the American first lady. Why did she marry George Bush? ``Because he's the nicest, friendliest, funniest, warmest, wisest person I've ever known,'' she said. How does she feel as wife of the president of the United States? ``I feel very, very lucky. Sometimes I feel a little bit of a burden. There is so much to do, and you don't have the time. Sometimes you want to do better.'' What are you going to ask for from Santa Claus? ``I'm going to ask Santa Claus for peace. How about that?'' The kids applauded and cheered. That was as near to politics as the questions came, although Mrs. Bush's 9-year-old guide, Sherif Hashem, told a reporter he had wanted to ask her about the resignation of British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. A teacher advised him not to, he said. Later, a reporter did the job for Sherif. The resigned British leader will be missed, Mrs. Bush said, ``but that's not the end of our friendship with Mrs. Thatcher. We'll see her again and again - she's a friend.'' Mrs. Bush said she was proud of the U.S. troops deployed in Saudi Arabia and that she was glad to have shared Thanksgiving with them. Mrs. Bush, wearing khaki slacks and a camouflage jacket, traveled with the president to two military encampments in the Saudi desert and to a U.S. warship off the Persian Gulf coast. She ate turkey with the troops and promised some she would call their relatives. ``My husband and I both felt very moved by those wonderful young men and women. I, like everybody else, hope that this will end peacefully,'' she said. The children waved little American flags, distributed by the U.S. Embassy, and posed for a souvenir photo with Mrs. Bush and Mrs. Mubarak. Mrs. Bush was given a tapestry made by one of the children. Security was heavy at the library, and at the Egyptian Museum, which Mrs. Bush also visited. The museum, which houses 100,000 artifacts from 5,000 years of Egyptian civilization, was closed to the public all morning, and American security men with an explosive-sniffing dog meticulously examined press equipment. Egyptian intelligence personnel stood watch in the museum corridors. The glass-encased mummy of Pharaoh Ramses II, usually covered with a blue cloth to protect it from camera flashes, was uncovered for the occasion. One of the most delicate of the ancient Egyptian relics, Ramses II's mummy, traveled to France in 1976 for treatment against decay. ``He's well now,'' Mrs. Bush said as Zahi Hawass, director of antiquities at the Pyramids area, related the mummy's history to the first ladies.

DOC.HEAD: Little Chance of Rare AIDS Virus Infecting Blood Supply, CDC Says
DOC.TEXT: A rare form of the AIDS virus could slip into the nation's blood supply, but officials at the federal Centers for Disease Control said Friday that it wasn't worth the cost to try to detect it. Only 18 known cases of the virus, known as HIV-2, exist in the United States. Tests for the more common AIDS virus, HIV-1, will usually - but not always - detect the rarer strain, predominantly found in West Africa. A CDC study of more than 25,000 blood samples detected no blood donors with HIV-2 infection. It would cost more than $60 million a year to test every blood donor for HIV-2, and the CDC concluded that it wasn't worth it. Dr. Lyle Peterson, an epidemiologist at the Atlanta-based CDC who led the study, said researchers chose 25,000 blood samples from the American Red Cross and New York Blood Center, which provide more than 50 percent of the nation's blood supply. Currently, blood centers conduct two tests for HIV-1: an enzyme immuniassay (EIA) and Western blot. Positive results from one test mean the blood is not transfused. Peterson said researchers have discovered that HIV-2 carriers are likely to test positive on the EIA and negative on the Western blot. So the study only used EIA-positive samples. But when these high-risk samples were tested solely for HIV-2, that strain of the virus did not appear. ``These (samples) represent over 12 million donations, so we're pretty confident there isn't any HIV-2'' in the blood supply, Peterson said. ``Generally, 60 to 90 percent of the time, HIV-2 (carriers) will have a positive HIV-1 test.'' The CDC believes there is only one HIV-2 carrier to have donated blood in the United States. The woman, who was not identified, had traveled to West Africa and donated blood in 1986 before the HIV-2 surveillance project began. But because her blood tested positive for HIV-1, it was not transfused. The CDC has biographical information on 15 of the 18 HIV-2 infected people in the United States. All of those either had immigrated from or traveled to West Africa recently or had had sexual contact with West Africans. Because of the HIV-2 risk, people who have moved to the United States from West Africa since 1977 are excluded from donating blood, and officials routinely question potential donors about their contact with West Africans. Peterson said the CDC is continuing the study and will report to the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, which would decide whether HIV-2 tests become necessary.

DOC.HEAD: Two Menudo Singers Arrested When Airport Dog Sniffs Pot; Later Fired
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with members fired, record company says.
DOC.TEXT: Two members of the Puerto Rican singing group Menudo were arrested after an airport drug-sniffing dog detected marijuana in their pants, and a spokesman for the group's record company said both were fired today. Oscar Llord, general manager for Sonotone Music, the group's Miami record company, said the group's manager had fired the two singers hours after their arrest. Sergio Gonzalez, 18, and a 16-year-old member of the group, whose name was not released because he is a juvenile, were arrested Thursday evening at Miami International Airport, Metro-Dade police Lt. James Kaelin said. The group was on a stopover en route from Mexico City to Venezuela when a U.S. Customs Service dog smelled the marijuana, Kaelin said. Customs agents took small amounts of the drug from the two, who were charged with possession of marijuana, he said. ``I guess some people call them personal-use amounts, but drugs are drugs, no matter what amounts they are,'' said Customs spokesman Joe Krokos. Gonzalez was released on a $1,000 bond Thursday night, officials said. Though the reason is different this time, firing of Menudo members is in itself nothing new. They are routinely replaced as they get too old to appeal to their pre-teen and teen audience. Menudo loosely translates as ``pocket money'' or ``small change.'' Members were active in Nancy Reagan's anti-drug ``Just Say No'' campaign. The group has been highly successful in the Spanish-speaking world, performing before sold-out stadiums throughout Latin America.

DOC.HEAD: `Medical Miranda' Warning Gives Patients Legal Options
DOC.TEXT: Many of America's hospitals and nursing homes are welcoming a new medical ``Miranda warning'' that gives patients their legal options for refusing or accepting treatment if they are incapacitated. ``If the issue is dealt with up front, it certainly makes things easier when crisis situations occur,'' said Janet Riley, a spokeswoman for the American Health Care Association, which represents 10,000 nursing homes. The legislation was tucked away in the deficit-cutting package approved in the congressional rush to adjourn and quietly became law with President Bush's signature earlier this month. It stemmed, in part, from the Missouri case of Nancy Cruzan, a woman who has been in a coma-like state since a 1983 car accident. The Supreme Court, in its first right-to-die ruling, rejected a request by Ms. Cruzan's parents to remove a tube sustaining her with food and water. The court said the Cruzans didn't have ``clear and convincing'' evidence that their daughter would want to be allowed to die. Advocates hope the law will help families avoid lengthy lawsuits to end unwanted, life-prolonging treatment. The law, effective in November 1991, applies to hospitals, hospices, nursing homes, health maintenance organizations and other health care facilities that receive money from Medicare and Medicaid programs. It will, supporters say, help inform patients of their medical care rights much in the same way police advise people of their legal rights in criminal matters through a ``Miranda warning'' at the time of arrest. ``For the first time, adult patients will be provided with the knowledge of their legal rights to make decisions about their care,'' said Sen. John Danforth, R-Mo. Under the law, patients must receive written information explaining their right-to-die options under their state laws. For example, a person checking into a hospital would be told about ``advance directives'' such as a living will, which spells out a person's wishes for treatment. Another possibility is a durable power of attorney, which designates someone else to make medical decisions if an individual is unable to do so. Hospitals and other providers must note on medical records whether patients have legal directives on treatment. Providers also must have procedures to ensure they comply with a patient's wishes in accordance with state law. The law requires the Department of Health and Human Services to conduct a nationwide campaign to educate people about right-to-die legal options. ``The most important aspect of the law in my mind is not necessarily what it's requiring hospitals to do ... but that there is a public educational effort,'' said Frederick J. Entin, general counsel for the American Hospital Association. Danforth, who introduced the legislation with Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., has complained ``the health care and legal systems do a terrible job of telling patients about care in hopeless situations.'' But Thomas Marzen, general counsel for the National Legal Center for the Medically Dependent and Disabled, was critical of the legislation. ``It could become a program of persuasion for a lot of people to decline medical treatment, even if it's not particularly burdensome and might be necessary,'' he said. The law, particularly for the disabled, could act as ``another nail in the coffin - trying to get them, because they are deemed to have a low quality of life, not to live,'' Marzen said. Advocates say the law creates no new federal rights. ``This isn't a bill that says you must refuse treatment'' said Fenella Rouse, executive director of the Society for the Right To Die-Concern for Dying. ``It is a bill that says you're free to make your own choices.''

DOC.HEAD: Hurd Says Security Council to Meet Next Week on Gulf
DOC.NOTE: Eds: COMBINES urgent series, ADDS background; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said today that the U.N. Security Council may meet next week to consider a draft resolution authorizing the use of force against Iraq in the Persian Gulf crisis. Hurd met earlier this week on the sidelines of an international summit in Paris with U.S. Secretary of State James Baker III to discuss the proposed resolution, which would authorize an attack to drive Iraq from Kuwait. The United States lobbied extensively with its allies to garner support for the resolution and maintain the international coalition that has formed against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. Several leaders speculated in Paris that the meeting at the United Nations would take place in December. But Hurd's comments were the first indication that enough support had been gathered to call the meeting as early as the end of this month. The United States holds the chairmanship of the council, but it is rotated and passes to Yemen in December. Yemen, the only Arab nation on the council, has refused to endorse the proposed resolution. The United States has led the campaign to win international support, and Baker visited Yemen on Thursday. Both sides said no decision had been reached. But President Gen. Ali Abdullah Saleh, standing next to Baker, criticized the military buildup in the region and called for an Arab solution to the crisis. In Cairo today, President Bush told reporters ``the world is getting tired'' of Iraq's continuing occupation of Kuwait and said he was closing in on an agreement for the proposed resolution. Speaking at the launching of his campaign for leader of Britain's Conservative Party and prime minister, Hurd said the gulf crisis ``weighs on my mind among the issues more heavily than anything else at the present time.'' Hurd said he hoped that passage of the proposed resolution would be ``the latest of the peaceful pressures on Saddam Hussein to get him to withdraw.'' ``I don't know whether those peaceful pressures will work - and that is why I fear the crisis is entering a crucial, critical phase and in the next weeks and months we will be in that phase,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Human Bomb Attack Fails
DOC.TEXT: A ``human bomb'' attack, similar to last month's IRA bombing which killed seven people, failed when the enormous bomb fizzled, police said Friday. No one immediately claimed responsibility for Thursday night's failed attack but a spokesman for the Royal Ulster Constabular said the Irish Republican Army was suspected. The RUC spokesman said armed, masked men kidnapped a man from his home near Newtown Butler and ordered him to drive a truck containing a 3,500-pound bomb to an army checkpoint at Annaghmartin. The gang tied up the man's elderly parents and locked them in a bathroom while the man was driven near the checkpoint, 56 miles southwest of Belfast. The man was told to deliver the bomb, which they said had a five-minute timer, police said. The man drove the red pickup to the checkpoint, jumped out and shouted a warning. A short time later there was a small explosion, which was believed to have been caused by the detonator going off, police said. Army bomb experts defused the bomb, one of the largest ever found in Northern Ireland, police said. The army said there was only minimal damage and no one was injured. On Oct. 24, the IRA staged three human bomb attacks which killed six soldiers and a civilian, who drove one of the bombs to the army targets. The IRA is fighting British rule in Northern Ireland. It wants to unite the predominantly Protestant province with the 95 percent Catholic Republic of Ireland, under socialist rule.

DOC.HEAD: Damage Five Times As Bad As Five Years Ago
DOC.TEXT: The number of pine trees in Yosemite Park damaged by ozone has increased more than five-fold in the last five years, according to a new study. The report, released this week, says 29.7 percent of Yosemite's pines now show mottling caused by damage from ozone, a colorless, odorless gas produced by auto and industrial emissions. A similar study in 1985 found 5.7 percent of the trees had suffered damage, the National Park Service reported. Officials at Yosemite, which celebrated its 100th birthday as a national park Oct. 1, said they need to study the 1990 findings before they can comment on ways to alleviate the problem. But a decade-old master plan for the park in the central Sierra Nevada calls for eventually abolishing vehicle traffic by tourists into Yosemite Valley, their prime destination. No timetable has been announced for the plan to force tourists to switch to trams or buses and leave their cars above Yosemite Valley. But National Park Service Director James Ridenour has promised that park maintenance facilities will be moved out of the valley, perhaps starting as early as the 1992 fiscal year. The effects of ozone in the Sierra Nevada first were noticed in the 1970s at Sequoia National Park, 100 miles south of Yosemite and less than 150 miles north of Los Angeles. The Park Service has commissioned research to determine if ozone affects giant sequoias as it does pine trees. Diane Ewell, Sequoia's air quality specialist, says officials may start a system to warn visitors when the park's ozone is high, much like the alerts in smogbound cities such as Los Angeles.

DOC.HEAD: Business in Civil War Relics is Booming
DOC.TEXT: Confederate money and weapons were nearly worthless when Sherman attacked Atlanta in 1864. But time and television have been kind to the Confederacy, which is now a hot spot in the memorabilia market. ``We won out anyway,'' said Dent Myers, owner of Wildman's Civil War Surplus in Kennesaw and a descendant of a rebel soldier. ``All the Confederate stuff is worth more now than Union stuff.'' Prompted in part by the Public Broadcasting Service documentary ``The Civil War,'' more and more people are out to buy souvenirs, and demand is creating ever higher prices for authentic objects. ``There's been an unbelievable increase in sales,'' said Lori Nash, an employee at Stone Mountain Relics. ``Everybody says, `I want a gun like in that movie.''' In some cases, collectors are paying up to $4,000 for rifles and as much as $2,000 for certain Confederate belt buckles. Musket balls and bullets, however, are still the cheapest items, sometimes going for as little as $2 each. By comparison, John Marcinkowski spent $24,000 for a one-ton piece of history that rests in his father's basement. ``It just makes me happy,'' Marcinkowski, a Vietnam veteran who lives in Marietta, said of his recent purchase of a Pennsylvania cannon. ``A lot of people don't know their history.''

DOC.HEAD: Hurd: U.N. Security Council Might Meet Next Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with British foreign secretary saying Security Council resoltuion might come next week, Bush arriving in Geneva; Edits to trim, conform; No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today he was close to getting U.N. authorization to use force against Iraq, and Britain's foreign secretary said the Security Council might meet next week to consider the matter. The United States, meanwhile, made an ``urgent'' appeal today to its NATO allies to help ship and fly additional U.S. troops and equipment to the gulf region. Iraq announced today it was calling up army reservists. A defense communique read on Baghdad radio said reservists born in 1958, 1959 and 1960 would have three days to report for duty. The callup appeared to be part of a buildup of 150,000 reservists announced earlier this week. The communique did not provide numbers for those born in the three years mentioned. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein on Thursday visited his troops in Kuwait. He used the trip, his second since the invasion, as the scene for new threats to the U.S.-led alliance. Saddam's visit to the emirate was announced today. Bush met in Cairo, Egypt today with President Hosni Mubarak, who has led Arab opposition to Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. He later flew to Geneva, where he was to meet with President Hafez Assad of Syria, who also has joined forces with the United States in its confrontation with Saddam. In Cairo today, Bush told reporters ``the world is getting tired'' of Iraq's continuing occupation of Kuwait. He said that in his most recent round of diplomacy he was closing in on an agreement for a U.N. Security Council resolution authorizing the use of miltiary might to drive Iraq out of Kuawit. But even without it, ``we have the authority to do what we have to do,'' Bush said. Mubarak reiterated Egypt's wish to get Iraq out of Kuwait, but was non-committal on the issue of using force to do so. Later, Britain's Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said in London: ``Soon, probably next week, the Security Council will consider a draft resolution authorizing member states to use force to bring about the reversal of the Iraqi aggression.'' Hurd spoke at the launching of his campaign for leader of Britain's Conservative Party. Earlier this week, during an international summit in Paris, Bush lobbied hard with its allies to garner support for the resolution and maintain the international coalition that has formed against Saddam. Secretary of State James A. Baker III visited Yemen on Thursday, trying to get the only Arab nation on the U.N. Security Council to support the use of force against Iraq. Both sides said no decision had been reached. Congressional leaders said today that Bush would have a far better chance of getting Congress to approve the use of force in the Persian Gulf if the United Nations first backed such a move. The U.S. has deployed 230,000 troops in the Persian Gulf as part of the multinational effort against Iraq. Iraq has stationed about 430,000 troops in southern Iraq and Kuwait. Meanwhile, the Chinese and Soviet foreign ministers held talks today on the gulf crisis. Later, the two reiterated their opposition to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and their demand that it withdraw. Neither Qian Qichen of China nor Eduard Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union disclosed whether they had reached agreement on the next step to defuse the crisis. They met in the remote Chinese city of Urumqi, near the two countries' Central Asian border. Saddam visited his troops in Kuwait and southern Iraq on Thursday for the second time since his invasion, according to the official Iraqi News Agency, monitored in Nicosia, Cyprus. ``We are not seeking war, but if war is imposed on us we will fight in a manner that will please friends and incense the evil blasphemers,'' he told officers, the agency said. On the same day Saddam visited Kuwait, Bush shared a Thanksgiving turkey dinner with U.S. troops in the sands of the Saudi desert and promised the soldiers that ``We are not here on some exercise.'' In Kuwait, Iraqi occupation authorities have lifted a curfew, the Iraqi News Agency reported today. The report indicated the Baghdad government wants to convey that conditions in Kuwait City and its environs have quieted down. Also in Kuwait, Iraq rounded up five Britons who had been in hiding, the British Foreign Office said today. Iraq is holding hundreds of Westerners, many as human shields at strategic sites to deter attack by the multinational forces.

DOC.HEAD: Demonstrators March to Protest Emperor's Enthronement
DOC.TEXT: About 2,400 people in two cities Friday protested enthronement ceremonies for Emperor Akihito and the government's proposal to send members of the military overseas. In downtown Tokyo, 300 riot police stood guard as about 1,400 people marched on busy streets chanting ``Destroy the rituals!'' No injuries were reported, although police said they made two arrests. In Osaka, almost 1,000 people performed music and danced to protest the ceremonies. Opponents say the state-funded rites violate the constitution, which mandates the separation of religion and state and defines the emperor as a national symbol. Akihito's father, Hirohito, was enthroned as a living god and was used by militarists to rally support for Japanese aggression in World War II. ``Our country will repeat its history if Japanese citizens allow the emperor's enthronement rituals,'' warned Yosuke Sugi, a leader of the ultra-leftist Chukaku-ha group. The demonstrators also opposed an unsuccessful bill introduced by the governing Liberal Democratic Party that would have allowed the dispatch of Japan's military overseas as part of international peacekeeping efforts. In a predawn ceremony Friday, Emperor Akihito observed the most controversial rite in his accession to the Chrysanthemum Throne, in which he communed with the Shinto sun goddess. Legend says the imperial line descended from the goddess and in the past the rite was believed to give emperors their status as living gods. About 30,000 police were assigned to security in Tokyo during the ritual. Akihito was formally enthroned on Nov. 12.

DOC.HEAD: Gift List Can't Be Had for a Song
With AM-Christmas Sales, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS list to INSERT cost of six geese-a-laying.
DOC.TEXT: If you're sining the blues about the cost of Christmas presents, be thankful your true love isn't asking for the complete catalog of gifts in ``The Twelve Days of Christmas.'' J. Patrick Bradley, that literal-minded chief economist at Provident National Bank, has once again toted up the sales slip for the items listed in the old carol, from a partridge in a pear tree to twelve drummers drumming. This year's total: $15,231.72. That means the Christmas Price Index (CPI) was up 4.34 percent from last year. That's a slower inflation rate than the government's Consumer Price Index, up 6.3 percent in the same period. Five gold rings fell in price, from $750 to $600, and the nursery Bradley checks every year had a half-price sale on pear trees, just $12.48 this year. So who's to blame for the higher index? Those nine ladies dancing and ten lords-a-leaping don't come cheap. Bradley checked with the Philadelphia Dance Company and found a performance by the ladies would cost $2,417.90, up from $2,084.40; ten leaping lords would run you $2,686.56, up from $2,316. Eleven pipers piping cost $42.12 more this year, or $947.70; 12 drummers drumming can be had for $1,026.68, up $45.63. And those eight maids-a-milking are still a minimum-wage bargain at $30.40 for an hour's work, up $3.60. Everything else held steady. Swans continue to be the biggest strain on the credit-card limit at $1,000 a pop, or $7,000 for all seven. ``We have been tracking these prices since 1984, as a way of getting ourselves into the Christmas spirit,'' Bradley said. ``Many of our clients look forward to reading about it. Plus, it shows that we practitioners of the dismal science have a sense of humor.'' ---= The complete list, with prices: One partridge in a pear tree, $27.48. (Partridge, $15; pear tree, $12.48.) Two turtle doves, $50. Three French hens, $15. Four calling birds, $280. Five gold rings, $600. Six geese-a-laying, $150. Seven swans-a-swimming, $7,000. Eight maids-a-milking, $30.40. Nine ladies dancing, $2,417.90. Ten lords-a-leaping, $2,686.56. Eleven pipers piping, $947.70. Twelve drummers drumming, $1,026.68.

DOC.HEAD: New Telephone Program Will Alert Doctors to Respiratory Viral Outbreaks
DOC.TEXT: The Centers for Disease Control announced a new program Friday that the agency hopes will help doctors hear about outbreaks of potentially fatal respiratory viruses sooner. The CDC is monitoring respiratory syncytial (RSV) and parainfluenza viruses - which cause a variety of often serious respiratory ailments, especially in young children. Previously, health officials had alerted the CDC of outbreaks by weekly postcards. Now, they will report the viruses by telephone, enabling the CDC to post the results on the national Public Health Network weekly. CDC epidemiologist James Alexander said the timeliness will help doctors and public health officials hear of outbreaks sooner, thus cutting down on the number of diagnostic tests ill children undergo and possibly helping doctors prevent spread of the virus. The study shows that RSV is most often found in January. RSV causes kinds of bronchial illnesses that can be fatal to infants or sickly children, and it hits almost every child by age 2. The CDC found that the two least serious types of parainfluenza, known as types 1 and 2 and which cause colds and croup, usually cause outbreaks every other fall, especially in November. Parainfluenza type 3 is more serious and causes types of bronchitis and pneumonia in infants and the elderly, which can be fatal. It is found year-round but the CDC study indicates it peaks in spring.

DOC.HEAD: Surveys Find Budget Deficits Loom In 30 States
DOC.TEXT: At least 30 states face budget deficits because of the rising cost of services, falling tax revenues and slackening consumer spending, according to surveys. The deficits range from $42 million in Tennessee to $1 billion in New York, according to studies by the National Association of State Budget Officers and The Boston Globe. ``It's unusual to have this many states in trouble when we're really just going into a recession,'' said Jerry Miller, head of the state budget group. ``The last time things were this bad, in 1982-83, we were already in a recession.'' The surveys concluded that the faltering economy has dampened business output, leading to a falloff in revenues from state business taxes. ``Corporate taxes are the most volatile and have fallen the greatest,'' said George Leung, head of state ratings at Moody's Investors Service. Leung said consumers have been buying less, leading to a dro in sales tax collections. ``Studies show consumer confidence has dropped to record lows,'' he said. The less consumers spend, the more businesses are likely to lay off workers. State governments also have trimmed their payrolls, including Massachusetts where up to 10,000 part- and full-time state jobs have been eliminated over the past two years. The surveys found that job losses, by both public and private employers, are adding to state spending, as unemployed workers sign up for state benefits and more families join the welfare rolls. Such layoffs have also depressed states' third major source of revenue: personal income taxes. Indications of economic hard times were papered over in some states to shield officeholders running for re-election, said Hal Hovey, editor of State Budget and Tax News. Hovey said that in Maine, for example, state officials falsely reassured voters that depressed revenues would increase after the election. Similarly, Michigan budget officials predicted spending on Medicaid would drop, Hovey said, ``when everyone else expects it to go up 10 to 20 percent.'' Miller agreed that ``a number of states were not totally candid until after the election.'' The federal government last year began requiring states to pay for expanded coverage for victims of catastrophic illness, nursing home residents and pregnant women. ``Just the new mandates in Medicaid cost more than the total revenue growth in a number of states, including New York, Rhode Island and Massachusetts,'' said Miller. Even many states where budgets remain in balance are worried. ``This year we're right on target, but it's looking like we may have slowed revenue growth so things will be pretty tight next year,'' said John Gasparith, New Mexico's budget director. These are the 30 states listed by the surveys, which did not provide complete deficit figures: Alabama, Arizona, California, Colorado, Connecticut, Delaware, Florida, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, Mississippi, Missouri, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, South Carolina, Tennessee, Texas, Vermont and Virginia.

DOC.HEAD: Attackers Kill Guard at Armenian Arms Depot
DOC.TEXT: Unidentified gunmen attacked a weapons depot in the Armenian capital of Yerevan, killing one guard and wounding another in an ensuing gunbattle, the Tass news agency said Friday. According to the regional border guard commander, Thursday night's assalt was the second attack this year on the arms and combat hardware depot. ``A group of approximately five to six criminals covertly approached the territory of the post and suddenly opened fire from automatic weapons from three directions simultaneously,'' the news agency quoted Gen. L. Vysotsky as saying. He said the depot was under the protection of border guard troops, a division of the KGB, when the gunmen attacked. ``The sentries took up defensive positions and repulsed the bandits' attempts to break through to the depot premises,'' Vysotsky said. ``When reinforcements arrived at the facility, the attackers fled, taking with them the submachine-gun of the killed border guard.'' Armenia and the neighboring southern republic of Azerbaijan have been locked in a three-year battle for control of Nagorno-Karabakh, a predominantly Armenian enclave inside Azerbaijan's borders. More than 220 people have died in the ethnic clashes. Militants in both republics have carried out raids on military installations and police stations in order to arm themselves. On Thursday, Tass reported that military reinforcements had been sent to the border region between the two republics to quell four days of ethnic-inspired shootings in which seven people were killed and nine wounded.

DOC.HEAD: Colonial Williamsburg, Seeking To Trim Costs, Offers Early Retirement
DOC.TEXT: The Colonial Williamsburg Foundation is trying to entice hundreds of employees to retire early to ease the impact of a 10 percent drop in visitors this year. Colonial Williamsburg officials said Wednesday that early retirement will be offered to 360 employees, about 8.6 percent of its total work force of 4,200. The early retirement program will not forestall the usual seasonal layoffs in January and February, the off-season at the restored colonial capital of Virginia, officials said. The incentive was offered to management as well as unionized and non-unionized employees. Colonial Williamsburg spokesman Albert O. Louer said savings from the plan should be about $1 million. The plan was offered Nov. 13 to employees who are at least 55 years old and have at least 10 years of service with the non-profit foundation. Eligible employees have until Dec. 19 to decide on whether to join. Among the incentives for early retirement are a boost in pension benefits, and continuation of health and life insurance until the retiree reaches 65. The tourist attraction, which features craftsmen and others in period costume portraying colonial life, had 1.17 million visitors last year. Spokesman Jim Bradley said they expect at least 1 million visitors this year.

DOC.HEAD: Students Warned Pen Pal Soldiers Could Die
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A teacher who started a pen pal program with soldiers in the Persian Gulf wants his students to brace themselves for the worst - that their new friends could die in battle. ``At first it was an assignment,'' said Dan Copen, a 14-year-old student at Valley Middle School. ``But when we got the letters back, we're thinking, `I have a friend over there.' ``Now, I'll watch a good football game and think, `Ah, that is something Barry would like to see,'' the eighth-grader said of his pen pal, a U.S. Marine stationed in Saudi Arabia as part of Operation Desert Shield. Todd Beach, a 25-year-old teacher and wrestling coach at Valley Middle School in this Twin Cities suburbsaid he decided to put his seventh and eighth grade students in touch with the soldiers because he was frustrated. ``The kids were thinking: `Things are swell. The world is safe,'' he said. Meanwhile, events in the Persian Gulf were being compared to events preceding World War II, and Saddam Hussein was being compared to Hitler. ``It wasn't hitting them,'' said Beach. ``They couldn't comprehend or understand what a huge, huge thing this is historically.'' But Beach is concerned about the budding friendships. ``I do need to tell you some things,'' he told his classes last week. Reports that U.S. troops are moving closer to the Kuwaiti border suggest the possibility of military action against Iraq, he told them. ``You have to realize that things are changing very quickly there. You need to prepare yourselves,'' he said gently, ``that there is a great possibility that the people you are writing to might die.'' About 150 students have written to soldiers in the Persian Gulf and some have also written to Hussein and President Bush. ``In the beginning, I was 100 percent behind you in your decision,'' Copen wrote in a letter to Bush last week. ``I did not know anyone who was sent over there. But, just a few months ago I started to write to a soldier named Barry. And all he talks about is coming back home, and how afraid he is of not coming home.''

DOC.HEAD: Abortions Increase 1 Percent
DOC.TEXT: There was a slight increase in the number of abortions performed in the United States, the Centers for Disease Control reported Friday. The CDC said 17,614 more abortions were performed in 1988 than in the preceding year, an increase of 1.3 percent. In 1988, 1,371,285 abortions were reported and in 1987 there were 1,353,671 abortions, according to the CDC. But the national ratio - the number of abortions per 1,000 live births - dropped from 356 to 352. The characteristics of women having abortions also remained the same, epidemiologist Lisa Koonin said. About 92 percent of the women were residents of the state in which the procedure was performed. They were predominately younger than 25, white, unmarried and had no other children. About half the abortions were performed in the first eight weeks and 88 percent within the first trimester. Curettage, a suction and scrape method, accounted for 97 percent of the abortions.

DOC.HEAD: Radical Students Battle Police in Protest Over Trade
DOC.TEXT: Radical students fought riot police with firebombs and rocks in a demonstration Friday demanding an end to U.S. pressure to open Korean trade and agriculture markets. As anger over trade issues increased, the nation's major dissident and radical student organizations announced nationwide protests to be held Sunday. Police said illegal protests would be blocked and security would be tightened around U.S. facilities. ``I admit we have not made enough effort to remove misunderstanding,'' Deputy Premier Lee Seung-yun told reporters Friday. Lee, also the economic planning minister, said the government would try to resolve trade dispuates with foreign governments, especially Washington. He said if foreign distrust of Korean external economic policies increase ``trade friction is bound to expand and is feared to greatly affect the operation of our economy.'' About 4,000 students at 16 universities in Seoul staged rallies and battled riot police Friday to demand an end to U.S. pressure that Korea open its markets, news reports said. An additional 400 students clashed with police in southern Kwangju city, reports said. ``Drive out Yankees who force (trade) negotiations!'' yelled about 200 students hurling firebombs and rocks at Seoul's Yonsei University. ``Oust Roh!'' they chanted. At Seoul's Sogang University, 500 students clashed violently with police for more than an hour outside the campus. Students hurled hundreds of rocks and firebombs and police fired volleys of choking tear gas from four black armored vans. There were no reports of arrests or injuries. Opposition leader Kim Dae-jung told lawmakers the nation would face major unrest unless Roh halts ``suppressive rule'' using security organizations to crackdown on dissidents, workers and students. Kim also said the country should ``sternly cope with America's unrealistic pressure to open its markets, especially farm products.'' It was Kim's first speech to the National Assembly since his group, the Party for Peace and Democracy, ended a four-month boycott and returned to the legislature on Monday. All 78 opposition legislators offered to resign en masse from the 299-member parliament in July, charging the ruling party with railroading bills and reneging on democratic reforms. Also on Friday, conservative Catholic bishops issued a rare political statement demanding release of imprisoned dissidents, including those jailed for making illegal trips to Communist North Korea. The opposition claims there are 1,500 political prisoners, a charge denied by the government. Dissident and farmers have staged violent anti-government and anti-American protests, denouncing U.S. pressure on South Korea to open its agricultural markets wider. South Korean consumer and civil groups have threatened to launch a nationwide boycott against U.S. goods, saying anti-American sentiment is escalating because of U.S. trade pressure. Earlier this week, U.S. Ambassador Donald Gregg said negative views of America have become widespread in South Korea, threatening to poison economic and political relations between the two countries.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Meeting With Syria's Assad, Says Nearing Agreement on U.N. Resolution
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS three grafs after 7th graf prvs ```I think...' with Soviet saying Security Council to meet next week
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today sought to solidify the Arab coalition against Iraq's Saddam Hussein, getting fresh assurances from Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak and then flying here to consult with Syria's Hafez Assad. Assad's Syrian Arab Airlines Boing 747 touched down three hours before Air Force One. Speaking through an interpreter, Assad told reporters, ``We have the hope there will be between us convergent viewpoints.'' Bush and Assad planned two hours of talks. The session has proved controversial because Syria is on a State Department list of countries that sponsor terrorism. At a photo session with Bush before the meetin, Assad shrugged off a question about whether Syrian forces would join any military offense against Iraq. ``Do you think at such a large press conference that we speak about offensive or defensive operations?'' he said. Bush, tight-lipped and largely unsmiling as he joined Assad, refused to answer reporters' questions. The two leaders sat in chairs some distance apart. Before leaving Cairo, Egypt, Bush declared that ``the world is getting tired'' of Iraq's continuing occupation of Kuwait and said he was closing in on agreement for a U.N. resolution authorizing the use of force in the Persian Gulf crisis. ``I think we're very, very close now,'' said Bush, fresh from a Thanksgiving Day visit with U.S. troops in the Persian Gulf. In New York, Soviet Ambassador to the United Nations Yuliy M. Vorontsov said the U.N. Security Council will meet next week, with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze attending. Secretary of State James A. Baker III will also be in New York next week. Vorontsov said the meeting will discuss Iraqi aggression and to issue a ``strong, serious and precise warning'' to Baghdad. British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said Friday that the council may meet next week to consider a draft resolution authorizing the use of force. Geneva was the final stop of Bush's week-long overseas journey. It also was the site of his controversial meeting with Assad, whose nation is on a State Department list of nations that sponsor terrorism. Bush defended his decision to meet with Assad, whom he said ``is lined up with us for a commitment to force.'' He said the international coalition demanding Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait ``will not rest'' until Saddam pulls his forces out. ``So-called partial solutions are out of the question,'' he said. Mubarak's declarations sounded identical. ``The Iraqi invasion must be reversed and Kuwait must be liberated,'' the Egyptian leader said. ``For both of us it's a matter of principles and moral courage.'' At the same time, Mubarak used the news conference to call for an overall settlement to intractable Arab-Israeli disagreements. He urged a greater international effort to deal with the ``plight of the Palestinian people.'' He added. ``The holy shrines of Jerusalem must be respected and protected.'' Bush said the United States is eager for an overall Middle Eastern peace agreement. But, he swiftly added, ``What I am equally determined to do is to keep these two questions separate. There is no linkage'' to the Kuwaiti occupation, he said. The United States currently has an estimated 230,000 troops in the Persian Gulf region, and another 200,000 or more are on their way. Bush spoke with reporters as congressional leaders returning from Saudi Arabia said the president would have a far better chance of getting House and Senate support for the use of force if the United Nations first backed such a move. ``It would have some significant impact if the United Nations granted such a resolution,'' said House Speaker Thomas Foley. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell said a U.N. resolution would improve Bush's chances but not necessarily guarantee congressional approval if the president sought it. Senate GOP leader Bob Dole said he would urge Congress to reconvene immediately if the United Nations endorsed force to free Kuwait from Iraqi occupation. ``Then I would hope Congress would reconvene and take similar action,'' Dole said. Bush's authority has been challenged by 45 House Democrats who filed a suit in federal court earlier this month seeking to bar him from ordering an attack without congressional approval. Bush, whose voyage took him to a 34-nation European summit conference as well as to the Middle East, is mounting an energetic diplomatic campaign to round up support for a U.N. Security Council resolution permitting the use of force to dislodge Saddam's army from Kuwait. Secretary of State James A. Baker III traveled to Yemen on Thursday as part of that effort, but was rebuffed. Yemen sits on the Security Council and will take over the rotating chairmanship from the United States at the end of the month. Baker is headed for Colombia on Saturday for additional meetings with another Security Council member. Bush, when asked about the status of a U.N. resolution, said he believes he has the authority necessary to act without United Nations concurrence. He added, however, ``I am confident that we will be successful in the Security Council. The world is getting tired of this, and the Security Council is tired of the fact'' that earlier resolutions have been ignored. ``But we're going to keep working on it and I think we're very, very close now,'' he said. Bush also defended his decision to meet with Syria's president, brushing aside a question of whether he was rewarding terrorism by meeting with the leader of a nation that is on the State Department roster of nations that sponsor terrorism. ``They're on the front line'' of standing up to Saddam, Bush said. He quickly added, ``that doesn't mean we have no differences with Syria,'' and said he would be discussing those subjects with Assad. ``Mr. Assad is lined up with us for a commitment to force,'' Bush said. Bush's day trip to three continents - he was ending up at Camp David, Md. - marked the end of an overseas journey that seemed to span two eras. He began his trip in Europe, where he participated in signing ceremonies for a treaty to cut conventional forces in Europe and attended a conference that symbolically buried the Cold War. The emotional highpoint of the trip was the holiday spent visiting U.S. and British forces in the Persian Gulf. ``We won't pull punches,'' Bush promised troops in Saudi Arabia. Bush was in high spirits Thursday after hop-scotching by helicopter across eastern Saudi Arabia to spend Thanksgiving with troops who someday may be ordered to war to drive Iraq out of Kuwait. The president, accompanied by his wife Barbara, came within 65 miles of the border with Kuwait, stopping at an encampment for U.S. Marines. Bush called it ``an unforgettable experience.'' It was a scene of endless desert, marked only by clumps of camouflage netting that concealed combat vehicles and other equipment. Altogether, the president saw about 5,000 to 6,000 of the 230,000 American troops in the Persian Gulf. ``We are not here on some exercise,'' Bush said. ``And we're not walking away until our mission is done, until the invader is out of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Warns that Break-up of Soviet Union Could Lead to Bloodshed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to CORRECT lead and quote to `civil conflict' stead `civil war'; No pickup
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Soviet-Politics
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev warned today that a breakup of the Soviet Union could lead to ``bloodshed and civil conflict,'' and said he would use all his constitutional powers to prevent it. ``We will not be able to divide. When such attempts have been made, the results were bloodshed and grave consequences,'' Gorbachev said in a news conference. He spoke hours after the Supreme Soviet legislature for the second time in a week endorsed his plans to reorganize the presidential branch of government, and gave him two weeks to take radical steps to boost the food supply. Gorbachev offered few details on his proposals to improve the food situation, other than saying he had secured promises of Western aid, and planned to suggest changes in laws covering agriculture and landholding. He said the latest draft of a proposed Union Treaty would be published Saturday. The treaty is designed as a new charter binding the 15 Soviet republics. All but one of have declared some form of sovereignty, and the three Baltic republics have declared independence. Gorbachev said that those republics wishing to leave the union must hold a referendum, as required by Soviet law, and that as president he would oppose any other form of dissolution of the union. ``If someone tried to impose such a policy, it would result in bloodshed and civil conflict, which would be unacceptable to the world community,'' he said. Asked to specify what steps he would take to prevent a republic from leaving the union, Gorbachev said ``we will stay within the constitution.'' ``It is a whole divorce procedure,'' he said, referring to the law requiring a referendum in any republic wishing to secede. ``In this way, it will be bloodless.''

DOC.HEAD: Three Candidates Begin Campaign To Succeed Thatcher
LaserPhotos LON2,3,5
DOC.TEXT: A welfare recipient turned banker, a self-made millionaire and an old Etonian began the battle on Friday to succeed Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. All promised to be less combative than Mrs. Thatcher toward Europe, just as tough toward Iraq and willing to do something about her unpopular local services tax, heralding a five-day campaign that seemed more about a prize than a battle over policy. ``We can only get ourselves out of the mess by rallying everybody, by healing the wounds,'' said one candidate, Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd. Hurd and Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major joined the race Friday. They must stop former Defense Secretary Michael Heseltine, whose strong showing in the first round of voting Tuesday provoked Mrs. Thatcher's resignation. She spent the day in her office at 10 Downing Street ``running the country,'' her son Mark said. Mrs. Thatcher gave no hint of which candidate she favored, although it certainly wasn't Heseltine. Major, 47, left school at 16 and worked his way up from laborer and welfare recipient to banker, and then went into politics. He is regarded as on the right of the party and therefore closest politically to Mrs. Thatcher. Hurd, 60, was educated at the upper-class preparatory school Eton and Oxford and generally more liberal in Tory terms. Heseltine, 57, also Oxford-educated, is a self-made millionaire who resigned from the Cabinet in 1986 after a sharp disagreement with Mrs. Thatcher about the sale of a British defense contractor. Mrs. Thatcher decided to quit Thursday after Cabinet ministers and her campaign manager told her she would lose to Heseltine in the second ballot next Tuesday. The vote among the 372 Conservative members of Parliament will go to a third and final ballot next Thursday if no one gets a simple majority of 187 or more on Tuesday. Hurd and Major pledged at their campaign kickoffs to review the nation' so-called poll tax, an unpopular per capita local government tax imposed regardless of income and regarded as a major political blunder of the Thatcher era. ``I do become increasingly convinced that we cannot leave things as they are,'' Major said. Heseltine declared that an immediate and fundamental review of the tax ``is essential for our survival.'' Hurd and Major, who support Mrs. Thatcher's rejection of a single currency for the European Community, each promised - in the closest to open criticism of her so far - to adopt a markedly different tone in Europe and in Cabinet meetings. ``I think that Cabinet government consists of listening, deciding, persuading (voters) in that order,'' Hurd said. ``You listen to views, you take a decision - in our case collectively in Cabinet.'' Hurd maintained he'd be the best prime minister for the Persian Gulf crisis. Mrs. Thatcher has been the most enthusiastic Western supporter of the U.S. troop buildup in the region. Her Cabinet decided Wednesday to send 14,000 more troops to the gulf, bringing the British total to 30,000. ``The crisis is entering a crucial, critical phase ... and will require cool and authoritative handling,'' Hurd said. On the poll tax issue, Heseltine has the advantage of having left the Cabinet before it was imposed. However, he is regarded as something of a maverick who does not fit wholly into the party's left or right, and he has stirred deep anger among some Thatcher loyalists for bringing her down. ``It's not been a pleasant thing to do,'' Heseltine said. ``But now that it has happened, the mood of unity has overwhelmed the party.''
