David Robertson, a fellow in politics at Oxford University, said the reluctance by Hurd, Heseltine and Major to adopt markedly different policy platforms reflected the ``old American political notion of a balanced ticket.'' ``All three of the current candidates, rather than advancing serious general ideologies, are doing their damndest to hide them,'' Robertson said in a BBC radio interview. He predicted the party was returning to pragmatism, ``a sort of non-ism,'' after nearly 12 years of Thatcherism. Mrs. Thatcher spent part of Friday on the telephone, talking to foreign leaders calling to say goodbye and good luck to the Western world's longest-serving head of government. Her husband, Denis, and 35-year-old twins, Mark and Carol Thatcher, spent part of the day with her. ``She's doing what she always does on a Friday, running the country,'' Mark Thatcher, an auto executive who lives in Dallas, Texas, told reporters after visiting his mother. Bookmakers made Major and Heseltine near-equal favorites to win. A Market and Opinion and Research International poll for the Times of London suggested the Tories, who have lagged in opinion polls for 16 months, would defeat the opposition Labor Party under Heseltine or Major, but lose under Hurd.

DOC.HEAD: Cocaine Found in Blood of 6 Percent of Child Patients
DOC.TEXT: A study has found that 6 percent of young children treated at a Detroit hospital had cocaine in their systems, fueling concern that secondhand drug smoke harms infants, officials say. Dr. Norman Rosenberg, chief of emergency medical services at Children's Hospital of Michigan, said his findings may be the first effort to determine the rate of children's exposure to smoke from crack, the highly addictive, smokable form of cocaine. ``Nothing official has ever been published,'' he said. ``Everyone I have talked to says it (evidence of exposure) is extraordinarily high.'' Since October 1989, evidence of cocaine exposure has been found in the urine of about 6 percent of 360 children treated in the hospital's emergency room. An additional 120 samples have yet to be analyzed. The study includes children from 1 month to 5 years old who were taken to the hospital with non-life-threatening ailments. None had been breast-fed, and any cocaine from exposure in the womb would have dissipated from their blood by the time they were 1 month old. Rosenberg said youngsters who tested positive had to have been exposed to crack smoke within three days because cocaine passes through the body within 72 hours. Children were excluded from the study if they had symptoms such as seizures, hypertension and rapid pulse, which suggest they may have eaten the drug, Rosenberg said. ``It's a very sad commentary for the quality of life for children in this state,'' said C. Patrick Babcock, director of the Michigan Department of Social Services. ``Every day, there is a new phenomenon because crack is so widespread and such a cheap high.'' Elizabeth Rahdert, a research psychologist at the National Institute on Drug Abuse, said Rosenberg's results seem clinically significant. She said the finding is disturbing because it may only reflect the tip of the iceberg since crack addicts may be less likely to seek medical care for their children. Doctors in several U.S. cities have reported that babies exposed to crack smoke had seizures, were abnormally drowsy or couldn't stand up. A 1989 study published in the American Journal of Diseases of Children examined the cases of four children from 3 months to 4 years old in New York City's Harlem section who were heavily exposed to crack smoke. Each had symptoms of drowsiness and unsteady gait or seizures.

DOC.HEAD: Security Council May Meet Soon; Iraq Calls Up Veteran Reservists
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 18 grafs to UPDATE with Soviet ambassador saying Shevardnadze will attend Security Council meeting, Assad comment. Pick up 15th graf pvs, `The U.S....'; ADDS 2 grafs atend on British captives and European report on coordination of multinatinal forces.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos CAI1,2,3,15; DHA2,3
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Friday he was confident the U.N. Security Council would authorize the use of force against Iraq, and Britain's foreign secretary said the council probably would meet next week to take up the matter. Iraq, underscoring its readiness to fight to keep Kuwait, began calling up battle-hardened military reservists on Friday. It also lifted a curfew in the conquered emirate, insisting ``normal life'' is resuming - and implying that the Kuwaiti resistance has been beaten down. The United States made an ``urgent'' appeal to its NATO allies to help ferry U.S. soldiers and equipment to the Persian Gulf region, officials said. There are about 230,000 American troops in the gulf region now; 200,000 more are to arrive in coming weeks. Word that the Security Council would convene soon to consider the use-of-force measure came from Douglas Hurd, Britain's foreign secretary. ``Soon, probably next week, the Security Council will consider a draft resolution authorizing member states to use force to bring about the reversal of the Iraqi aggression,'' he told reporters in London. Iraq overran Kuwait Aug. 2 in a dispute over land, money and oil. The Soviet ambassador to the United Nations also said the Security Council would meet next week to discuss Iraqi aggression, but did not specify whether the resolution authorizing force would be discussed. But the envoy, Yuliy M. Vorontsov, said Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze would attend the session. Shevardnadze held talks Friday with his Chinese counterpart, Qian Qichen, in the Chinese city of Urumqi. Both China and the Soviet Union have urged Iraq to get out of Kuwait, but both have stressed the need for a peaceful solution. Hurd's comment was the first indication that enough support for the use-of-force measure had been gathered to call the meeting before the end of the month. The urgency is due in large part to the fact that Yemen, which has tilted toward Iraq in the past, takes over the rotating chairmanship of the Security Council from the United States in December. Secretary of State James A. Baker III was in the small Red Sea nation on Thursday seeking support for the resolution, but failed to get it. Yemen is the only Arab state on the Security Council. Baker will continue his intensive lobbying effort on the measure during the weekend. He is to meet Saturday with senior officials in Colombia and hold talks in Los Angeles with officials from Malaysia. Both are Security Council members. Bush, too, has been working hard to build support for the resolution. He conferred Friday in Cairo with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, which has been a chief Arab ally in the anti-Iraq coalition. Afterward, Bush said: ``I am confident that we will be successful in the Security Council.'' Later, Bush arrived in Geneva, Switzerland, for talks with Syrian President Hafez Assad. Some congressional leaders have expressed concern about the meeting because Syria is on a State Department list of countries that sponsor terrorism. But Bush defended his dealings with Assad, saying the Syrian president is ``lined up with us for a commitment to force.'' Before the meeting, Assad declined to tell reporters whether Syria would participate in any military offensive against Iraq. The U.S. pitch for help from North Atlantic Treaty Organization members in ferrying troops to the gulf was made by NATO envoy William H. Taft IV at the Brussels headquarters of the alliance, officials said. European allies have already provided some troop-transport assistance, but the ew request centered on the need for passenger planes, said a U.S. official at the NATO mission, speaking on condition of anonymity. The latest Iraqi call-up, announced in a defense ministry communique broadcast on Baghdad radio, involves reservists in their 30s, including battle-tested veterans of the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war. They apparently will be among 150,000 reservists and draftees that Iraq said earlier this week would be sent to Kuwait, along with about 100,000 other regular army troops. Also Friday, Iraq's official news agency said it was canceling an overnight curfew in Kuwait because the emirate is calmer now. The news agency, monitored in Nicosia, CYprus, said the move was meant to ``confirm the return of normal life'' to Kuwait, which Iraq has declared to be an Iraqi province. In other developments: -Western European lawmakers warned in a report that the multinational force in the gulf region risks dangerous mix-ups if coordination is not improved. It said procedures for identifying the nationality of warships and planes must be modified ``to assure the safety of friendly forces.'' The report is to be discussed next month by representatives of the West European Union, the European arm of NATO. -Iraqi authorities rounded up five British men who had been in hiding in Kuwait since the Iraqi invasion, Britain's Foreign Office said Friday. The government estimates that 750 British citizens remain in Iraq, about 300 of whom are being detained a key military sites. Less than 600 Britons remain in Kuwait, about 60 of whom are being detained.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Spies Continue to Operate in Germany
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet KGB has stepped up its espionage activities in Germany despite the new era of East-West friendship, a spokesman for Bonn's counterintelligence agency said Friday. While political leaders hail the Cold War's end, Soviet spies continue to search for German defense secrets, desperately needed technological know-how and political information. ``It's cheaper to use the help of a spy agency to get the know-how than to buy it,'' said Hans-Gert Lange, spokesman for the German counterintelligence agency. About 400 Soviet spies are working in former East Berlin, according to one leading newspaper. In years past, Communist East Germany employed up to 8,000 spies to keep tabs on West Germany, and then passed on the information to its Warsaw Pact allies in Moscow. That changed after the peaceful revolution in East Germany a year ago led to the unification with NATO member West Germany. ``The intensification is due to the fact that they (the Soviets) have to do more on account of the information deficit, and they are doing it,'' Lange said. He is the spokesman for the Constitutional Protection Office, the government branch in charge of fighting foreign espionage agents Lange said the political upheaval that shook East Germany made the Kremlin even more eager to get intelligence information. More Soviet agents are slipping into Germany, Lange said, although he did not have a specific number of KGB spies operating in the unified nation. Lange said the Soviets are trying to recruit former East German agents. ``There has always been spying and there always will be spying,'' he added. By law the spies should be rounded up and prosecuted, but the Berliner Morgenpost newspaper said German authorities for the most part are reluctant to make arrests because of the improved ties with the Soviet Union. The newspaper said at least 400 KGB agents were still operating in what used to be East Berlin. The paper said the information came from former East German secret police agents cooperating with German authorities since unificaiton on Oct. 3. German officials are hoping the Soviets will withdraw their spies on their own initiative, the paper said. The Nov. 5 arrest of a KGB major in Potsdam, near Berlin, was a ``warning signal'' to the Soviets, the paper added. A government spokesman said Friday night he had not read the article and therefore could not comment directly on it. But the official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said spies would be arrested if caught, ``regardless of which country'' they worked for.

DOC.HEAD: Man Fires Shotgun More Than 70 Times Inside House
DOC.TEXT: A man wrecked his house with more than 70 shotgun blasts during a four-hour standoff with police early Friday before surrendering peacefully, police said. ``There were holes everywhere - totally ventilated,'' said police Sgt. Pat Findley. ``He just said he was shooting through his house and he couldn't see any reason why he couldn't do it.'' Roy Koutsky, 25, was booked for investigation of reckless shooting, said Findley. No one was injured and police never returned his fire. Most of the shots were fired through the house's back wall. Police called to Koutsky's Hollywood home by neighbors evacuated two houses and an adjacent apartment building and a special weapons and tactics platoon surrounded the house, Findley said. After Koutsky surrendered, officers counted 73 shell casings on the floor of the house, Findley said. Some pellets hit duplexes behind Koutsky's house, but there was no other apparent damage to other buildings. Officers confiscated a large quantity of ammunition, a shotgun, a sword and a toy pistol, Findley said.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Fans Handcuff Themselves to Railings
With AM-Britain-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: At least two of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's loyal fans on Friday found it hard to let go of the woman who quit after 11{ years in power. Jean Rogers and Mark Kingscote from the Torbay Conservative Association handcuffed themselves to railings outside the home of Michael Heseltine to protest his ``betrayal'' of their beloved Mrs. Thatcher. Heseltine's challenge to Mrs. Thatcher for the Conservative Party leadership led to her resignation on Thursday. Mrs. Rogers and Kingscote said he had ``stabbed her in the back.'' ``We have been faithful,'' said Mrs. Rogers, who described herself as a housewife. ``We are disgusted about what has happened.'' Mrs. Rogers and Kingscote, 29, who works in a jeweler's shop, also were angry with Nigel Lawson, Edward Heath, Sir Geoffrey Howe and the Conservative members of Parliament who voted against Mrs. Thatcher in the first round of the leadership battle. The couple carried a placard which read: ``Maggie made us great, you have destroyed us.'' They said they were part of a group of 40 faithful Thatcher supporters who had traveled from Devon to register their anger. ``We would have liked Maggie to stay on,'' Mrs. Rogers said. ``The only time I thought she would leave Number 10 was in a coffin. I feel like I am in mourning.'' After 10 minutes, the pair freed themselves and told reporters they were heading to Downing Street to continue their pro-Thatcher protest.

DOC.HEAD: Government Appears To Welcome Drug Cartel's Offer To Surrender
DOC.TEXT: A senior Colombian judicial official said Friday the government wanted to clear the way for drug traffickers to surrender peacefully. The traffickers have proposed that hundreds of them gather to surrender in a heavily fortified compound protected by the army. The judicial official, Carlos Mejia, appeared to endorse the idea in a radio interview Friday. ``We would guarantee the personal security of these persons, as well as protect their legal rights, giving them decent and dignified treatment,'' said Mejia, national director of Colombia's Criminal Court Division. The drug smugglers have not said if the offer to surrender applied to Pablo Escobar, the Medellin cartel's leader. Escobar, Colombia's most wanted man, remains at large despite a government offer to pay $500,000 for information leading to his capture, dead or alive. The surrender offer came in a statement given to President Cesar Gaviria by a group of church leaders who have been negotiating the release of nine journalists being held hostage by the cartel. The president's office released the statement late Thursday. In exchange for giving themselves up, the druglords demanded guarantees of safety and a promise not to send them to the United States. On Friday, the traffickers declared a unilateral cease-fire in their terrorist attacks, their third such truce this year. Thursday's statement said between 200 and 300 cocaine smugglers would be willing to surrender in a compound protected by the army and police. The statement did not mention the fate of the journalists. But the Medellin cartel issued a communique Friday saying the journalists ``will be released as long as our human rights and those of our families are respected.'' Earlier, the cartel said it kidnapped the journalists because police were torturing and killing trafficking suspects in Medellin, Colombia's second-largest city. In Friday's statement, the cartel said it was declaring a cease-fire so that ``the people can go to the polls freely'' in a national election next month. Voters will elect a national assembly to reform the country's constitution. The Medellin cartel has been blamed for killing about 550 Colombians since the government and traffickers declared war on each other after a political assassination in August 1989. The traffickers' offer to surrender raised hopes that the drug war would end soon. Justice Minister Jaime Giraldo on Thursday outlined guarantees for cocaine smugglers who surrender. In a letter to the Criminal Court Division, he said traffickers would be kept in clean, well-guarded facilities. Giraldo said surrendering traffickers ``can be sure they will not be extradited.'' Many of the cartel's killings have been to protest extraditions to the United States. In statements to the media, the cartel refers to itself as ``The Extraditables.'' In September, Gaviria had offered to ban extraditions and reduce jail sentences of cocaine traffickers who surrendered and confessed. The traffickers said they would expect, upon surrendering, that their treatment be monitored by international human rights organizations. In Thursday's statement, they said they do not deserve to be treated like common criminals.

DOC.HEAD: Two Men Sought In Assault on Autistic Patients
DOC.TEXT: Two counselors who set out to ``get revenge'' against two autistic men after a scuffle were accused of beating and burning them with cigarettes, police said. ``It's pathetic when you think that people who are put in charge of these people would assault them in any way,'' said Detective Michael Fiori. Arrest warrants were issued Wednesday for Charles Blakney, 26, and Marvin Hill, 33, for investigation of the burning and beatings. On Friday, the two Denver men had not been arrested, Fiori said. Blakney and Hill were counselors for the Denver Board for the Developmentally Disabled and make up part of the victims' round-the-clock care. On Oct. 3, Fiori said, a 32-year-old autistic man became distraught and began destroying his apartment, which he shares with the other victim. At some point in the disturbance, he slapped a counselor with an open hand. ``That's what caused the counselor to decide he was going to get revenge,'' Fiori said. A day and a half later, the counselors allegedly assaulted him, Fiori said. One of the assailants told another counselor that ``they hit him about the stomach and chest area so as not to show any bruises,'' Fiori said. ``One victim was also burned with a cigarette on his forearm,'' Fiori said. ``This had been confirmed by a doctor. There was one other client out there who was also burned with a cigarette on his stomach.'' Blakney and Hill, who are black, were placed on leave when the assaults came to light in late October. They have since filed complaints with the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, Fiori said. The complaints say the move to place them on leave was racially motivated, he said. Neither victim is able to help in the prosecution. But there was a witness to one of the assaults and evidence in both cases, Fiori said. ``I don't have any comment on the personnel issue,'' said Gene Van Blaricom, acting executive director of the board. Because of confidentiality laws, he said, he was unable to comment on the discrimination complaint.

DOC.HEAD: Jewelry Sales Raise Fortune for Homeless
DOC.TEXT: An artist's sales of inexpensive jewelry in the shape of houses have raised nearly $300,000 to benefit the homeless in 38 states. The jewelry designed by Lucinda L. Yates is available from retail stores and non-profit groups. Under an agreement with her, all of the outlets donate 40 percent of the $10 price to community shelters. Ms. Yates, who previously created high-fashion jewelry, said she devised the idea for house pins after failing to find volunteer work in the community. ``I wanted to get involved in some capacity, other than working in a soup kitchen. And here I was offering my services but I was getting little or no response,'' she said. The colorful cardboard brooches caught the imagination of local residents. And when the president of the Women's Council of Realtors in Portland took some of the pins to its national convention in Florida, sales started to spread to other states. The business gained wider attention when other national groups, including foundations and a college sorority, joined the cause. ``When I wear a house pin, I get stopped by people in the streets, wanting to know where I got it,'' said Sister Eileen Reilly of St. Mary's Catholic Church in Richmond, Va. So far, 80,000 pins - each one slightly different - have been sold. In the past three weeks, the company Ms. Yates created to manufacture the brooches has been getting 1,000 new orders a day, she said. Ms. Yates, her family and several friends make the pins at her South Portland office. She also employs several home-based workers for a total work force of 25 people. The 35-year-old Portland native said she is just as surprised as anyone at the popularity of her pins. ``Pretty soon we'll have to have 18-wheelers come in here to pick up all the orders,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Germany Says Soviets Need Food Help, Will Lend Hand
With AM-Soviet-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Germany on Friday rejected U.S. claims that the Soviet Union has sufficient food supplies this year, and said it will send experts to Moscow next week to try to resolve distribution problems. There have been dire predictions of what the winter holds in store for the Soviet people and fears that food shortages could worsen long-standing tensions and lead to widespread civil unrest. In a meeting with reporters Friday, government spokesman Dieter Vogel underscored Bonn's view that food shipments and other aid to Moscow this year were absolutely essential. ``According to our knowledge, delivery of foodstuffs is unfortunately necessary, because although there was an average, a reasonably good harvest in the Soviet Union, the logistics there contain so many complications that the supply is obviously insufficient,'' Vogel said. U.S. officials in Washington say there is no evidence of widespread hunger in the Soviet Union, one of the world's biggest grain growers, and that a food aid program shouldn't be necessary this year. ``Clearly, it's mostly a political consideration, not a nutritional or an economic consideration,'' one U.S. source said on condition of anonymity. ``The Germans offering food aid put some pressure on the rest of us to show the same kind of concern, but it's exasperating because it's their (the Soviets') problem to solve, and they're not taking the necessary steps.'' Vogel noted that the Soviets have always said their biggest problem was getting the goods to their people. Hundreds of German trains bound for the Soviet Union are stuck at the German-Polish and Polish-Soviet borders because the Soviets are unable to unload the goods and ship them to their destination. A team of German foreign ministry, economic, agricultural and transportation officials, under the leadership of Horst Teltschick, Chancellor Helmut Kohl's top aide, will be in Moscow on Tuesday and Wednesday for talks on the matter, Vogel said. Kohl told Parliament the group would meet with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and other Soviet officials. Bonn has already promised $19.5 billion in various forms of aid to the Soviet Union. Berliners have said they want to send stockpiles they kept during the Cold War, in the event of a Soviet invasion, to help their former enemies. Vogel said the delegation would discuss the Berlin stockpiles, but that how much could be sent would be left to the Bonn ministries to decide. Kohl has made help for the Soviet Union a major theme in recent speeches and meetings with world leaders, particularly at this week's 34-nation summit on security in Europe. His argument is that only with a stable Soviet Union can the old East bloc continue with its reforms.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Army Halts Discharges to Assure Gulf Troop Strength
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of soldiers who had planned to retire or leave the service at the end of their enlistments will be forced to stay in uniform, the Army said today. The troops may be needed for Operation Desert Shield, the Army said. The Army also said it was freezing all transfers of soldiers from overseas to bases in the United States, and that all training centers and military schools will be kept open during the customary two-week Christmas vacation period. The Army-wide halt to releasing officers and enlisted men and woman personnel was approved today by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. Details were to be announced later. The combination of measures is designed to keep the Army at the highest possible state of readiness in case additional reinforcements are needed in the Persian Gulf crisis, officials said. Also today, the Marine Corps disclosed that it invoked a measure on Nov. 8 that means as many as 12,000 Marines, both regular and reserve, could be prevented from leaving the service even though they were due to retire or finish serving their obligations. On Aug. 22 President Bush gave Cheney authority to retain members of the armed forces on duty in the gulf who reach their retirement or re-enlistment dates.
DOC.HEAD: Capt. Barbara, 6th graf
Homeland Military Leader Says South Africa Backed Coup Attempt
DOC.TEXT: The military leader of the Transkei black homeland on Friday accused the South African government of backing a coup attempt by rebel troops that left 18 people dead. Maj. Gen. Bantu Holomisa told a news conference that the government allowed rebels to use South African territory to mount the attack. He said the coup bid ``vindicates accusations that South Africa destabilizes government that it does not like.'' The South African government denied any involvement in the failed coup. Holomisa's troops Friday displayed in Umtata the bodies of rebel leader Lt. Col. Craig Duli and 10 other insurgents killed in the fighting. Seven loyalist soldiers were killed, officials said. Holomisa denied reports that Duli had been executed after he was captured. He said the rebel leader was wounded in the fighting and died on the way to the hospital. Witnesses said Duli was carried alive but wounded from a government building and put in the trunk of a car after spectators tried to attack him. Holomisa also denied South African press reports that five whites involved in the coup attempt had been arrested. According to various reports from Transkei, rebels firing mortars attacked an army base on the outskirts of Umtata early Thursday, but were driven off by loyal troops. The rebels then headed for the center of the city and holed up in Holomisa's office in the main government building. Press reports said the airport in Umtata came under heavy mortar fire and that terrified civilians tried to flee the city. Telephone lines were cut after the initial attacks. Duli helped Holomisa seize power in a bloodless coup on Dec. 30, 1987, that ousted Prime Minister Stella Sigcau. At the time, Duli was the military intelligence chief. Holomisa apointed him to the ruling military council that was set up to run the homeland, but Duli resigned in April 1989 after disagreements. He was detained shortly afterward on suspicion of engaging in activities that threatened state security and was held until December 1989. Duli was arrested again in April on charges of illegal possession of firearms and ammunition and was sentenced to six years in prison. He was free on bail, pending appeal, when he launched the coup attempt. Transkei is one of four black homelands declared independent by the South African government but not recognized as such by any other nation. The South African leadership set up the homelands in the 1970s and 1980s as part of a plan to create separate states for blacks. The mostly rural homeland, the birthplace of ANC leader Nelson Mandela, is made up of three separate land blocks in the southeast of South Africa and has about 2.75 million residents. It accepted independence in 1976.

DOC.HEAD: Archbishop Says Vatican Censure Won't Affect Abortion Stand
DOC.TEXT: Roman Catholic Archbishop Rembert Weakland, censured by the Vatican for studying women's reasons for having abortions, said Friday his critics won't silence his views. ``I can't imagine (being stopped) unless you take out my tongue,'' he told reporters as he broke into laughter at a news conference marking his return from a trip to El Salvador. ``I must admit I may be too upbeat about it. Maybe that's not good.'' When asked about the Vatican's decision last month to bar a Swiss university from giving him an honorary doctorate, he said: ``I haven't taken it that seriously,'' The Vatican's Congregation of Education in October ordered the University of Fribourg to remove Weakland's name from a list of recipients for honorary degrees scheduled to be awarded this week. The university had sought to honor Weakland for his work in writing a 1986 U.S. bishops' letter on the economy and social justice. After the Vatican's order, it canceled the awards ceremony rather than exclude Weakland. In the letter to Fribourg, the Vatican accused Weakland of ``causing confusion among the faithful of the United States'' concerning abortion. Weakland has maintained he respects the church's opposition to abortion but believes church leaders need to better examine the reasons why women, including Catholics, risk sin to obtain abortions. He held six meetings this year with women in his archdiocese to discuss the question, then issued a letter that criticized some tactics of anti-abortion protesters as demeaning and lacking compassion. The same letter also suggested that some people who describe themselves as ``pro-choice'' may not necessarily advocate abortion and their views needed to be reconciled with those of the church. Weakland said he considered the Vatican's censure confusing and has written a letter asking for clarification. ``Everybody's shrugging their shoulders wondering what's going on,'' he said. Weakland said church leaders have warned that his views ``are not without theological implications'' but he doesn't plan to change his outspoken approach to the issue after the censure. ``It won't change my procedure, I'm sure, in dealing with any topic. I'm not concerned about that,'' he said. He added that the loss of the award was insignificant when compared to the insight he gained from discussing abortion with women.

DOC.HEAD: Former Communists Survive No-Confidence Vote
DOC.TEXT: The embattled government of former Communists survived a no-confidence vote on Friday, but the opposition kept up the pressure by declaring a boycott in Parliament. Petar Beron, leader of the opposition Union of Democratic Forces, said his parliamentary faction was ``temporarily interrupting its participation in Parliament'' and consulting with voters. Meanwhile, the nation's largest union expressed disgust with both the government and opposition. It said it would circulate a petition among its hundreds of thousands of members expressing no confidence in lawmakers. Premier Andrei Lukanov had tied his political fate to the parliamentary no-confidence vote. It came after months of wrangling between his Socialists and the opposition on how to turn around the moribund economy and end Bulgaria's political paralysis. The no-confidence motion was defeated 201-159 in secret balloting in the 400-seat Grand National Assembly. It came a day after lawmakers approved Lukanov's austerity budget in a vote boycotted by the opposition. Lukanov had threatened to resign if the budget had failed to pass. Krastyu Petkov, head of the independent labor federation, appealed to President Zhelyu Zhelev to call new elections. He told state television a non-politial government of experts should run the country in the interim. A smaller trade union has called a general strike starting Monday if Lukanov does not step down before then. But the general prosecutor issued a statement Friday warning that strikes based solely on political demands were not permitted. Prior to the vote, Lukanov defended himself against charges by the opposition that his government was ineffective, and called for ``dialogue and honest compromise.'' The Socialists, formerly the Communist Party, won June elections and have 210 of the 400 seats in parliament. But because some of those seats are held by renegades, Lukanov has not been able to count on a majority. Scarce supplies of food and consumer goods have fired anger among Bulgaria's frustrated citizens about the economic crisis and the political deadlock. Opposition leaders claim they would triumph in new elections, and that Bulgaria would win more international aid under an opposition-led government than one of former Communists. But Lukanov said international aid ``does not depend on the color of the government.'' The premier, who returned to Sofia on Thursday from a 34-nation Paris summit, said talks with other leaders convinced him no one would help a country ``in which there is no stability, in which the reforms are not decisively implemented.'' The opposition has repeatedly rejected Lukanov's requests to join a broad Socialist-led coalition government, insisting instead on naming the premier and holding key ministries.

DOC.HEAD: Polish Miners Demonstrate at Parliament
DOC.TEXT: About 500 miners in hard hats and overalls staged a noisy demonstration in front of parliament Friday demanding increased government subsidies for financially troubled coal mines. A petition handed to the Sejm, or lower parliament house, said a cut in subsidies under the government's radical economic reforms has made mines unprofitable and caused a drop in living standards for miners, the state PAP news agency reported. During the 1{-hour protest, the miners also demanded wage talks with the government, PAP said. A 31-year-old miner, Ryszard Chojnowski, collapsed during the demonstration and later died, PAP reported. The cause of death was being investigated, it said. Miners in a series of warning strikes have been demanding basic pay of twice the national average of 1.2 million zlotys a month, equivalent to $130. Traditionally, miners commanded much higher wages than other workers because of the strategic importance of their industry and the difficult, dangerous working conditions. But Poland's post-Communist, Solidarity-led government has said mining should be transformed into a profit-making industry. Huge government subsidies are slowly being cut, while coal prices are being allowed to rise. Many of the miners demonstrating Friday were from the Communist-founded OPZZ trade union federation. Leaders met with Mieczyslaw Gil, head of the Citizens Parliamentary caucus, which is allied to the Solidarity labor movement; Senate Speaker Andrzej Stelmachowski; and various deputies. ``We are leaving hopeful, although we have not solved the question,'' said Rajmund Moric, head of the OPZZ mining union, after the demonstration. He said representatives of parliament and the government would visit the mining region of Silesia on Dec. 1.

DOC.HEAD: Fired Santas Picket Mall After Elf Accused of Lechery
DOC.TEXT: Santa Claus walked a picket line Friday after a company that provides Santas was fired by mall managers because an elf allegedly made a suggestive comment to a store employee. Bernard Zolnowsky, president and ``head Santa Claus'' of Old Style Music Inc., said he and several other workers dressed as Santa, Mrs. Claus and elves decided to picket the Seneca Mall to show the public the mall ``is playing Scrooge'' by firing them at the start of the season. ``They said the elf on Saturday had made a comment to a store employee that he wanted to molest her body,'' said Zolnowsky. He refused to identify the man hired as an elf. Lawrence Rose, manager of the mall just south of Buffalo, told the Santa company Sunday he wanted the elf fired, said Zolnowsky, who is threatening to sue Seneca Mall for breach of contract. ``They said, point blank, if you don't fire the elf, we'll terminate your contract,'' he said. Rose said the mall's attorneys told him not to comment on any allegations concerning the elf. But he said that wasn't the reason Old Style's contract was invalidated and said the contract says management needs no reason to cancel the contract. ``We terminated the contract on the basis of the general quality in the operation of the Santa Claus operation,'' said Rose. ``We did not feel this was up to our standards.'' Zolnowsky said that when he first heard about the allegation ``there was steam coming out of my ears. My first idea was to fire this person.'' But he said the elf convinced him that he didn't say anything to the female employee. Zolnowsky said the mall management refused to give him any proof of the allegation or a affidavit containing the store employee's claim. Old Style will remain at the mall until its contract ends at the end of the month, said Zolnowsky. Rose said the sight of Santa picketing has hurt not only his mall but the image of Santa Claus. ``Santa Claus is a revered institution,'' he said. ``And when somebody plays with it in a negative way, people reject it.''

DOC.HEAD: Rainy In East, Windy In Northwest
DOC.TEXT: Snow was scattered over the north-central part of the nation Friday while rain fell across much of the Eastern seaboard and the Gulf Coast. High wind blew across parts of the Northwest. At midday, snow showers extended over Upper Michigan, northern Wisconsin, northeastern Minnesota and north-central North Dakota. Rain reached across eastern New England, New Jersey and eastern Pennsylvania, and over coastal and central North Carolina, southeastern Georgia, southern Florida and the central Gulf of Mexico coast. Rain also fell over western Washington state. Wind gusted to near 50 mph across much of Washington state, with gusts to 70 mph near Hanford. Blowing dust caused some local road closures, including Interstate 82 near the Oregon border, the National Weather Service said. A high wind watch was in effect into Saturday over northwestern, eastern and south-central Wyoming. Friday morning's low for the Lower 48 states was 5 above zero at Gunnison, Colo. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 15 in Minnesota at International Falls and Warroad to 86 in Texas at Brownsville and Harlingen.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Calls Up More Reservists
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq on Friday canceled a night curfew in Kuwait to convey that Kuwait is calmer now, but also began calling army reservists in their 30s to join troops facing multinational forces in the Persian Gulf. A Defense Department communique broadcast on Baghdad radio did not say how many reservists fell into the age group specified - those born from 1958-60 - but it would include battle-hardened veterans of the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war. They apparently will be part of a callup of 150,000 reserves and draftees that Iraq said this week would be sent to occupied emirate along with about 100,000 regular army troops. The curfew announcement, reported by the official Iraqi News Agency and monitored in Nicosia, followed a two-day trip by President Saddam Hussein to Kuwait and southern Iraq. INA said lifting the 11 p.m.-7 a.m. curfew ``was taken to confirm the return of normal life to the governate.'' Following its blitz invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, Iran declared Kuwait Iraq's 19th province, or governate. Refugees from Kuwait reported an active, though diminishing resistance struggle there. Saddam inspected Kuwait on Thursday and told the troops he would fight to ``inflict defeat and disappointment ... on the evil blasphemers'' in event of a U.S.-led offensive. The visit came as President Bush spent Thanksgiving in Saudi Arabia with some of the 230,000 U.S. servicemen so far deployed in Operation Desert Shield. U.S. troops make up most of the multinational army opposing Iraq. ``After getting acquainted with conditions of the citizens in the province of Basra, the president (Saddam) paid a visit to the 4th and 2nd Army Corps and the command of the Republican Guard forces,'' INA said. The 4th and 2nd Corps are usually based in the central sector of the border with Iran. They were apparently redeployed to reinforce troops in the south in August after Saddam suddenly acceded to Iran's peace demands for a final end to their eight-year war. The Republican Guards are an elite corps of 120,000 men who spearheaded the invasion of Kuwait. At least six divisions are deployed south of Basra as a strategic reserve for Iraqi forces occupying Kuwait. Iraq now has about 430,000 troops in southern Iraq and Kuwait. Bush has ordered the U.S. force in the region increased by an additional 200,000 troops, mainly armored units based in Germany, by mid-January. That will bolster the U.S. and allied forces in the region to around 550,000 personnel and give the multinational force an offensive capability. The force originally was deployed to defend Saudi Arabia and its oilfields. Iraq's army has seven corps totaling 55 divisions, including 555,000 regular troops and 480,000 reserves. Saddam had to abandon plans to form 10 new divisions, with up to as many as 150,000 men, because of a manpower shortage. Iraq has a population of 16 million, including about 1.5 million men aged 18-32.

DOC.HEAD: Four Fishermen Missing After Submarine Pulls Down Boat
DOC.TEXT: Four fishermen were missing and feared dead Friday after a British nuclear submarine snagged their trawler's fishing gear and dragged the boat under water. ``The search for the crew continues,'' Defense Minister Archie Hamilton told the House of Commons. ``But, sadly, it now seems extremely unlikely that they will be found alive.'' Hamilton said the Royal Navy and the Transportation Department will investigate how the submarine HMS Trenchant caught the boat's fishing gear and pulled it under Thursday in the Firth of Clyde off southwestern Scotland. A naval vessel's underwater video equipment discovered the wreckage of the 52-foot trawler Antares early Friday 390 feet below the surface, said coast guard spokesman Roger Clarke. He said the land and sea search for the fishermen was centered on the Isle of Arran. Fishermen and friends of the missing men said submarine activities in the Firth of Clyde should be suspended. ``Quite a few people are getting angrier and angrier,'' said the Rev. Alastair Dunlop, a minister in Carradale, the trawler's home port. ``Everybody finds it hard to believe that a modern submarine does not know there's a fishing boat above it.'' Hamilton said the Royal Navy had operated submarines in the Firth of Clyde area for more than 80 years ``with an excellent safety record.'' ``This incident was a tragedy, but it seems to have been a very freak accident,'' he said. Clarke said no one was concerned about the incident until the fishing boat did not return to port later Thursday. Searchers then spotted an oil slick and the wreckage, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Says He, Bush Agree on Gulf; Look to Security Council
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev said Friday he and President Bush agreed the U.N. Security Council should be convened soon to discuss the Persian Gulf, and said higher ranking officials than U.N. representatives may attend. The Soviet president denied reports he and Bush disagreed when they met Monday night in Paris. ``I can tell you that meeting I had with President Bush only reinforced our cooperation,'' he told a news conference. ``We need to find a common solution,'' Gorbachev said, repeating his call for the Security Council to meet in the near-future. ``Once we have the Security Council in session, I am sure that it will be able to adopt a course that would be adequate to meet the requirements of the situaion. ``I am not sure whether it is going to be a resolution or any other formal document. ``I don't think that it would be on the permanent representative level. ... We might perhaps give some thought to having another level for that Security Council meeting, which we would approach with full seriousness.'' He did not specify who might attend from the Soviet side. Gorbachev rejected speculation that he and Bush differed on their approach to the crisis, which began with Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. ``The analysis that we made with President Bush showed that we have to continue to act within the framework of the U.N. Security Council so that we can tell the aggressor to comply with the demands of the Security Council.'' He said that some news media reports pointed to ``cracks between the two countries'' because the two leaders ``decided not to have a press conference, and this gave rise to reports of some divisions between us'' Monday night. Instead, said Gorbachev, he and Bush agreed ``the situation is fraught with grave consequences, larger than those that we had in Afghanistan or Vietnam.'' ``This is something very serious, and that is why we must cooperate here on the basis of a joint approach that we developed. We maintain systematic contacts so that we continue to control the situation,'' he said. ``Therefore, as a result of our frank analysis and exchange of views ... we concluded that time made it essential for the Security Council to be convened and to consider the situation. No one can speak for the Security Council, irrespective of the role played by the two countries, the Soviet Union and the United States, they still have to act together with the United Nations,'' he said. In Cairo, Egypt, on Friday, Bush said he was very close to getting U.N. approval for using force to try to oust Iraq from Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Contact Lens Injury Interrupts Billy Idol European Tour
DOC.TEXT: Rock singer Billy Idol, on a comeback tour after a serious motorcycle accident, was briefly sidelined in Europe by a contact lens injury. Idol, in the second week of his ``Charmed Life'' European tour, canceled four shows after his corneas were lacerated by grit that got under his lenses, spokeswoman Sharon Chevin said Friday in London. The injury occurred during an outdoor show in Oslo, Norway, on Saturday, said another spokeswoman, Sarah McMullin, in Houston. Idol has a home in Los Angeles. The painful injury forced Idol to cancel concerts earlier this week in Gothenberg, Sweden; Copenhagen, Denmark; and Brussels, Belgium, his spokeswomen said. He planned to perform as scheduled Friday night in Frankfurt, Germany, Chevin said. To protect his eyes from damage under the bright stage lights, Idol was to wear sunglasses, with a patch over his more badly injured right eye. The Brussels concert has been rescheduled for Saturday, and Idol intended to try to reset the other canceled shows, Chevin said. The European tour started Nov. 14 in Helsinki, Finland.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Warns Break-Up of Soviet Union Could Bring Bloodshed
LaserPhotos MOSB1-2
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev warned Friday that a break-up of the Soviet Union could lead to ``bloodshed'' and ``civil conflict,'' and said he will use all his constitutional powers to prevent it. ``We will not be able to divide, and when such attempts have been made, the results were bloodshed and grave consequences,'' Gorbachev said in a wide-ranging news conference. He spoke shortly after the Supreme Soviet legislature endorsed his general plans to reorganize the executive branch of government, and gave him two weeks to take steps to alleviate shortages in the nation's food supply. The legislature also passed a ``state of the union'' resolution asking its chairman, Anatoly Lukyanov, to begin urgent negotiations with his counterparts in the 15 Soviet republics for agreements to stop the political disintegration of the country. The resolution expressed serious concern about the collapse of central authority, and recommended Gorbachev take all steps ``authorized by law, up to extraordinary measures'' in cases where there is a ``threat to human life, health or property.'' It seeks to end a national paralysis of power resulting from the republics acting independently in introducing reforms to switch from a centrally planned to a market economy. All the Soviet republics except Kirgizia have declared some form of sovereignty, and the three Baltic republics have declared independence. It was the second time in a week the Supreme Soviet endorsed Gorbachev's proposal to eliminate the Council of Ministers, or Soviet Cabinet, and replace it with several bodies under direct presidential control. It's unclear if the legislature will take up the Gorbachev reform plan again. Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, whose job would be eliminated under the government realignment, was quoted by the government newspaper Izvestia as saying he was prepared to step down if Gorbachev's proposals are accepted. Ryzhkov said the proposals, announced last Saturday by Gorbachev, caught him by surprise. Ryzhkov and radical lawmaker Anatoly Sobchak, the mayor of Leningrad, criticized Gorbachev's proposals as sketchy. ``There isn't any complete picture of the system of the political government of the country,'' he was quoted as saying. Gorbachev said he respected the autonomy of the republics, but that if any of their leaders ``try to ... act in the way of an ultimatum, they will destabilize the situation, and make it more difficult. And I, as the president, also have a limit.'' Asked later whether he would use force to prevent any republic from seceding, Gorbachev said ``we will stay within the constitution'' in negotiating a new union treaty to serve as a charter uniting the republics. Any republic wishing to leave the union, he said, must respect a Soviet law passed this year requiring a referendum. ``It is a whole divorce procedure,'' he said. Attempts to leave the union without a referendum ``would be a tragedy to our peoples,'' he said. ``It would lead to civil conflict with the most grave consequences and that would bring the country to a situation unacceptable to the world community, as well.'' The resolution contained a gloomy assessment of the country's economic and political affairs. ``The situation in the country continues to worsen and is approaching a crisis condition,'' it said. The legislature also gave the KGB security police responsibility for dealing with what it called ``economic sabotage.'' The Supreme Soviet, in endorsing Gorbachev's plans to ``streamline the executive branch,'' removed a requirement for the president to consult with leaders in the republics before making the changes. The plan appeared designed to remove officials who are resistant to radical reform, and bring representatives of the republics into the central government. Under the outline, the Council of Ministers would be replaced by several bodies under presidential control. The principal ruling body would be the Federation Council, grouping representatives of the republics. Gorbachev offered few details on his ideas to improve the economy, other than saying he would propose changes in laws covering finances, transportation, energy resources, agriculture and landholding. The resolution called on Gorbachev, within the next two weeks, to work out a program to improve the food situation and ensure distribution of food from abroad. And he said that Western nations were offering food, credits and other forms of assistance to the Soviet Union during the winter. His spokesman, Vitaly Ignatenko, said this week that Gorbachev had won promises of up to $10 billion in aid from Germany, Italy, Canada, Spain and Britain. President Bush also has offered to aid the Soviet Union this winter.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Wants Interim Government
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela said Friday he will request a constitution-writing assembly and interim government at next week's talks between his African National Congress and the South African government. He told an African trade summit in Swaziland that the government seems to be losing its resolve to enter full-scale negotiations and is trying to weaken the ANC. Mandela and President F.W. de Klerk are due to meet Tuesday for talks aimed at setting up negotiations on a new constitution to give political power to the black majority. Both sides had said they wanted to begin full-fledged negotiations early next year. However, the white-led government has recently criticized ANC calls for increased protests and other forms of mass action against apartheid, the South African system of racial separation and white dominance. The two sides also have differed over the causes of black factional fighting in townships near Johannesburg that has killed more than 800 people since August. Mandela said Friday he would advocate a constituent assembly to draw up a new constitution and an interim administration to govern until the process is completed. Anti-apartheid groups have previously called for interim leadership and an elected constituent assembly to ease South Africa's transition to a non-racial government. The government has rejected an interim leadership. However, De Klerk has pledged to eliminate apartheid and to share political power with blacks. He asks protection of minority rights under any new system. The ANC wants a non-racial system with equal voting rights for all citizens. Under apartheid, the 5 million whites control the government, while the 30 million blacks have no national voting rights.

DOC.HEAD: Lebanese Horse Racers Protest Government Construction Plans
LaserPhoto BEI1
DOC.TEXT: About 2,000 owners, breeders, trainers, jockeys and stable grooms held a sit-in protest with dozens of Arabian steeds Friday at the shell-battered race track over a government decision to build a presidential palace there. The protesters who gathered at th walled midcity hippodrome pledged to resume racing at the beginning of the new year. ``We shall race anew despite the government decision,'' Nabil Freij, a leading member of the track's governing committee, told reporters. ``The track has long been a prime symbol of national unity. Its choice for a new palace ground shatters this symbol.'' As he spoke graceful Arabians trained at the track for the first time in two years. Hundreds of Moslem and Christian fans joined in the applause as the horses paraded. The track is governed by ``the committee for preserving the dynasty of the Arabian horse,'' which allows only Arabian steeds to race. Throroughbreds are prohibited. Bulldozers were clearing the rubble of 15 years of civil war during which the track, because of its location right on Beirut's dividing Green Line, was caught in Christian-Moslem crossfire. The track, called the Palace of Peace, was closed and reopened more than a dozen times during the civil war. The last closure was in March 1989, during a rebellion by renegade Gen. Michel Aoun. Now, peace finally seems to be coming to this nation of roughly 3.5 million people. Of the 700 racing Arabians in the stables at the track, 400 survived shelling duels between troops loyal to Aoun and regulars and irregulars with whom he fought intermittenty until his rebellion was crushed on Oct. 13. Some horses were killed in their boxes. Many perished of hunger and thirst when breeders and stable grooms fled. The heavy shellfire punched huge craters in the mile-long oval track, wrecked sections of the galleries and left gaping holes in the three-story headquarters of the governing committee. ``The loss is colossal for us, something around $5 million within the track,'' said Freij, whose family has a breeding farm in east Lebanon's Bekaa valley. ``And now we have this irresponsible decision of the government.'' On Nov. 7, President Elias Hrawi's Cabinet decided to build a new palace and government complex for the prime minister at the pine-wooded track. The old palace in suburban Baabda, a main target during the sectarian conflict, was demolished by Syrian warplanes during the drive against Aoun. Hrawi's administration has abolished the city's demarcation line and ordered civil war irregulars to withdraw from the capital and its environs to create a unified, militia-free ``greater Beirut.'' ``You don't inaugurate a united greater Beirut with an act of disunity,'' Freij said. ``That's what the decision to build the palace on the race track amounts to.'' The track has been one of the few places where up to 10,000 fans, rich and poor, Moslems and Christians, mixed at weekends. Freij inherited the racing passion from his father, the late Marquis Moussa de Freij, who founded the track with millionaire sportsman Henry Pharoun, now 90, about 70 years ago. Moslem horse owners and breeders flanked Freij, a Christian, as he warned on Friday that closing the track would strip 2,500 families of their only source of income. ``I've been spending $4,000 a month for years now to keep my trainers and stable grooms with my 33 Arabians, waiting for the day races will resume,'' said Antoine Kashouh, a Christian. ``Will the government feed them now?'' Moslem trainer Mohammed Haddar said at times during the fighting he had to buy food one day for his family and one day for the horses he cared for. He complained, ``We've starved to keep the horses. We survived the civil war, the (1982) Israeli invasion and Aoun's wars, hoping against all odds to race again. With peace in sight now, the government says `no.' It's not fair.'' The track was inaugurated in 1916 under the Ottoman Empire. The present governing committee took an 80-year lease for the grounds in 1920, when France ruled Lebanon after World War I.

DOC.HEAD: Mongolia's Communist Party Re-elects Chairman
DOC.TEXT: Mongolia's Communist Party re-elected its reform-minded chairman, but replaced most other party chiefs in its latest leadership shakeup, China's official Xinhua News Agency reported Friday. The presidium, the top body of the Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party, have undergone several major changes this year amid public pressure to adopt reforms similar to those being introduced in the Soviet Union. Party chairman Gombojavyn Ochirbat was re-elected and L. Tudev, director of the party newspaper Unen, was reported to have retained his presidium seat. At a three-day session, the party's Central Committee appointed five new presidium members ranging in age from 34 to 44, the news agency reported. The presidium, formerly known as the Politburo, sets basic party policy. It now has seven members. Four presidium members appointed in earlier shakeups stepped down or were removed, Xinhua said. One had become ambassador to the Soviet Union and another is the foreign minister, Tserenpiliin Gombosuren. The party also decided to hold a congress in February to discuss its future and revise its platform and constitution. In a dispatch from the Mongolian capital of Ulan Bator, Xinhua quoted the Mongolian newspaper Unen as saying the party leadership would be voted on again in February. Ochirbat became chairman in March after demonstrations demanding Soviet-style reforms. Under Ochirbat, the party agreed to give up its constitutional guarantee of power. Mongolia's first multiparty elections, held in July, kept the Communists in power but also gave new opposition parties a strong voice in government.

DOC.HEAD: Convicted Murderer Suspected In Another Slaying
DOC.TEXT: A condemned killer suspected in the slayings of nearly two dozen young men is under investigation in the fatal stabbing of an Indiana man whose body was found in 1982, police said Friday. The investigation, launched a couple of weeks ago, is a result of the release of a book detailing the life of Larry Eyler, convicted in 1986 for the murder of 15-year-old Danny Bridges of Chicago. Bridges' dismembered body was found in August 1984 in trash bags behind Eyler's Chicago apartment. Eyler is on Death Row at the Pontiac Correctional Center in Pontiac, 80 miles southwest of Chicago. Eyler is suspected of killing 23 young men in Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky and Wisconsin from 1982 through 1984, said Detective Dan Colin of the Lake County Sheriff's Department. He was tried only in Bridges' death. According to court testimony, Eyler, a homosexual, was into bondage. Some of his sexual partners testified that he enjoyed tying them up. All of the victims in which Eyler is a suspect were stabbed and their pants were pulled down. A judge in Lake County, where the body of 28-year-old Ralph E. Calise of Chicago was found in August 1983, ruled that police violated Eyler's rights during a search which officials said yielded crucial evidence in the Calise case. In September 1983, Indiana authorities investigating Eyler in a series of killings had confiscated some of his belongings, including his boots and a knife. He was detained for hours but never charged. Police later said blood taken from Eyler's boots matched Calise's. Because Lake County officials believed Indiana authorities had failed to make proper prints of the tires of Eyler's truck, they conducted their own search. But the Lake County judge, convinced that Indiana authorities had violated Eyler's constitutional rights, suppressed the Indiana evidence. And because the Illinois search of Eyler was prompted by the one in Indiana, the judge ruled that that evidence, too, should be suppressed. Without the evidence, authorities had no case and Eyler, 36, of Greencastle, Ind., was freed. Six months later, he was arrested in Bridges' slaying. Since then, the evidence from the Indiana search had remained in Lake County. On Wednesday, as a result of the book, ``Freed to Kill, The True Story of Larry Eyler,'' prosecutor Larry Thomas of Vermillion County, Ind., took the suppressed evidence to use in his investigation of an unsolved murder. Detective Colin said Thomas had reopened the murder case of 23-year-old Steve Agan of Terre Haute, Ind., and planned to convene a grand jury using the evidence that was suppressed in Illinois. Agan's body was found near Newport, Ind., in December 1982. ``My understanding is that the book gave them some insight they didn't know back then,'' Colin said. ``We have a lot of unsolved murders out there,'' said Colin, one of the investigators in the Calise case. ``I'm always glad when someone is able to put together a murder case and solve their stuff.'' ``It's just too bad that a book had to come out to force Indiana authorities to reopen some of the 16 cases attributed to Larry Eyler,'' Kolarik said.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Parties Pledge to Boycott Elections
DOC.TEXT: Opposition parties in Serbia said Friday they will boycott the republic's first free elections in 50 years because ruling officials rejected demands to change rules on casting and counting ballots. The republic's communist-controlled Parliament on Thursday denied requests to allow opposition officials into state-run ballot-counting commissions, and permit some Serbs abroad to vote in the Dec. 9 election. A statement by 12 opposition parties said Parliament's decision blocked the ``most elementary conditions'' for fair elections and ``wiped out the last chance of compromise'' with the ruling Socialists, the new name adopted by the communist party. The statement also demanded the resignation of Serbia's communist President Slobodan Milosevic and the ouster of Parliament leaders and other communist officials. The parties urged voters to join the boycott and attend a protest rally Dec. 3 in Belgrade. The statement was signed by leaders of the center-right Serbian Renewal Movement, the Democratic Party, the Serbian branch of federal Premier Ante Markovic's Alliance of Reformist Forces, and other parties. About 50 opposition parties are registered for the vote. Many have complained they had less access to state-controlled media for their campaigns. Vuk Draskovic, who was the top challenger to Milosevic, said his Renewal Movement had planned to contest all 250 Parliament seats. But under the boycott, only Milosevic's Socialists and a few newly formed communist groups would run, he said. The statement said unfair elections would make Serbia ``along with Albania, the last Bolshevik ghetto in Europe'' and isolate the republic. Following the vote Thursday, Parliament Chairman Zoran Sokolovic said current law, drawn up by the Socialists, ensures democratic elections. Nebojsa Popov, head of the small opposition Union for Yugoslav Democratic Initiative, said the vote would be ``a farce'' under the present election rules. Serbia, the largest of Yugoslavia's six republics, and Montengro, the smallest, are the last to hold multiparty elections. Communists were ousted last spring in the western republics of Slovenia and Croatia. In the central state of Bosnia-Hercegovina, nationalist parties had a landslide victory over communists. In last November's single-party Serbian elections, unregistered voters were allowed to cast ballots in some districts. Milosevic won with 104 percent of the registered voters in some areas. Parliament also began discussing a ban on the Democratic Alliance of Kosovo, which opposes Serbia's rule over the Kosovo province, where ethnic Albanians make up 90 percent of the 1.9 million people. The Democratic Alliance, supported by the ethnic Albanians, registered as a party with federal authorities, but not with Serbian officials. Serbia clamped down on the province's autonomy in July after Kosovo's parliament declared sovereignty.

DOC.HEAD: Cashbox Jingle May Be Quieter This Year
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3 grafs for 4th graf, `But lines ...' to UPDATE with strong sales in San Francisco; picks up 5th graf, `Many shoppers ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY10
DOC.TEXT: Consumers wandered the nation's malls and Main Streets on Friday, starting a Christmas shopping season that retailers fear will be their worst in years because of the twin grinches of a weak economy and the Persian Gulf crisis. In keeping with a tradition that's as much a part of Thanksgiving weekend as leftover turkey, shoppers lined up early, some standing in the rain before stores opened. By midmorning, many an aisle was crowded, from midtown Manhattan's swank department stores to the State Street Mall in Chicago to the shops that ring San Francisco's picturesque Union Square. ``We're having a phenomenal year, a record year,'' said Rebecca Schulz, store manager for FAO Schwartz on Union Square. ``We opened at 9 a.m. and there was a line waiting to come in past the toy soldier. We're seeing everything fly out the door - the basic toys, games, cuddly toys, electronic goods.'' Other San Francisco merchants were similarly ebullient about the 1990 holiday season. But elsewhere, lines at some cash registers were ominously short, substantiating fears of retailers who had predicted they would host browsers, not buyers. Many shoppers are trimming holiday budgets because they already have been squeezed financially by higher fuel prices, while talk of an economic downturn has unnerved them. ``I'm going to cut mine at least in half,'' said Sharon Stowe of Cary, N.C., who with her daughter-in-law was eyeing a model train display at a mall in Raleigh. Wanda McNamara of New Cumberland, Pa., said she has not been personally threatened with a layoff or loss of income. Still, she is taking recession talk seriously. ``I'm watching my dollars,'' she said while waiting for Boscov's department store to open in Harrisburg, Pa. ``I'm more careful, more selective. I'm looking for sales. I'm cutting down on the Christmas list.'' The first few days of Christmas shopping season are scrutinized by retailers because they're considered a barometer of what to expect in their most critical time of year, when they make about half their annual sales. No one is expecting this to be a great - or even very good - Christmas shopping season. Some pessimists, including retail industry analyst Daniel Barry of Kidder Peabody & Co. in New York, have even said it will be the worst holiday season since the 1974 recession. The Thanksgiving weekend has lost some significance in recent years because more consumers shop later in the season. But it still helps stores decide when to offer sales and what items they must restock. Gary Ebel, assistant general manager of Skagway department store in Grand Island, Neb., said he had no idea how the holiday retail season would turn out once the day after Thanksgiving had passed. ``Normally, it's one of the biggest days of the year for us,'' Ebel said. ``That's proved to be false for us for several years. Our biggest day is the last Saturday before Christmas, and it seems to be moving toward that trend.'' Still, Ebel and other merchants resorted to gimmicks to lure buyers. ``We gave away poinsettias to the first 300 customers, and we got rid of those in 15 minutes,'' Ebel said. ``We had books of stamps at 25 cents off today for two hours.'' Consumer spending, which slipped as the economy weakened this year, dropped precipitously after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Not only were consumers shaken by prospects of war, but they suddenly found themselves paying more for gasoline and heating oil. The Middle East turmoil, however, has inspired some merchants. A Florida discount store offered ``Put a Stain on Hussein'' toilet paper, featuring pictures of the Iraqi leader, for $1 a roll. ``It's flying out of here,'' said Jack Rohn, manager of the ``Everything's A $1.00'' store at the Sawgrass Mills shopping mall near Fort Lauderdale. The scenario is particularly grim for retailers hurt last season. Many were forced to slash prices to bring in sales and several suffered earnings drops or losses. Their hope to avoid a repeat this year is faint. At the giant Glendale Galleria mall in suburban Los Angeles, many shoppers said the foot traffic looked lighter than usual Friday. At D. Laurenti, a boutique specializing in $725 Italian suits and $195 shirts, assistant manager John Tawlian said sales were off as much as 30 percent as the holiday season began. ``We don't have big hopes,'' he said as shoppers strolled by his empty store. ``Things could change, but if you ask me it's not going to be as good as last year.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Welcomes Lifting of Import Ban, Ends Trade Action
DOC.TEXT: Thailand has agreed to legalize import of American and other foreign cigarettes and the U.S. governent is ending its 18-month investigation of unfair trade charges against the Southeast Asian country, it was announced Friday. ``We have been guided by the principles of obtaining fair and non-discriminatory access to the Thai market without in any way seeking to encourage smoking as a personal habit,'' said a statement from U.S. trade representative Carla A. Hills. The announcement did not mention cigarette advertising, banned in Thailand, and one of the controversial issues in Washington public hearings and in prolonged negotiations between the two governments. But her office confirmed Mrs. Hills' mid-October statement that ``with respect to advertising, we did not push that issue.'' The U.S. Cigarette Export Association filed charges of unfair trading against Thailand in 1989. If upheld, those charges could have led to retaliatory measures. Industry critics, including former U.S. Surgeon General C. Everett Coop, objected that the U.S. government should not be promoting exports of a health hazard. Some charged that the U.S. tobacco industry sought to undermine Thailand's official anti-smoking campaign and to glamorize smoking among new users such as youth and women. They said this happened in three other Asian countries where U.S. cigarette brands gained market access, Japan, South Korea and Taiwan. The U.S. industry and representatives of tobacco-growing states demanded the issue be treated as strictly commercial. They charged that the health issue was introduced to protect the Thai government tobacco monopoly. ``As long as Thailand sees fit to produce and sell its own cigarettes to its own people, we see no reason that foreign cigarette manufacturers should not have the same opportunity,'' Mrs. Hills said Friday. A breakthrough in the case came when a panel of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade earlier this year supported U.S. demands for market access, but did not support demands that U.S. brands be allowed to advertise. Thailand then agreed to discuss admitting imports and the U.S. side in mid-October passed up publishing a list of Thai products subject to potential penalty duties if the ban had continued. Sunday was the deadline for Mrs. Hills to recommend final action on the industry petition. Mrs. Hills said in October the U.S. government would abide by the GATT ruling on advertising ``even though is going to be difficult for foreigners to get their products in and known. It will simply have to be carried by word of mouth.'' Her office must decide by year-end on another U.S. industry petition to launch a new investigation of Thailand involving piracy of motion pictures, music recordings, computer softwear, books and trademarks.

DOC.HEAD: Police Arrest Prison Guard In Triple Slaying
DOC.TEXT: A state prison guard was arrested Friday and charged with killing a newlywed couple and a third victim, whose dismembered body was found in several locations, police said. Michael Laveglia, 30, of Beacon, was charged with three counts of second-degree murder, state Trooper Robert Gillespie said. Laveglia, a guard at the Downstate Correctional Facility in Fishkill, was accused of killing Thomas and Lorraine Thompson and Joseph Realmuto. The Thompsons were found shot to death Thursday, while police discovered Realmuto's remains early Friday in several trash bins in Fishkill, Gillespie said. The couple's bodies were discovered by firefighters called to put out a fire in their apartment in Clintondale, a hamlet on the Hudson River about 60 miles north of New York City. State troopers said it wasn't clear when the killings occurred. The Thompsons had been shot with a .45-caliber gun, state police Sgt. Ron Marek said. Police said they believe Laveglia, who was also charged with arson, started the fire to cover the crime. The couple were married Nov. 3, said the woman's father, Rosario Giunta. Laveglia was arraigned before Hurley Town Judge Athena Groelle and ordered held in Ulster County Jail without bail, Gillespie said. Corrections Department spokeswoman Ann Colodny said Leveglia became a state prison guard in 1984 and had been working at the Fishkill prison since 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Pilots Bring Packages and Holiday Cheer to Impoverished Town
DOC.TEXT: Twenty private pilots took off Friday on an annual airlift of medical supplies, clothing and food to a remote Mexican town. ``We celebrated our own good fortune and the blessings we've had on our Thanksgiving Day and then we try to give it to somebody else afterwards because we've got plenty left over,'' said Don Greif, 66, an organizer of the 10-year-old event. Aviators from Santa Barbara to Bakersfield contributed items to be flown in small planes from Van Nuys Airport in Los Angeles to Santa Rosalia in Baja California. The town has an airstrip but no control tower. This year's cargo included two new wheelchairs, crutches and first aid packages - valuable items in a town miles from any hospital. The town's copper mine closed years ago, increasing unemployment where people already were underemployed, Greif said. ``It's a deprived area,'' he added. ``There's no stable income there.'' The airlift is a festive occasion. Children from the school receive candy and clothes. And after the exhausting six-hour flight, pilots are greeted with food and beer provided by residents. Mexican marines guard the planes overnight and the pilots sleep in the only hotel nearby - a place where showers are often cold. The 642-mile trip is not easy, said Greif. Fuel can be an obstacle. The U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration and the Mexican government have been trying to stem the flow of drugs out of the country by removing fuel supplies from lesser known airstrips. The pilots fly over the sea for an hour after leaving Mexicali, a border city where they go through customs and refuel.

DOC.HEAD: Christmas Tree Poachers Draw Ire of Forest Rangers
DOC.TEXT: Christmas tree rustling in national forests in southern California is one annual holiday season ritual that should be stopped, forest rangers say. ``A lot of people think that if I just take one, it's not a problem,'' said Carla Van Dyne at the Tujunga district office of Angeles National Forest. ``Once they start cutting or even damage (the tree), it is going to die.'' U.S. Forest Service officials report problems with poachers taking trees without permits and outside designated areas at Los Padres, Angeles and San Bernardino national forests. Tree thievery is especially serious in Southern California forests because there are relatively few evergreens to begin with. The trees are already harmed by disease, insects and smog, foresters said. Nabbing the culprits can be tough. For example, only six federal employees keep watch over the 500,000-acre Mount Pinos reserve in the Los Padres National Forest in northern Ventura County. Officials estimate that thieves cut down and steal 20 to 30 fir and pine trees every year. Don Trammell, a recreation and operations officer at Mount Pinos, said about two tree rustlers are caught each year. The penalty for taking a tree is usually a $50 fine, but the penalty can be as heavy as a $5,000 fine and can include a one-year jail term. Mount Pinos firefighter Jamie Moore said thieves have been known to climb tall firs and saw off the top half. The remainder of the tree usually dies because it is vulnerable to a species of wood-eating beetle, she said. ``What they are taking is not so much a commodity but something that is high in value in the recreational sense,'' Forest Service Officer John Kelly said.

DOC.HEAD: Three Killed in Mud Slide in Mine
DOC.TEXT: Three miners were killed Friday in a mud slide at a Freegold Western Holdings gold mine near Welkom, about 100 miles southwest of Johannesburg, Anglo American Corp. announced. On Thursday, a rock fall more than 1{ miles underground, caused by an earth tremor, killed five people at Doornfontein gold mine near Carletonville, about 30 miles west of Johannesburg, said mine owner Gold Fields.

DOC.HEAD: Gunmen Kill Colombian Congressman
With AM-Colombia
DOC.TEXT: Assassins in an adjacent moving vehicle fired 10 bullets into a Conservative Party congressman in eastern Colombia Friday, killing him as he traveled in a car with his wife, police said. A police bulletin said Rep. Juan Barragan was killed in Bucaramanga and his wife, Flor Alba de Barragan, was slightly wounded. The gunmen escaped. Barragan was elected to the House of Representatives last March. Police gave no motive for the assassination.

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovakia to Slaughter 800 Sick Cows
DOC.TEXT: Eight hundred cows contaminated with toxic compounds will be slaughtered and burned to ashes by the end of the year in southern Moravia, the independent daily Mlada Fronta Dnes reported Friday. Their milk and meat contain excessive levels of polychlorated biphenyls (PCBs), with levels equally high in the meat of their offspring, it said. It gave no precise figures. ``Newly born calves have the same levels of PCBs as their mothers. That is why the first to be slaughtered were pregnant cows,'' the daily quoted Zdenek Havlicek, chief of the Borsice cooperative, as saying.
