It said that following slaughter of the first 150 cows Friday, arrangements were made to pulverize the carcasses and put them in special containers. PCBs are chemical additives contained in paint used for agricultural equipment. Such chemicals were banned for use in Czechoslovakia in 1984, but the PCB content in the food chain has been increasingly noticed by environmentalists. To destroy PCBs, temperatures above 1,832 degrees are needed, it said. But furnaces in Czechoslovakia cannot now work at such temperatures. ``We are also storing some 150 tons of butter contaminated with PCBs,'' Havlicek said. About 60 percent of the PCBs detected in the cows came from the paint of silage pits and were absorbed through the cows' fodder, Mlada Fronta Dnes said. The rest was blamed on general PCB pollution of the evironment, it said.

DOC.HEAD: Turkeys Returned After Poison Threat in Arizona
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout to UPDATE with new estimate of the number of turkeys that will be buried, rewards offered and comment by store chairman. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Customers deluged a Tucson supermarket chain with turkeys, some of them already cooked, after a man claimed to have injected some of the birds with cyanide. The Pima County health department said Friday that about 4,600 turkeys would be buried in a landfill north of Tucson. They included about 550 turkeys the store took off its shelves and about 4,050 that customers returned. Jim Acton, vice president of media operations for Smith's Food and Drug stores, estimated that the cyanide scare would cost the supermarket chain as much as $200,000. The store on Friday offered a $10,000 reward for information leading to the arrest of the perpetrator, and authorities in Tucson and surrounding Pima County also offered a $1,000 reward. A man called reporter-anchorwoman Barbara Grijalva of KOLD-TV on Wednesday to say he had injected some Smith's turkeys with cyanide. Police have said there was no evidence that the birds were tainted. The supermarket chain removed turkeys from its four Tucson stores and offered refunds or exchanges to customers who recently had purchased turkeys. No stores outside of Tucson were affected. Ninety to 95 percent of the customers who brought turkeys to the store on Thursday asked for a refund instead of another turkey, store officials said. Samples have been taken of all the varieties of turkeys from the Tucson stores and will be tested for poisoning, Acton said. ``It appears to be simply the work of a hoax of a very sick person who either has a grudge to bear against Smith's or only wished to cause a great deal of anguish among innocent people,'' Smith's chairman, Jeff Smith, said in a statement.

DOC.HEAD: Mubarak Says Question of Iraqi Military Capacity Should Wait
DOC.TEXT: Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak said Friday the United States and other countries should liberate Kuwait before they confront the question of how to maintain peace in the face of mounting Iraqi military power. ``Let us start by liberating Kuwait ... complete withdrawal and then this issue should be studied in the negotiations after the withdrawal,'' Mubarak said in an interview with NBC's Tom Brokaw aired Friday night. The interview came after President Bush's visit earlier Friday with the Egyptian president. Egypt has promised up to 20,000 troops to the international force in Saudi Arabia to liberate Kuwait. Iraq maintains a chemical warfare capability and some analysts say it will be able to launch nuclear-tipped missiles in 10 years unless stopped. Strategists have pondered whether go beyond liberating Kuwait in the current crisis and use the opportunity to topple Iraqi President Saddam Hussein before he gets a nuclear arsenal. Mubarak brushed aside a question on what would happen if Saddam were allowed to maintain his military power and used it to attack Israel. ``You in America are going through so many items,'' Mubarak said. ``You are saying, Supposing he may attack Israel, then he may attack Saudi Arabia ... Iraq is not a superpower.'' As for getting Iraq out of Kuwait, Mubarak said President Bush ``is eager to solve the problem peacefully as much as he can ... but at the same time if he didn't find a way to solve it peacefully he is going to use force.'' ``There is no other way else,'' he said. ``If there is no other way to solve the problem them we will have to use force.'' But he reiterated that Egyptian forces would not go beyond Kuwait and fight inside Iraq itself. ``Our troops will not go to Iraq because we are not going to liberate Iraq,'' Mubarak said. ``The problem is Kuwait.'' He also said the parties to the dispute ``should tackle the Palestinian question because it is the crux of the whole problem.'' ``This issue should move foward,'' he said. ``We should not neglect it.''

DOC.HEAD: Lawyer Will Fight Attempts to Try Client as Adult in Harbour Slaying
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to elaborate on black leader's criticism of the investigation into the killing; picks up 17th graf pvs: ``We have to ...
DOC.TEXT:
A judge denied bail Friday for one of five juveniles charged in the Halloween rape and murder of a 26-year-old woman, and a black leader blamed police for mishandling its investigation because the woman was black. A woman who says she was a witness said she has been warned not to talk to authorities. ``At this point in time I think that he should be tried as a juvenile,'' said the juvenile's attorney, Juliane Balliro, after a closed hearing in Suffolk Superior Court. ``He is 15 years of age and he has no prior criminal involvement whatsoever.'' Balliro's client is one of eight youths charged in the death of 26-year-old Kimberly Rae Harbour. Authorities alleged she was bludgeoned, repeatedly raped, and stabbed more than 100 times by a gang of teen-agers roaming the streets in search of women to rob. The Suffolk County district attorney is seeking to have the five juveniles charged as adults in her death. Three other young men aged 17, 18 and 19 were charged as adults. Conviction as an adult on a charge of first-degree murder would bring an automatic life sentence without parole. If the five youths are found delinquent as juveniles, they could be released on their 18th birthday. Also Friday, a leader in the city's black community, Sadiki Kambon of the Black Information Center, called for the resignation of Boston Police Commissioner Francis Roache. Kambon said the department's investigation into the slaying only highlighted of failure of police to properly serve minorities in the city. There was no immediate response from Roache to the call for his resignation; he did not return telephone calls. The slaying more than three weeks ago initially drew little public notice after police announced it as a homicide. Details weren't released until this week after the arrests.
Blacks have complained that residents should have been warned of the attack earlier so they could protect themselves. Kambon also repeated criticism of the police handling of the Stuart case. The shooting death of Carol Stuart in October 1989 brought police into a minority neighborhood to search for a suspect after Stuart's husband, Charles, said he and his pregnant wife were attacked there by a black mugger. Charles Stuart later apparently committed suicide after learning he had become a prime suspect in his wife's death. Kambon also called for more minority police patrols in the inner city and said minorities must do more to help youngsters. ``We have to assume some of the responsibility for what's going on out here,'' Kambon said. Meanwhile, a possible witness of Harbour's death said she has been warned not to talk to authorities. ``I need some protection,'' Laura Peterson, 40, told the Boston Herald. Peterson told police she fled to safety while eight young men chased Harbour into a park in the city's Dorchester section and killed her. Peterson said a man knocked on the door of an apartment where she was staying Thursday and gave her a message ``from a boy.'' She said the message was to ``keep your mouth shut.'' On the night of the killing, Peterson said she was standing with Harbour, who she assumed was out ``selling her body.'' She said three masked teen-agers tried to rob her before joining others in chasing Harbour, who she said was yelling ``Help me, Help me.'' Peterson said she was too frightened, even after reaching a friend's apartment, to call police.

DOC.HEAD: Irish Prime Minister Enters Dispute Over Bronze Age Necklace
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Charles Haughey on Friday joined efforts to bring a 3,700-year-old necklace back to Ireland from a London auction house. Officials at the National Museum of Ireland claim the Bronze Age necklace, or lunula, was illegally taken from Ireland. It is now at Christie's, a London-based auction company. Haughey said there is evidence the necklace was removed from Ireland within the past two years in violation of the national monuments act. ``The Irish authorities will take all necessary measures to obtain the return of this important national treasure,'' the prime minister said. The necklace, dated from about 1800 B.C., was found in County Galway in 1975. Irish press reports had said the necklace was worth about $39,200. Christie's spokesman Mark Wrey said the National Museum had offered to buy the necklace for $23,500. He said when Christie's called the museum to negotiate a price for its client, it was told the necklace had been illegally exported. The client was not identified. Christie's will not place a value on the piece until the ownership dispute is resolved, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Greek Government Supports Film Director After Bishop's Threats
DOC.TEXT: The government on Friday backed a film director battling a Greek Orthodox bishop who has threatened to vandalize the filmmaker's props and excommunicate anyone working on his movie. The bishop claims the film is unpatriotic in calling for the abolition of national borders. He also charges that a copy of the script he has seen contains erotic scenes. ``The government unreservedly supports Theodore Angelopoulos and the shooting of his film,'' Culture Minister Tzannis Tzannetakis said. Angelopoulos, one of Greece's best known directors and the winner of several European prizes, is due to start filming ``The Suspended Stride of the Stork'' in Athens on Dec. 3 and in the northern border town of Florina on Dec. 17. But the town's bishop, Avgoustinos Kantiotis, has threatened to ``destroy the props with fire and excommunicate'' anyone involved in the film, Angelopoulos says. The film has a budget of $3.3 million, including some European Community funding, according to the semi-official Athens News Agency. Italian actor Marcello Mastroianni is expected to star in the film. Among Angelopoulos' prize-winning films are ``The Traveling Players,'' filmed in 1975; ``Megalexandros,'' 1980; and ``Landscapes in the Mist,'' 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Iranian Refugee Threatens to Set Fire to British Embassy
DOC.TEXT: An Iranian refugee threw gasoline on the floor of the British Embassy on Friday and threatened to set the building on fire, but he was persuaded to leave and then arrested, a British diplomat said. No was was injured, said Alyson Bailes, the political counselor. She said the man had his application to live in Britain rejected. He has political asylum in Norway, she said. She did not identify the man, saying only he is in his 30s. ``He was in the outer part of the reception hall when he started throwing gasoline on the floor from a small container. He held a match that he said he was ready to strike,'' Ms. Bailes said. She said embassy officials talked him into leaving the building. He was arrested by Norwegian police.

DOC.HEAD: People In The News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Two members of the teen-age singing group Menudo were fired Friday after being arrested at Miami International Airport and charged with possession of marijuana. Sergio Gonzalez, 18, and a 16-year-old whose name was not released because of his age, were charged Thursday after a U.S. Customs Service dog smelled marijuana. Customs agents took small amounts of the drg from them, Metro-Dade police Lt. James Kaelin said. ``I guess some people call them personal-use amounts, but drugs are drugs, no matter what amounts they are,'' said Customs spokesman Joe Krokos. Oscar Llord, general manager for Sonotone Music, the group's Miami recording company, said Friday the group's manager had fired the two singers hours after their arrest. Menudo, based in Puerto Rico, has been around for 12 years, rotating new members into the group as veterans grow too old to appeal to a pre-teen and teen audience.

DOC.HEAD: District Attorney Says Victim Had Sex With Witness
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 2 grafs after last graf, ``The way ...' to UPDATE with details of how the allegations surfaced. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A woman with 46 personalities has acknowledged having sex with a key witness in the trial of a man who was convicted of sexually assaulting her. The admission is significant in part because, under Wisconsin law, having sex with a mentally ill person can be a crime. Winnebago County District Attorney Joseph Paulus said the 27-year-old victim confirmed allegations in a court document that she had a sexual relationship with Gerald Reeves, her downstairs neighbor. ``She said, `It's true, I did do it,''' Paulus said, adding he was uncertain whether the relationship would result in new criminal charges. Mark Peterson, 29, of Oshkosh, was convicted earlier this month of sexually assaulting the woman. Authorities argued he was guilty of a crime because he manipulated one of her personalities in June two days after he met her. Under Wisconsin law, it is a crime to have sex with a mentally ill person if the person is so severely impaired he or she can't appreciate the consequences of the behavior, and if the other person knows of the illness. Paulus said it's not clear whether any charges would be filed against Reeves. He said it would depend on whether the victim would file a complaint and whether it could be proven she was taken advantage of her because of her condition, called multiple personality disorder. Reeves, who testified during the trial about the victim's vulnerability, did not return telephone messages left at his house Friday by reporters seeking comment. He said in an earlier interview he was unaware of the allegations. He has not been charged with any crime. Peterson's attorney, Mary Lou Robinson, said she would proceed with her plan to request a new trial for her client, adding the latest allegations would assist her appeal. ``The way this case developed has brought mockery upon the court system,'' she said. Allegations that Reeves had a relationship with the woman were contained in a letter sent Wednesday by a former Winnebago County counselor to county Circuit Judge Robert Hawley. Sheila M. Carmichael, who counseled the woman, was fired earlier Wednesday for entering into a contract last week for movie and publication rights involving the victim's story.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING to CORRECT headline
One of Nation's Oldest Chartered Press Club Closing
DOC.TEXT: One of the nation's oldest chartered press clubs, the 109-year-old Pittsburgh Press Club, will close its doors for good by year's end. ``Let's just say that the program we thought would work just didn't come to fruition. The bricks just didn't fall into place,'' club President A. Alan Paulus said Wednesday. ``It takes a lot of support from the membership to keep it going. I'll just leave it at that.'' A federal bankruptcy judge officially turned down the club's attempts to reorganize under bankruptcy protection earlier this month. The club has been in financial trouble since the early 1980s and filed for protection under Chapter 11 of federal bankruptcy law in March 1989. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Joseph L. Cosetti said the club had ``no reasonable prospect of reorganizing.'' Officials blamed the club's decline on a number of factors, including difficulty in attracting younger members, strife among club officers and between officers and management. In addition, many members did not return after a strike closed the club for three months in 1983. In the latest attempt to save the Press Club, not affiliated with The Pittsburgh Press, officials had slashed the staff from 42 to about a dozen, moved to less expensive quarters, increased dues and added about 200 members. Paulus said he would ask members to pay $25 each to keep the club operating through the holiday season. As of Sept. 30, the club had $372,384 in bills and only $28,988 in current assets to pay them. Some club vendors have unpaid bills dating to 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Missing Man Identified as Civilian; Search Continues
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `Three of ...' to UPDATE with men released from the hospital. Picks up 10th graf, `The missing ...'
DOC.TEXT: Divers searched the murky water of Lake Ellsworth on Friday for a civilian flight instructor missing after a military helicopter crash. After two or three dives, there still was no sign of the missing man, and the search was called off at dusk, said Fort Sill spokeswoman Sheila Samples. ``They're still having some problems getting into the aircraft ... They can't seem to get it open or see in it to see if anybody is in it,'' she said. A large Chinook helicopter brought in from Fort Sill partially lifted the UHV-1 helicopter from the lake Friday, but the wreckage broke free and fell back in, she said. Searchers will return to the lake early Saturday, she said. The instructor and five members of the 374th Air Ambulance Company were on an over-water training mission, working for the first time with new night vision goggles, when the helicopter crashed into the lake late Thursday. The cause of the crash was not known. The 374th is a Little Rock reserve unit activated as part of Operation Desert Shield, Ms. Samples said. The unit, which has about 50 members, arrived at Fort Sill on Sunday. Lakeshore residents in a 12-foot fishing boat rescued the five crewmen. Three of the men were treated for hypothermia and minor cuts and bruises at Reynolds Army Community Hospital, Ms. Samples said. They were released from the hospital Friday. The missing man was identified as Phillip E. Walker, of Sheridan, Ark., a civilian maintenance facility manager for the Army at Little Rock, said Ms. Samples. Previous reports stated incorrectly that he was a reservist. Ms. Samples said a team from the Army Safety Center at Fort Rucker, Ala., was en route to Fort Sill to investigate.

DOC.HEAD: Court: Austrian Holocaust Reparations No Bar to U.S. Benefits
DOC.TEXT: Austrian immigrants who are paid reparations to compensate for Nazi persecution cannot be disqualified from receiving U.S. benefits for the low-income aged, blind or disabled, a federal court has ruled. Chief U.S. District Judge Thelton Henderson said in a ruling released Friday that Austrian reparations must be treated like similar payments from the German government. The U.S. government had sought to differentiate Austrian from German reparations, questioning whether Jews who fled Austria should be considered victims of Nazi persecution. The ruling concerned a class-action lawsuit filed by an Austrian immigrant, Herbert Bondy, who was 16 when his family fled Austria in 1938 after Germany occupied the country. Bondy, who retired in 1980, had been received Social Security payments as well as benefits for the blind when he received his first reparation payment from Austria in 1988. The Social Security Administration counted the payments as income and disqualified him from benefits for his blindness. Henderson ruled that reparations from Austria must be treated like those from Germany, referring to a 1984 ruling by the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals that excluded German reparations as income in determining eligibility for federal benefits. About 8,800 people in the United States receive Austrian reparations; an estimated 158 to 572 also collect federal benefits for the aged, blind or disabled, Henderson said. The U.S. government has argued that only those interned by the Nazis qualified for reparations. Henderson quoted the Austrian consul general in Los Angeles as explaining Austrian reparations were for a moral obligation ``in view of the great injustice and heavy suffering inflicted on the victims of Nazi persecution while Austria was under Nazi occupation.'' Austria won back its independence in 1945 at the end of World War II. According to the National Jewish Congress, Austria had anti-Jewish laws as early as 1935 and, in 1938, Jews commonly suffered beatings, lootings and deportations. A lawyer for the group, J. Mark Waxman, described the reparations as modest but said he didn't know precise amounts. The government's attorney could not be reached for comment Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Surgeon Who Did First Successful Liver Transplant to Quit Transplants
DOC.TEXT: Dr. Thomas Starzl, who led the world's first successful liver transplant in 1967 and trained most of the nation's doctors who can perform the operation, said Friday he plans to quit surgery and concentrate on research. Starzl said the death earlier this month of one of his patients, 13-year-old Stormie Jones, left him emotionally drained. The 13-year-old Texas girl was the world's first recipient of a heart-liver transplant in 1984. Starzl, 64, has not performed surgery since undergoing an operation in August to clear a blocked artery. Liver transplants are ``so standardized, there really isn't any point in my handling cases,'' he told the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette. ``We have eight to 10 lead surgeons.'' Starzl said enough surgeons are qualified to transplant livers to allow him to study the effects of FK-506, an anti-rejection drug approved by the U.S. Department of Agriculture for use only at Presbyterian University and Children's hospitals in Pittsburgh. About 1,000 transplant patients now take the drug, which studies show is more effective than its predecessor, cyclosporine. Starzl said he also hopes to improve the search for organ donors and delivery of their organs. Starzl performed the first liver transplant in 1963, and it failed. He had his first success four years later at the University of Colorado at Denver. He also pioneered development of a medical team that performed 200 kidney transplants at Colorado General and Denver Veteran's Administration hospitals. Starzl began working in 1981 at the University of Pittsburgh, which he helped turn into one of the world's premier transplant centers. Last year, the hospital performed more than 460 liver transplants and 210 kidney transplants. Since Starzl's earliest efforts, thousands of such transplants have been performed around the world. On Valentine's Day 1984, Starzl led the team that lifted a diseased heart and liver from Stormie Jones, then 6, and replaced them, giving her six more years of life. ``I saw her grow up, and I saw her at death's door,'' said Starzl, who was one of her principal surgeons. Stormie, of White Settlement, Texas, died Nov. 11 when her body suddenly rejected her transplanted heart more than six years after the historic operation that saved her life. ``When you lose a patient like that, it's awful,'' said Starzl, who was traveling in Europe when he learned she had died.

DOC.HEAD: Washington Medical Educator Dies
DOC.TEXT: A memorial service will be held Monday for Dr. W. Montague Cobb, a former president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and faculty member at Howard University Medical School for 45 years. Dr. Cobb, 86, died Tuesday at George Washington University, where he had been hospitalized for heart problems and pneumonia. An amateur violinist and historian who once estimated that he had helped train more than 6,000 physicians as a teacher of anatomy, Cobb wrote more than 600 scientific papers in a career that saw service on many scientific and government committees. He was a member of the board of directors of the NAACP for more than 30 years and served as president from 1976 to 1982. He also served as president of the National Medical Association, the leading organization of black physicians, and was editor of its journal from 1949 to 1977. A native of Washington, Dr. Cobb attended Amherst College and Howard University Medical School and received a doctorate in anatomy at Case Western Reserve University before joining the Howard faculty in 1928. Dr. Cobb is survived by two children and four children. His wife of 47 years, Hilda, died in 1976.

President Bush, trying to tighten the Arab coalition against Iraq, held talks today with Egypt's Hosni Mubarak after an exhilarating Thanksgiving visit with U.S. combat forces at remote desert outposts. ``We won't pull punches,'' Bush promised troops in Saudi Arabia. The Egyptian president put aside his cautious style of leadership to lead Arab opposition to Iraq after its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Bush rewarded Mubarak by requesting - and obtaining - congressional legislation waiving more than $7 billion in Egyptian military debt to the United States. The two leaders met at Kubbah Palace, an ornate guest house for foreign officials visiting Egypt. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - The off-again, on-again attitude of the Soviet Union on using force to liberate Kuwait is a problem for the Bush administration. Moscow's support is vital, and November is drawing to a close. The significance of the calendar is that the United States is president of the United Nations Security Council this month. Then it's Yemen's turn, and the Arab nation has opposed most of the resolutions aimed at Iraq since the August invasion. Running the Security Council gives the Bush administration a tactical advantage. Once Yemen is in the chair it would be that much tougher to win adoption of a resolution to use force as a last resort to liberate Kuwait. ``There's a lot of ways to get thoroughly wrapped around the axle of the United Nations,'' a senior State Department official said recently about the intricacies of the world organization. ``There are a whole host of other things that can come up. So it's important to try and do it during the period of our presidency of the council.'' ---=

Saddam Hussein answered President Bush's trip to the Saudi desert with his own morale-boosting mission to Iraqi troops in Kuwait, telling them he is ready to fight ``the evil blasphemers'' if attacked. The U.S.-dominated force in the gulf got a boost, meanwhile, with Britain's announcement Thursday that it was nearly doubling its forces, bringing its contribution to 30,000 - the second largest contingent after the United States. Sharing a turkey dinner with U.S. troops in the sands of the Saudi desert, President Bush promised them that ``We are not here on some exercise.'' ``And we're not walking away until our mission is done, until the invader is out of Kuwait,'' he said. ``And that may well be where you come in.'' The troops cheered with approval. The president also cautioned that Iraq was developing nuclear capability, and he warned that Saddam ``never possessed a weapon he didn't use.'' ---= LONDON (AP) - Hailed as the end of an era that transformed Britain, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's decision to resign has angered supporters, pleased opponents and left three men battling to succeed her. Ex-defense secretary Michael Heseltine, whose challenge precipitated her resignation announcement Thursday, was joined in the Conservative Party leadership race by Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd and Treasury chief John Major. A new poll today indicates the party, led by Mrs. Thatcher for 15 years, stands a better chance of winning an election now that she agreed to step down when the party picks her replacement next week. The Conservatives had lagged behind the opposition Labor Party in recent surveys as a result of high inflation and interest rates as well as an unpopular per capita tax. ---= NEW YORK (AP) - Retailers don't expect booming business as the Christmas shopping season gets off to its unofficial, day-after-Thanksgiving start today amid uncertainty over the sagging economy and Persian Gulf crisis. Sales, already weakened by the economic slowdown, fell off sharply after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in early August drove up gasoline and heating oil prices. Consumers tend to spend more during the holidays, but storekeepers expected many shoppers would browse, not buy, this weekend. ``We're not living on hope, we're living with reality,'' J.C. Penney Co. Chairman William R. Howell said. ---= COLLEGE STATION, Texas (AP) - Soviet ballet star Alexander Mischenko, wearing a new red bandanna, watched as Shawn Strahan demonstrated the Texas two-step in his shiny brown cowboy boots. Then Mischenko imitated the steps precisely - adding a pirouette. The dance duel came as College Station welcomed the Soviet Union's first private ballet company, the Bolshoi-Grigorovich, which makes its U.S. premiere tonight at Texas A&M University with a new version of ``The Nutcracker.'' A country-western vs. Russian classical ballet dance-off pitting Strahan's troupe, the Aggie Wranglers, against the Soviet company was the high point of a `Howdy!' reception put on by the College Station Chamber of Commerce. American and Soviet youths, in a circle around Mischenko and Strahan, cheered as they danced.

DOC.HEAD: Burning Tree Presents Blues With a '90s Psychology
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: If it were possible to record the stale smell of beer and cigarettes in the air, the wet circles left on a counter from bygone drinks and the jaded eyes of souls deep in their cups, you'd come up with Burning Tree. The California trio's self-titled debut album on Epic draws upon the guitar-based blues of such '60s legends as Cream and the Jimi Hendrix Experience for its sound - a refreshing change from glossy, overproduced radio fare. Burning Tree may sound like they've been trapped in a time warp, but they don't write songs that way. ``We're very derivative, I suppose, of the older sound, but when you're a three-piece band, you either sound like the Police or you sound like Cream,'' bassist Mark Dutton said in a recent telephone interview. ``When you're playing as a three-piece, everybody has so much to do that you basically have to be proficient on your instrument, so when you do that and you get into that jam mode, you go over the edge,'' he said. Blues references, probably more so than classic rock ones, abound in Burning Tree's down-and-dirty style. The album's title track warns against taking unnecessary risks in life, like flying on ``a one-winged eagle.'' The ballad ``Playing in the Wind'' is the band's warning to itself about letting fame go too far. On the same theme, the delightful ``Crush,'' about the pitfalls of show business, shows a healthy sarcasm for people who've ``got a crush on one of us, but they don't know which one it is.'' Dutton said Burning Tree's self-appointed task was to update the blues' subject matter. ``All the great blues artists, the reason they were so great and so loved is because they sang about their reality, they sang about their life,'' he said. ``I think what we want to do is keep that sound that appealed to your ears so much, but bring it up to date psychologically.'' All three members of the band - Dutton, guitarist Marc Ford, and drummer Doni Gray - sing and write material. Dutton, who had always been in charge of previous bands, said it was a learning experience not to be calling all the shots. ``You have to stifle those feelings'' of being in charge, he said. ``Those are natural feelings, but you have to trust the other two people in your band - and that's the only reason we're a band is because we do trust each other.'' The album's deliberate underproduction is noteworthy. Ford's hoarse, raspy voice is left alone, even when it cracks during a verse, and the album's entire sound is kept murky and dingy, true to its blues roots. ``If we actually do get a take all the way through where we sing the right words, then we have to keep it, because chances are, we wouldn't be able to do it again,'' he said. ``But it gives the song charm, you know. It's kind of like the perfect human being - who would want to be with someone perfect? It'd get real boring after a while.'' Dutton credited producer Tim Palmer, who also worked on David Bowie's ``Tin Machine,'' for keeping Burning Tree's live sound intact. ``We had all these old ideas and he just knew when we were going a little too far and would step in and bring us up to date.'' Burning Tree has been performing live for a year and a half. The album was recorded in just eight weeks. Asked if the band had paid its dues, Dutton said: ``I hope we never finish paying our dues, but I think our heads are in the right place right now, whether you want to call it paying your dues or not. We just happened to be at the right place at the right time - there's really no formula whatsoever. ``We just play honestly and I think people can tell that,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Economic Outlook Bleak for Pakistan
DOC.TEXT: Creditors demand money, foreign currency reserves are being drained to repay short-term loans and domestic price increases are overdue, so Pakistan is asking for help. ``There's no way we can cover the losses ourselves; $1 billion we can make up on our own, but we need help with another billion,'' said Sartaz Aziz, finance minister of the new government. Japan was the first to respond, offering a $500 million aid package when President Ghulam Ishaq Khan visited Tokyo for the enthronement of Emperor Akihito. In an effprt to make up the first billion, Pakistan plans to raise domestic prices, implement strict oil conservation measures and push exports while reducing imports. Gasoline prices went up more than 40 percent this month. Last month, the United States suspended $500 million in aid because of suspicions that Pakistan has or is developing nuclear weapons. ``It doesn't hurt us immediately,'' Aziz said. ``There's still some aid in the pipeline.'' Because of the financial problems, former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto may have found a silver lining in her stunning election defeat Oct. 24. Political analysts and economists say the opposition seats appear to be the safest place in Parliament at the moment. Little was done about the economy for three months after Ishaq Khan dismissed Ms. Bhutto's government Aug. 6 for alleged corruption. The caretaker administration he appointed concentrated on keeping the nation afloat until a new government could be chosen. It refused to increase prices because of the imminent election, paying its bills instead with short-term loans at high interest rates. Now, the economic problems are likely to interfere with the industrial revolution conservative Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif has promised. Even the left saw the victory of Sharif, a wealthy businessman from humble beginnings, as a catalyst for ending centuries of control by the feudal landlords class, to which Ms. Bhutto belongs. Economists say fiscal realism will have to be an essential part of the Sharif government's plans. ``You can't just do things because you want to,'' one said, on condition of anonymity. ``You've got to bite the bullet, increase prices or raise taxes or both.'' Foreign currency reserves have fallen to only $50 million, the inflation rate is rising and another $2 billion has been added to the foreign debt, raising it to about $15.5 billion. A Western economist said the additional debt was largely due to the higher oil price. He said the International Monetary Fund was holding back nearly $300 million until Pakistan improved its economic performance. Aziz said Iraq's invasion of Kuwait nearly four months ago was costing Pakistan about $33 million a month. Sharif initially refused Aziz's request for price increases because most of Pakistan's 110 million people are landless laborers who earn less than $400 dollars a year. Pakistan is one of the largest recipients of international aid, a total of about $3 billion a year. Some senior officials suggested the government might have to suspend payments on the debt, but Aziz said that was not being considered.

DOC.HEAD: Hard Times at the Buenos Aires Zoo
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Rocky the lion roars with hunger and Josefa the polar bear sweats in front of a fan. Porota, the only hippo, stands in a concrete water tank not much larger than she, looking doleful. The Buenos Aires zoo is in bad shape. About 1,800 animals are crowded onto 47 acres of land. The budget of $2 million a year is hardly enough to feed them, let alone provide mates or enough living space and caretakers. ``The worst is that, a year ago, we had to kill the goats and cows to feed other animals,'' said Juan Romero, a veterinarian who is the zoo's director. Five years ago, a hippo died after eating a can and its head was sold for $5,000 to buy food for other animals. Now, the head is displayed in a trendy disco called Hippopotamus. A flamingo choked to death on a coin tossed by a visitor. Toto the giraffe died after swallowing a plastic bag. A condor, used to soaring over mountains, can barely spread his great wings without hitting the bars of his cage. Porota is not the only solitary animal. The zoo also has only one rhinoceros, giraffe and elephant. Replacing animals was too expensive for municipal administrations that suffered inflation, recession and near bankruptcy in recent years. An elephant can cost $70,000 and a rhino $150,000. When it opened 102 years ago, the Buenos Aires zoo was an oasis of shady paths and exotic animals in the noise and pollution of a city that would grow to a population of 10 million. Now, the grass is gone from many enclosures, leaving only dust and concrete. Some buildings are boarded up and there are few attendants to remind visitors not to feed the animals, try to catch them or poke them with sticks. Last month, the city leased the zoo to Gerardo Sofovich, a television host and animal lover, who said he would invest $5 million to buy new animals and spruce the place up. Among his plans are building an aquarium and conducting public education programs about animals and the outdoors. Some critics say Sofovich's motives are more mercenary than philanthropic. They claim his proposed admission fee of about $2 would recoup his investment in a single year and effectively close the zoo to the poor. ``Sofovich ... doesn't want to improve the quality of life of the animals, but rather enrich himself,'' said Raquel Celoria, who leads a neighborhood group opposed to the deal. The Association for the Defense of Animal Rights believes the number of animals should be reduced by half rather than increased. Other opponents cite Sofovich's friendship with President Carlos Menem and zoo director Romero, a former business partner, in claiming favoritism. Romero responded: ``Those who are protesting now, why didn't they do anything when the animals were starving?'' ``People say stupid things,'' Sofovich commented. ``It's not as if we're going to put in a disco, like some people say. We are going to do what ... governments could not'' because they didn't have the money.

DOC.HEAD: George Carlin Finds Co-Star Status in `Trash'
DOC.TEXT: In his new album, George Carlin says he's never sure what he can say, because of the Federal Communications Commission. The FCC once got cranky when a radio station played Carlin's album containing seven naughty words. Ergo, he explains, he has adopted his own policy about things he won't say. He will not, for instance, say ``game plan,'' ``role model,'' ``happy camper,'' ``lifestyle'' or ``moi.'' And ``we will not maximize, prioritize or finalize,'' and ``we definitely will not spend any ... quallllity tiiiime.'' Be that as it may, he thinks he spent quality time on ``Working Trash,'' Fox Broadcasting's first TV movie, airing tonight. Carlin considers it quality time because the film promotes him from character player to co-star as one of two Wall Street janitors who get rich by investing on information they find in company trash. Given the state of Wall Street today, that would seem a sure way to oblivion. No matter. Carlin, 53, considers the co-star part a step up. He doesn't think it's a bit late in the game for him. ``It would be if I'd been chomping at the bit all this time,'' said Carlin, who wears T-shirts that say New York Police Bomb Squad but speaks seriously in interviews. At such times, he doesn't play the foole, as he likes to spell it. ``I put my acting desires aside in the late '60s when I found I really wasn't very good at it,'' he said. ``It had been my plan from childhood to become a radio disc jockey, then a stand-up comedian, then a Danny Kaye, Bob Hope or Red Skelton kind of actor. ``But when I tried that ... I just lacked confidence.'' In his defense, Carlin's first time was in the Marlo Thomas sitcom, ``That Girl.'' In recent years, though, matters have improved, namely well-received character turns as Rufus in ``Bill and Ted's Excellent Adventure'' and the soused old-hippie guide of ``Outrageous Fortune.'' ``What's nice about approaching it at this age is that I bring a lot more seasoning to my acting,'' he said, ``and it gives me a career to look forward to.'' A New Yorker, Carlin has lived in Los Angeles since 1966. As two generations of comics since have done, he went to Hollywood to grab the brass sitcom ring. He was one of the early hipster comics, a coffee-house graduate, a guy who loved word-play - still does - and, as the '60s heated up, developed social and political edges to his humor. A far cry from what some call ``brick-wall comics,'' the new wave of sitcom aspirants who wear black and usually appear on cable against a nightclub's brick wall, discussing relationships, flossing and Los Angeles freeways. He's kindly, if ambivalent, about them, even those who are somewhat to the left of whoopee: ``They have at least a few minutes that's interesting and worthwhile, and I find myself glad I hear that part.'' Aren't they a little, er, blah, though? He shrugs. ``Well, there are so many,'' he said. ``It (comedy) has become a cottage industry in a way. It's just the sheer numbers that would dictate a certain sameness.'' Despite all that, he keeps working in comedy, although in venues where he now, for a night's work, earns what one might call a bundle. He does at least 110 concerts a year, he said, and has taped seven Home Box Office specials. And then there are the comedy albums. Last week, he released his 14th. It's entitled ``Parental Advisory: Explicit Lyrics.'' The album has no lyrics, technically speaking, but does have a certain amount of raunch. The title comes from the sticker some record labels put on their albums when the records are of 2 Live Crew nature. ``I just thought using that sticker as the entire album label was the appropriate thing to do,'' he said, alluding to groups that have loudly protested what they call obscenity in rap and other kinds of music. ``Because as long as you're going to have to deal with these people ... you might as well mock them. So the whole album is one large warning sticker.'' Carlin wasn't pressured to make his album cover a warning label. He owns the company that made the album. It's called Eardrum Records. He grinned. ``Our slogan,'' he said, ``is `Stick it in your ear.' '' --- Elsewhere in television ... REASONS NO. 396 and 396.5 TO CONTINUE BREATHING: The syndicated ``The Joan Rivers Show'' has been renewed for a third season, an tonight's edition of the syndicated ``Geraldo'' will do sort of a ``The Big Chill'' number. The series' host, Geraldo Rivera, is devoting the entire show to his reflections on the '60s - you know, stuff like Vietnam, civil rights and the Beatles. He uses as a starting point his return to the University of Arizona, his alma mater, for a 25th anniversary class reunion. A press release on tonight's show says viewers also will see the school's homecoming queen of 1965, ``the girl Geraldo admired from afar, but never had the courage to ask for a date.''

DOC.HEAD: Author Preaches Gospel Of Debt-Free Living
DOC.TEXT: Marc Eisenson has an important message for Americans: Do yourself, your country and your grandchildren a big favor and pay a few more dollars on your monthly bills. Make it a habit. The withering industrial base, the federal deficit, the savings and loan crisis and even Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait make it more imperative than ever that Americans get out of debt, Eisenson says. ``It just makes it clear that future stability is not assured,'' Eisenson said of world events. ``If I am out of debt I can weather a lot of storms.'' Americans owe $2.4 trillion in mortgage debt and another $729 billion in consumer credit bills, Federal Reserve figures show. Ironically, those big mortgages provide many people with their greatest opportunity to save money. According to Eisenson, no investment - not Treasury bonds, not the stock market - is more lucrative in the long run than simply spending money to retire debts. That allows people to avoid interest payments that run around 20 percent on many credit cards. ``If you were to bring your balance down it's like earning 20 percent with your money,'' said Eisenson. ``Twenty percent is more than Donald Trump can earn safely. It is absolutely guaranteed, risk-free. And it is available to only those who are, unfortunately or fortunately, in debt.'' Eisenson calls his system debt management, and insists it holds the key to happiness and financial security for millions of Americans. The concept is especially effective when applied to long-term debt, such as mortgages. Paying a few dollars extra a month can take thousands of dollars and years off a typical mortgage. At 10 percent, a $75,000 mortgage takes 30 years to pay and winds up costing the borrower a total of $237,000. By paying just $25 a month extra, a person can save $34,000 and take five years off the mortgage, according to Eisenson's formula. Pay $100 a month extra and save $78,000 and 12 years off the same mortgage. ``Get in the habit of debt management. I don't care how strapped you are, you can pay some money, even an extra five or 10 dollars,'' said Eisenson. ``You can start the process to free yourself of debt with very little money, the kind of money everybody has got.'' Eisenson said he learned his debt-free values from his parents, who lived fairly simple lives. His brother taught him how to apply those values to mortgages, and he paid off a 30-year mortgage in five years at age 27. A former electrical engineer, Eisenson, 47, has devoted the last fifteen years to developing his debt management system. That system is spelled out in The Banker's Secret, a 233-page book published this year by Villard Books, a division of Random House. Before the book, Eisenson delivered his message through a constantly evolving booklet. Along with his partner, Nancy Castleman, Eisenson has also developed a computer program to allow consumers to tailor prepayment plans to their individual needs. ``We're zealots. We want to change the world. We want to reach every homeowner in America with our message. It's just crazy to give $34,000 or more to a bank when you could use that money to put kids through college or finance your retirement,'' said Castleman. ``How many homeowners are there in this country with mortgages? That's how many people we want to reach.'' Too many Americans do not understand the mechanics of debt and how easily they can avoid thousands of dollars in interest by paying more than the minimum each month, Eisenson said. ``Most people just don't understand it is something they can really use,'' Eisenson said. ``Without making any significant change in the short term, without going without, people can dramatically change their lives in the long term.'' Lately, people are more receptive to his message. ``People are no longer in the spend generation,'' he said. ``Many are in financial trouble or on the edge of it. A lot of people really do begin to prepay and it makes a significant difference in their lives.'' --- Editor's Note: The telephone number for The Banker's Secret book and software program is 1-800-255-0899.

DOC.HEAD: Just in Time for the Holidays: Two Explicit Rap Compilations
DOC.TEXT: Two record companies, cranking up the volume in the ongoing music censorship battle, are asking music fans to buy new albums because of their explicit lyrics, not in spite of them. Released just in time for holiday gift-giving, two rap compilations are bound to reignite the furor over profane lyrics that surrounded 2 Live Crew's trial last month on charges of performing obscene material at a Florida nightclub. The rap group was acquitted. Priority Records says its ``Explicit Rap'' compilation was released for political reasons, while organizers of Reprise Records' ``2 Nasty 4 Radio'' cited business motives. ``The only difference between a CD of this stuff and cocaine is you can't fit it up your nose,'' Jack Thompson, the Florida lawyer who crusaded against 2 Live Crew, said of the new albums. The new records have brought charges from within the rap community that some artists are just trying to cash in on a controversy that has made the front pages. Among the featured songs on ``Explicit Rap'' are 2 Live Crew's ``Me So Horny'' and a handful of profanity-laced raps against the censorship movement. On ``2 Nasty 4 Radio'' a rapper in the number ``Talk Like Sex'' brags that his sexual prowess will leave his partner looking like a rape victim. The cover of ``Explicit Rap'' is a blown-up version of the sticker that the recording industry devised this year to warn parents against explicit lyrics. All profits from the album's sale will be donated to music critic Dave Marsh's ``Right to Rock Network,'' an organization fighting censorship, said Priority spokeswoman Lillian Matulic. ``It's not just about cussing,'' Matulic said. ``It's a statement.'' Along with being intentionally provocative, Marsh said the album - featuring artists like Ice-T, N.W.A., the Geto Boys and Ice Cube - contains some of the most exciting rock 'n' roll being made today. The New York City rap label Cold Chillin' Records, which has a distribution deal with WEA label Reprise, initially designed its compilation as a forum for new songs by its artists, said Tyrone Williams, Cold Chillin' chairman. WEA suggested the ``2 Nasty 4 Radio'' concept, he said. Williams said he tried to downplay the profanity, asking rapper Roxanne Shante to change the name of her new song to ``Brothers Ain't Slick'' instead of the profane alternative. Shante refused. But Williams and rappers Kool G Rap and MC Shan defended ``2 Nasty 4 Radio'' as giving consumers what they want in a package that's going to attract attention. Kids who attend his performances chant for his more obscene material, Shan said. He's happy to oblige. ``That's just us expressing what we see, feel and how we do things. They (the fans) love thumpin' that in the jeeps, in the cars.'' Jon Shecter, editor of The Source, a rap music magazine, said the Priority Records compilation is the more valuable of the two musically. But he said both albums represent blatant attempts to cash in on the controversy. He said they would hurt the cause of rap music and predicted they wouldn't sell that well. ``I don't think rap fans really want to hear that,'' Shecter said. ``Rap fans want to hear good music. If it happens to have profanity on it, that's part of the package.'' Thompson, the lawyer who led the anti-2 Live Crew crusade, said he found these albums even more abhorrent than 2 Live Crew's material because obscenity is the whole point of the records instead of a byproduct of the work. He predicted that the record companies would face obscenity charges over the material and that anti-censorship forces will regret picking a fight over these albums. But Marsh, whose organization distributes pamphlets and organizes local anti-censorship movements across the country, said it's important to have the showdown now. ``It's time to spit in the eye of the censors,'' Marsh said. ``It's time to stop acting timid and start being bold about what the real issue is - the real issue is free speech. ``Every store that carries this record is making a statement that they know what the score is, that they know the warning label is a joke. It's a front for censorship, not some parental warning. ... Maybe, in fact, it ought to become a badge of honor.''

DOC.HEAD: Oscar-Winning Director of `Cinema Paradiso' Releases New Film
LaserPhoto
By MARY BETH SHERIDAN
DOC.TEXT: Giuseppe Tornatore remembers his low point. A film on which he had worked for years closed after a few days. Producers were cool. Friends were politely suggesting a career change. ``Instead of committing suicide, I wrote a new film,'' he said, laughing. Two years after that dark period, the 34-year-old Tornatore is being hailed as Italy's hottest new director in a decade. The film that flopped in 1988, ``Cinema Paradiso,'' went on to win him an Oscar in 1990. And the movie written ``in a moment of my life in which things were bad'' is being released in a moment in which things couldn't be better. ``Everything has gone so well,'' said the grinning, baby-faced director, his eyes sparkling behind horn-rimmed glasses. ``I'm sorry there was so much delay.'' Two years after its dismal debut, ``Cinema Paradiso'' is alive and well in Italian cinemas, and has drawn crowds in Europe, Japan and the United States. Now, the question is whether Tornatore can succeed again, and prove himself an heir to Federico Fellini, Bernardo Bertolucci and other great Italian directors. His new film, ``Stanno Tutti Bene'' (They're All Fine), produced by Angelo Rizzoli, has just been released in Italy and is due to open in the United States in February. It tells of an elderly man's journey through Italy to visit his five widely scattered children, whom he wants to reunite for a dinner. The father, played by Marcello Mastroianni, is chagrined to discover that his children have drifted from him and have hidden their failures at work and in marriage. ``I wanted to make a film about the difficulty there is today in personal communication,'' said Tornatore, sipping mineral water in a cafe near his apartment by the Vatican wall. ``We live in an era of communication, of mass media. But the nearer we move to events, the more difficult it is to communicate'' with people. While the film displays Tornatore's keen eye for the Italian character and for day-to-day human comedy, it is more melancholy than ``Cinema Paradiso,'' a semiautobiographical tale of a child enraptured by the silver screen. ``Stanno Tutti Bene'' was written ``in a moment of my life in which things were bad. I identified with the moods of people, especially those who were suffering, and also their failures,'' Tornatore said. A movie buff who began making documentaries at age 20, Tornatore already had two films to his credit - ``La Camorrista'' (The Camorra Member) and ``Cinema Paradiso.'' But they made little money. ``Cinema Paradiso,'' a cherished personal project, attracted little notice and quickly closed. Tornatore feared he would no longer be able to make his own films. But then ``Cinema Paradiso'' won an award at the 1989 Cannes Film Festival and returned to movie theaters. It went on to become the first Italian film to win Best Foreign Film at the Academy Awards since Fellini's ``Amarcord'' in 1975. ``I am happy because what happened was important,'' he said. He added, however, that now ``I don't have any more time ... not even to know if I'm fine or not.'' The idea for ``They're All Fine'' came about four years ago when Tornatore saw a dignified elderly man with a suitcase eating alone in a Roman trattoria. ``I thought to myself, `Where is he going?' I invented the idea that he was searching for his kids.'' The father's personal saga has modern Italy as its backdrop, peopled by power-obsessed young professionals, African immigrants sleeping in cardboard boxes and elderly parents closeted in retirement homes by their children. Tornatore, who like the father comes from a Sicilian town, objects to an urban society that has allowed answering machines and television to eclipse human conservation. ``I was conscious of the fact that during the day I call Paris or Tokyo or send faxes. Sometimes I make friendships by fax, without ever seeing the person's face,'' said Tornatore. ``Then when I return home, I don't know who lives next door. ... The long distances have shrunk. The small distances have become longer.'' He said the film's title sums up the gloss we use to cover the difficulties of modern-day society. ``It's a phrase we say every day. We are all always just too happy,'' he said. ``There's no one who says, `I'm not fine.'' ``Maybe it's a world of hidden unhappiness. Maybe it's easier to finish it there - people prefer to say something uncomplicated. .. . It's very symptomatic of this era.''

DOC.HEAD: Recession May Be As Difficult As Political Problems
DOC.TEXT: South Africa faces economic problems that are intertwined with the black-white political conflict and may be as difficult to solve. A year-old recession is expected to last through 1991. Unemployment is rising, black shantytowns are expanding and whites are joining the lines at soup kitchens. Economics has become a major part of the debate on South Africa's future. Government officials and most other whites say capitalism is the quickest route to prosperity for all. The African National Congress and other anti-apartheid groups, particularly labor unions, favor socialism and demand a major redistribution of the wealth controlled by whits. ``The economic debate is likely to become a great deal more heated if South Africa shifts ... to long-term stagflation,'' said Business Day, the country's leading financial daily. ``The merits of a market economy are less obvious when a stagnant economy ... is accompanied by ever rising prices.'' South Africa's economy is the strongest and most diverse on an impoverished continent, but is expected to shrink about 2 percent this year and not to grow in 1991. With the population increasing at more than 2 percent a year, President F.W. de Klerk says the economy needs at least 5 percent annual growth if living conditions for blacks are to improve substantially. As the economy declines, black expectations are rising with de Klerk's political reforms and his promise to dismantle the apartheid system of racial segregation. Blacks in South Africa have long equated apartheid with capitalism and many expect a new political system to bring major economic changes. For many blacks, that means socialism despite its failure in Eastern Europe and elsewhere in Africa. Annual per capita income for South African blacks is equivalent to more than $1,000, making it one of Africa's highest figures but only a fraction of what the average South African white earns. No accurate unemployment figures are available, but private economists say the rate is at least 15 percent for blacks and that 20 percent to 30 percent more are underemployed. In the southern city of Port Elizabeth, black unemployment is almost 50 percent. Operation Hunger, which feeds needy blacks in rural areas, estimates it is helping 1.5 million people, up from about 1 million at the start of 1990. ``We are getting more requests for help than ever before,'' said Bernie Cohen, financial director of the 10-year-old organization. John Rees, who runs the Methodist Care food distribution project in Johannesburg, said growing numbers of whites are losing their jobs and seeking assistance. De Klerk's government recently conceded that the black housing shortage, a perennial crisis, is getting worse as 1 million blacks a year move to cities in search of work. About 7 million of the country's 30 million blacks already live in shacks they built themselves, private groups report. The government speaks of spending more to improve black living conditions, but supports a huge bureaucracy created by apartheid. About one of every three working whites is employed by the government. Much of the bureaucracy is duplicated in a system that has separate branches for whites, blacks, Asains and people of mixed race, plus separate structures in the 10 black homelands. Strikes by black workers have increased as unions demand higher wages from white managements accustomed to cheap labor. Gold mining, for example, faces a combination of rapidly rising costs and a stagnant world price. South Africa is the world's largest producer of gold, which provides more than 40 percent of its export earnings, but many of its mines are among the world's deepest and most expensive to operate. Gold is hovering at about $380 an ounce on world markets. The magazine Financial Mail said ``the industry will continue to battle'' as long as the price stays under $400, and ``this will ripple through the economy as recession deepens.'' An estimated 31,000 of the 500,000 workers in gold mining have lost their jobs in the past year and about 15 mines are in financial trouble, according to the Chamber of Mines, an umbrella group of leading companies. Foreign economic sanctions imposed because of apartheid also have hurt, but no one can say exactly how much. Sanctions have shut off loans from internatonal lending agencies, and more than half of the 300 U.S. companies that did business in South Africa five years ago have left. The ANC, the main black opposition group, wants sanctions to continue as a way to keep pressure on the government, but plans to review its policy in light of de Klerk's reforms and the worsening economy.

DOC.HEAD: Low Cholesterol Steaks From Cattle Brought by Columbus
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Maybe Columbus didn't really discover America - the locals met him on the beach - but he brought a hedge against cholesterol 500 years before everybody started worrying about it. Argentine ranchers believe criollos, descendants of the hardy cattle Columbus carried across the sea, can be the basis of new crossbreeds that will produce leaner steaks for a diet-conscious age. ``Columbus brought the first cattle to the New World on his second voyage in 1493, and more on his third and fourth trips,'' said Dr. Sol L. Rabasa, a genetecist. ``You can accurately say the animals that subsequently populated the Americas, from the Texas longhorn in the north to what we call criollo cattle in Latin America, are their direct descendants.'' Rabasa is president of the 6-year-old Argentine Criollo Cattle Breeders Association, which is rescuing criollos from near-extinction, and breeds them on his ranch near Villa Canas, 185 miles west of Buenos Aires. He said the criollo and its crossbreeds convert food to muscle efficiently and produce leaner meat with less marbled fat. The Spanish word criollo is used throughout Latin America to denote people or animals born in the Americas of European parentage. Despite nearly five centuries of independent development, Rabasa said, the Texas longhorn and Argentine criollo have the same long, angular, short-haired body and the same colors - brown, red or piebald. Carlos E. Dawney, a rancher and association officer, said the only real difference is in the horns that give the Texas breed its name - ``often 60 inches from tip to tip, longer than ours.'' Rabasa believes Columbus chose the cattle from the arid regions near Spain's southern ports, selecting animals that were ``gentle for easy handling and hardy to stand the long trip in cramped quarters.'' They were used to establish breeding herds on Cuba and Hispanola in the Caribbean. From there, they were taken to Mexico, the Isthmus of Panama and to Peru for distribution through Spain's South American colonies. Criollos arrived in Argentina in the mid-1500s and soon multiplied into tens of thousands on the pampa, one of the world's finest natural grazing lands. Argentina exported hides, but there was no way to preserve meat for export and most of it was left to rot. Faster ships and use of salt as a preservative made ranching highly profitable by the 1830s. To boost production, cattlemen imported such faster-growing British breeds as the Hereford, shorthorn and Aberdeen Angus. Zebu breeds from India, slow-growing and tough but resistant to heat and disease, were introduced in semitropical northern Argentina. Soon the criollo was seen as inferior and began to disappear, absorbed by the herds of newcomers or banished to the least hospitable areas. Rabasa, 75, is a former university rector noted for research. He became interested in the criollo's potential 20 years ago when ranchers asked him about the possibility of crossing it with Zebu cattle. ``I had to tell them I didn't know, and we set out to find some evidence,'' he said in an interview. A herd of Zebu-criollo crossbreeds was discovered on a ranch in northwest Chaco province, and ``we found their production levels and meat quality were surprisingly good,'' Rabasa said. Years of research by Rabasa and the National Institute of Agricultural Technology followed, crossing the criollo with Zebu and British breeds. Studies showed the criollo still had the gentleness prized by Columbus, combined with superior fertility, body structure that facilitates calving, resistance to disease and good milk production, Rabasa said. ``The criollo calf gets up as soon as it is born and begins to drink its mother's milk, allowing the mother to pass more of her protective antibodies on to the calf during the first 24 hours,'' he said. ``The other breeds are slower to react and their calves receive fewer antibodies.'' Skin and eye pigmentation protect criollos and their crossbreeds from cancers, conjunctivitis and other ailments provoked by the bright sunlight prevalent in much of the Americas, the geneticist said. Criollos also need water less often and can spend more time searching for food over a larger area, making them ideal for marginal land. Rabasa and his associates began a search for pure criollos remaining in Argentina. They found them in pockets of the arid, thorn-forested Chaco and in La Rioja, a desert province. A wild herd turned up in the Glaciers National Park of southern Patagonia's Andean foothills about 185 miles from the Strait of Magellan. Registered criollo cattle now number between 1,000 and 2,000 and about 50 commercial herds use them as breeding stock. Rabasa said efforts to preserve criollo cattle are under way in other countries, including the United States, ``where a gread deal is being done.''

DOC.HEAD: Farmers Join U.N. Project for Alternative Crops
DOC.TEXT: LA ASUNTA, Bolivia (AP)- The coca boom is over and Armando Chavez is learning to grow something else. Chavez, an Aymara Indian, is one of thousands of farmers in this remote Andean region who are making the transition to coffee, fruit, soybeans and other crops with the help of a U.N. project. He said the program ``is like a dream to us. Now we have advisers, fertilizer and insecticies. They have introduced soybeans, built schools and roads. If the project left the area, we would be like orphans.'' The U.N. project is the cornerstone of a Bolivian government effort to wean farmers away from coca, the base of cocaine. ``Our purpose is to change the illicit economy created by the coca-cocaine axis (and) enable farmers to diversify their crops,'' Oswaldo Antezana, undersecretary of the interior for alternative development, said in an interview. ``Before, farmers were antagonistic.'' Chavez, 39, his wife and four children live in an adobe hut on a tree-covered hill outside La Asunta, a town of dirt streets and more tin-roofed adobe huts. It is near the Yungas, a coca-producing region in the subtropical Andean foothills east of La Paz. A four-wheel-drive vehicle needs seven hours to cover the 150 miles from La Paz to La Asunta. The narrow road runs along sheer cliffs hundreds of feet above cascading rivers that feed the Amazon. Farmers get from the road to fields across the chasms in makeshift conveyances suspended from cables. Many of them suffer from yellow fever or tuberculosis. When the cocaine boom began in the late 1970s, coca production spread from the Yungas to La Asunta. Migrants from the highlands and the Yungas moved in, cleared the forests and planted coca for sale to traffickers. The area became a no man's land where outsiders, particular police, were not welcome. Chavez moved to La Asunta 11 years ago, hoping coca would improve his lot. Then coca prices started down two years ago and he decided to call it quits, because ``there is a law requiring the reduction of coca and we cannot live only from coca.'' ``When prices dropped below the cost of production, it wasn't even worth harvesting the leaf,'' he said. Prices were driven down, in part, because of the Colombian government's crackdown on cocaine traffickers last year and increased interdiction activities in Bolivia. Chavez heads one of the seven community development centers in La Asunta that receive financial and technical support from the U.N. project. His center is introducing the raising of pigs and fish, and the cultivation of coffee, soybeans, spices and fruit. Veterinarians, agronomists and health workers assist farmers through the centers. Jairo Morales Nieto, chief tecnical adviser on the U.N. project, said the centers are involved in product development, production and marketing, as well as in training the farmers. ``In contrast to many other rural areas in Latin America, in Bolivia there is a remarkably organized peasant social base'' and peasant organizations have worked effectively for their members' interests, he said. Farmers get a credit of $2,000 for every hectare - about 2{ acres - of coca they destroy. Loans, seeds and fertilizer are provided as farmers progress in planting new crops and raising animals. Because one of the main problems in remote regions has been getting products to market, the U.N. project has financed new roads. Two years ago, it took eight hours in good weather to travel between La Asunta and Chulumani, a market town about 70 miles to the south, and longer in the rain. Now it takes three hours. The U.N. Fund for Drug Abuse Control has spent $21 million on the project, which has helped 150,000 farmers since it began in 1985. The money runs out this year, but the government hopes for an extension. ``As long as coca cultivation increases in the region, there is a greater possibility'' of cocaine traffickers and violence moving in, said Arturo Villanueva, an adviser who showed visitors experimental shrimp tanks financed by the project. An estimated 125,000 acres are devoted to coca cultivation in Bolivia. The government hopes to cut that to about 30,000, which is considered sufficient for the leaf's traditional applications. Coca is used as a medicine, in religious rituals, as a tea and is chewed by farmers and miners to help counteract the effects of high altitude and hunger. Two-thirds of Bolivian coca is grown in the Chapare, a flat tropical region east of La Asunta. Both the United Nations and United States are financing alternative development programs there, but with less success than in La Asunta. Bolivian farmers have destroyed a record 20 percent of the country's coca crop since October 1989. ``We have learned to establish a clear distinction between the peasants and the drug dealers,'' said Morales Nieto, the U.N. technical adviser. ``Generally, the peasants want to abide by the law.''

DOC.HEAD: Artisans Reprise Great Moment, Re-creating Tut's Tomb
LaserPhoto planned
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Artisans are re-creating one of the great moments of archaeology on an island south of Cairo. On Nov. 26, 1922, English archaeologist Howard Carter opened the tomb of the boy Pharaoh Tutankhamun and found a glittering world of delicate statues, inlaid chests, feather-light fans and decorated coffins of solid gold. The riches he discovered amazed the world. Now, 68 years after Carter peered into the small tomb in southern Egypt, the artisans are fashioning Tut's netherworld once again, working from photographs and other records. The replicas of Tut's treasures are to be entombed as the archaeologist saw them. Twenty-two artists, sculptors, engineers and university students are rekindling craftsmanship unseen since the days of the Pharaohs. They are halfway through their assignment: to duplicate his four-chambered tomb and 1,000 of the 1,703 Tut objects in the Egyptian Museum, as they were left by priests 3,313 years ago and the robbers who came later. Ever-watchful jackals, goddesses in sleek gowns, open-mouthed lions and even the boy Pharaoh himself, out for a walk in thonged sandals, cram the bustling workshop on Jacob's Island. A year from now, every day on Jacob's Island will be Nov. 26, 1922. Until then, people wanting to marvel at King Tut's storied world must travel to the two places they have visited for decades: the treasure hoard in Cairo's Egyptian Museum and his tomb, with the mummy, 450 miles to the south, in the Valley of the Kings. ``It's the wonder that we must produce in our tomb - the shock, which you don't feel when you see the objects away from the tomb,'' said Mahmoud Mabrouk, a sculptor and art professor who directs the Jacob's Island project. ``We work as a team, just as the ancients did,'' he said. Novices think Tut's treasures were all of solid gold. There was plenty of that, but there also were objects of wood, silver and other metals, alabaster, ivory, leopard skins, leather, pottery and gemstones. Decisions on whether to replicate individual items, big or small, were based on whether they were important to history or to art knowledge. The project is costing 1 million Egyptian pounds (almost $360,000) and is the brainchild of former diplomat Hassan Ragab, an entrepreneur who revived Egypt's extinct papyrus industry. In 1985 he opened his Pharaonic Village on Jacob's Island, where tourists come to view life from the days of King Tut, but without the boy Pharaoh himself. ``Dr. Ragab asked me to create a full-scale tomb with exact copies of objects so that tourists would feel the wonder as Carter felt it,'' Mabrouk said. ``The tomb was no problem, but nobody knew how to make the objects. Everybody I talked with told me to refuse the offer.'' Mabrouk, who advises an international committee working to save the Sphinx, said he accepted the challenge for two reasons. ``First, I wanted to enter the mind of the ancient artist,'' he said. ``What kind of people were these, to create things so beautiful, but things that would never be seen by the living? ``Today, we artists have exhibitions and everybody congratulates us. Not these artists. Their creations were locked up with Tut.'' The second reason harks back to Mabrouk's childhood. ``I was 12 when my brother and I saw the Tut collection in the museum,'' he said. ``We were so happy, but we were sad. The objects were beautiful, but nobody knew anything about them.'' ``I want Egyptian youth to look back on their history with a sense of pride, a sense of identity. It's an Arab problem that Egyptians turn their backs on anything about the Pharaohs.'' Mabrouk said he is astounded by the quality of Tut relics. ``We had to start with the simplest items,'' he said. ``Once we mastered the techniques, we could tackle the most difficult.'' Reproduction has been made more difficult because objects in the museum must be examined from behind glass and many Tut objects are locked in storerooms. Books contain conflicting information, and Mabrouk said many of Carter's notes are inaccurate. Even lowly artifacts proved tricky. A simple pair of sandals took three months to reproduce. Many of the 50 alabaster items from the tomb were lovingly worked with exquisite designs. Alabaster posed one of the toughest challenges. ``We spent six months working in alabaster factories outside the Valley of the Kings, just to see how to use the stone,'' Mabrouk said. ``We finally made three simple vases, but even that took a month.'' Still to come are Tutankhamun's gold death mask and the elaborately inlaid gold sarcophagus. ``Sometimes you just have to compromise,'' Mabrouk said. ``We'll use gold-plated copper instead of gold, but the effect will be the same.''
