DOC.HEAD: Milken, Bad Housing Numbers and More Bankruptcies
DOC.TEXT: A running news story became an entry for the history books this past week when a federal judge sentenced junk-bond financier Michael Milken to 10 years in prison. Even though the former master of the universe for Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. probably will serve only a fraction of the term, the severity of the judge's pronouncement punctuated the Milken tale with an exclamation point. There should be no doubt in anyone's mind - nor in the minds of those who study his case years from now - that this was a stunning comeuppance. A man who had been portrayed by some as the most influential financial figure of modern times got more jail time than some hardened criminals. The unmistakable message from U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood, just two years older than the 44-year-old Milken, was that white-collar crime should not pay. Milken made more than $1 billion peddling high-yield junk bonds for Drexel, and remains among the country's richest people even after paying $600 million in fines and restitution as part of his plea agreement to six felony charges. Despite his wealth, the Manhattan courtroom scene reduced the larger-than-life Milken to more human proportions. It proved a strange ending to an era of excess in the financial world. Once Milken found himself in the company of adoring elders in the highest ranks of corporate America as he charted a course for restructuring companies with huge amounts of debt. On Wednesday, he was humbled in front of a contemporary judge, who said he had misused his ``leadership position'' and should be ``removed from society.'' As the case was debated before and after the sentencing, Milken was alternately praised by supporters as a wizard and blamed by detractors for everything from Drexel's own collapse to the recent downturn in the economy. But Judge Wood's sentence struck with a force that diluted the celebrity and left just a man who would leave a wife and a family and go to prison next March. Milken was not vindicated, as he had hoped he would be, and the decade of greed that he symbolized seemed to be banished to the dark past.
DOC.HEAD: ECONOMY: Housing Numbers Extend Slide
DOC.TEXT: It was a light, but characteristically depressing, week for economic reports. The government said home building plunged 6 percent in October, extending the slide in the construction business to nine months, the longest on record. Housing starts have sunk to the lowest level since the last recession in 1982. Analysts said the industry was battered from two sides by sagging consumer confidence and tight credit. Many said the malaise would linger well into 1991. With the evidence of recession rising, so did the rhetoric from Washington. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady urged regulators not to overreact to the softening economy by discouraging banks from making reasonable loans. ``Use some judgment. Apply some balance,'' he implored bank examiners. Meanwhile, President Bush's chief economist, Michael Boskin, exercised some damage control of his own after his boss used the word ``downturn'' to describe the economy's shape. Boskin allowed that current conditions were sluggish, but he said it would be premature to declare a recession. There was no denying a recession on Wall Street, however. The Securities Industry Association said profits in the business totaled an anemic $200 million in the first six months of 1990 and have deteriorated since. The trade group said the sum was ``not equivalent to a single decent bond issue a few years ago.''
DOC.HEAD: COMPANIES: Laventhol Files for Bankruptcy, Greyhound Plan Proposed
DOC.TEXT: The nation's seventh-largest accounting firm, Laventhol & Horwath, sought refuge in bankrupcty court under fire from lawsuits seeking damages from dissatisfied clients. Robert Levine, the firm's executive partner and chief executive officer, said the Chapter 11 filing was prompted by ``a series of tragic circumstances.'' Among them was a $30 million payment to creditor banks last year - of which only $18.5 million was covered by insurance - over an audit for the Grabill Corp. of Chicago. Laventhol audits of Jim Bakker's PTL ministry also ended up in court in North Carolina. The firm's problems were among the most severe in an industry increasingly plagued by malpractice litigation. Laventhol said some of its partners would continue servicing clients independently to help pay off debts. In another Chapter 11 case, Greyhound Lines Inc. filed a plan of reorganization with a Texas court that would erase the equity of the current owners and issue new stock to the firm's unsecured creditors. The plan also promised full repayment of secured bank debt, real estate mortgages and bus leases. But the bus line must still satisfy its drivers, who have been on strike since March and have protested their treatment to the National Labor Relations Board. The drivers could propose a reorganization plan of their own. CBS Inc. said it expected a loss in the fourth quarter and lower earnings in 1991. The broadcasting company blamed the deteriorating picture on the poor advertising climate and disappointing returns from its expensive venture into sports programming. The disclosure of the projected loss came just before the network went before affiliates to propose a reduction in the amount of money it will pay local stations to carry national programming.
DOC.HEAD: MANVILLE: Beginning of the End for Claimants
DOC.TEXT: A plan was proposed for restructuring the finances of the Manville trust to try to meet claims by thousands of Americans made sick by working with asbestos. The plan was aimed at resolving the fund's cash crisis and breaking a logjam of asbestos claims in the courts. It proposes to pump up the fund with more money and pay the neediest cases first. Asbestos, once considered a miracle fiber, caused thousands of deaths from lung cancer and other ailments. The resulting lawsuits sent several companies into bankruptcy court and clogged court dockets nationwide. The $2.5 billion Manville trust was set up after Manville Corp., once the leading producer of asbestos, reorganized under bankruptcy court supervision in 1988. Already, the trust has paid more than $1.1 billion to settle about 23,000 claims, but faces another 130,000 cases. The restructuring plan, which must be reviewed by a judge and will likely be appealed, requires Manville Corp. to provide an additional $520 million to the fund over seven years. Claimants would be paid based on the severity of their illnesses. Lawyers' fees - one of the most controversial elements of the asbestos issue - would be capped at 25 percent of their clients' settlements.
DOC.HEAD: NO MIRAGE: One Gaming House Doing OK
DOC.TEXT: Even as Donald Trump struggled to keep control of his highly leveraged Taj Mahal casino in Atlantic City, Steve Wynn was showing off a beautiful hand at his Mirage Hotel in Las Vegas. The Mirage turned a year old, and Wynn took the opportunity to ballyhoo his first-year results, which ran about 50 percent above projections. He said hotel revenues the first year would approach $650 million. Between 25,000 and 45,000 people visit the Mirage daily, surpassing Hoover Dam as the most popular attraction in Southern Nevada.

DOC.HEAD: Recession Shuffles Old Investment Recipes
DOC.TEXT: By the time the current economic downturn runs its course, some Wall Street analysts contend, it could shake up the way many people think about American investments. For example, they suggest, just suppose that recession and a change in attitudes toward the use of credit bring about a long-lasting decline in interest rates. Bonds might lose their modern image as volatile securities and return to something at least a little like the slow-and-stodgy days of yore. Real estate, even with lower mortgage interest rates, might emerge lacking some of the luster it acquired over the past two decades as a prime beneficiary of an inflation-driven economy. Money-market mutual funds, Treasury bills, and other short-term interest-bearing investments could also fade from their present exalted status as their yields declined. As for stocks - well, just possibly they could flourish, provided the business world was able to find and develop important new sources of growth. Of course, all this is conjecture akin to a long-range weather forecast, based on a series of assumptions and interpretations that have not yet been tested by the course of real-world events. The prospect of a sustained drop in interest rates by itself is far from an accepted idea. Still, visions of this sort serve at least one present purpose - challenging any presumptions that the nation is simply going through a down cycle that will reliably give way sooner or later to a return of business-as-before on Wall Street. ``We argue that today's recession will complete the job that began at the outset of the 1980s,'' says Robert J. Barbera, economist at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. in a current appraisal of the outlook. ``Inflation collapsed after the economic downturns early in the decade, but inflation psychology lingered. Debt usage - a bet that inflation would return - thrived despite low inflation. ``High real short-term interest rates were necessary to contain U.S. economic growth in a debt-addicted society. Today, however, both borrowers and lenders are much more circumspect about the use of debt.'' Signs of at least a short-term drop in rates have lifted investors' spirits of late, although that mood of optimism seemed to be on hold in the past week. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials closed Friday at 2,527.23, down 23.02 points from the week before. The New York Stock Exchange composite index slipped .91 to 172.39; the NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market dropped 1.81 to 349.04, and the American Stock Exchange market value index was down 1.62 at 295.90. In holiday-dampened activity, volume on the Big Board averaged 126.53 million shares a day, down from 163.55 million the week before. To some observers, such as the economists S. Jay Levy and David Levy in Chappaqua, N.Y., it won't be easy to get U.S. business growing vigorously again even on the far side of the recession. ``The excesses of the 1980s are being paid for in the 1990s,'' the Levys declare. ``A decade's profligacy cannot be overcome quickly.'' Says Barbera: ``We completely agree with the idea that the 30-year debt cycle is ending and that attitudes about borrowing and lending are going through a metamorphosis. ``But we are also confident that at some point, interest rate declines will rekindle both borrowing and building before recession turns into depression. ``Debt's demise promises an end to the artificially high real short-term interest rates witnessed in the 1980s,'' he concludes. ``Long-term financial assets - stocks and bonds - will thrive in an environment of sharply lower rates.''

DOC.HEAD: Milken Could Reduce Term With Cooperation
DOC.TEXT: While the demise of junk bond financier Michael Milken symbolizes an era gone sour, his cooperation with prosecutors could lead to another round of high-profile Wall Street cases, lawyers said. U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood, who sentenced Milken to an unexpectedly harsh 10 years in prison and three years' probation, held open the possibility of reducing the term to reward cooperation. Milken associates said Thursday that the ex-head of junk bond trading at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., whose ideas about debt reshaped U.S. corporate finance in the 1980s, was devastated by the sentence. Milken, 44, and his wife, Lori, returned to their home in the Encino suburb of Los Angeles shortly after the sentencing Wednesday in Manhattan federal court. They were said to be spending Thanksgiving at home with their three children, aged 17, 14 and 9. Defense lawyers for Milkn subordinates at Drexel said they believed the judge gave a stiff term partly to send a message about the value of helping the government. ``She is communicating clearly to Michael and his attorneys that if she is going to entertain the possibility of reducing sentence he must completely and totally cooperate,'' said Aubrey Harwell Jr., who represented a former Drexel trader who received immunity from prosecution and testified against Milken. The sentence - if no reduction occurs - effectively means Milken will spend a minimum of nearly seven years in jail and on probation, denying him complete freedom until at least sometime in 1998. In a deal pleading guilty to six felony counts, Milken agreed to respond truthfully to any questions posed by the government after sentencing. Lawyers involved in the case said they expected prosecutors to target corporate officials who dealt with Milken. ``One of the topics of conversation in the last 24 hours is that if Michael completely and totally cooperates and provides information on corporate chieftains connected to his work, this sentence will be significantly reduced,'' said one defense lawyer, who asked not to be named. The lawyer said he believe the government would ``start out by gently pushing him, push him harder and harder and bring more pressure to bear.'' Milken's sentence is far stricter than any previous in Wall Street's corruption scandals, which evolved largely from information supplied by speculator Ivan Boesky, who received a three-year prison term after settling insider trading charges. Dennis Levine, a former Drexel investment banker, got two years after agreeing to return $12.6 million in illegal gains from trading on inside information. Mergers specialist Martin Siegel, who accepted suitcases of cash in exchange for inside information, spent two months in prison. The main difference between those cases and Milken's, legal experts agreed, is the three cooperated before sentencing, which judges consider a mitigating factor, and Milken didn't. ``(Judge Wood) said in a subtle way that Boesky cooperated and you didn't - how can you expect to get a sentence that's equal to his?'' said Harry First, a law professor at New York University. Milken was involved in thousands of financings, mergers and other transactions, and the government is known to have been scrutinizing several deals. First said Milken and his attorneys now must decide how much to help prosecutors. Martin Klein, a New York lawyer and friend of Milken's, called Wood's offer of a sentence reduction in return for good cooperation coercive. ``That assumes that he has anything to say,'' Klein said. ``This whole idea of getting people to turn on others sets a bad precedent in this country.'' Milken must report to federal custody next March. No prison was designated, but under federal guidelines Milken initially could not go to a minimum-security camp because of the length of his term. Legal experts said he likely will be eligible for parole upon serving one-third of his term. During probation, Wood required 1,800 hours of community service a year, or 34.6 hours a week. Milken's lawyers have 120 days to appeal the sentence through a motion seeking reduction. A Milken spokesman would not say whether a decision had been made. Milken had faced a maximum 28 years. Since Milken's crimes occurred before 1987, his sentencing was not based on federal guidelines that specify punishment. But two factors cited by the judge meriting a longer sentence under the guidelines were Milken's position of authority and the commission of crimes she said were hard to detect. Wood told the court anothr component of her decision was Milken's behavior after Boesky's November 1986 plea deal with authorities. She said Milken didn't directly order subordinates to destroy or remove documents but ``communicated the advisability of their doing so in subtle terms that preserved some deniability on your part.'' Wood said she did not accept government charges at a pre-sentencing hearing last month that Milken committed insider trading or manipulated a particular stock. That made the long prison term more shocking to associates. ``She found for us on those issues,'' said a friend of Milken's, who asked not to be named. ``If she found against us what would she have done? Twenty-eight years?''

DOC.HEAD: Government Lowers Growth Forecast to 2.3 Percent
DOC.TEXT: The Hong Kong government on Friday revised the forecast for this British colony's gross domestic product in 1990 to 2.3 percent from 2.5 percent predicted in August. It also revised the inflation rate to 9.7 percent from 9.5 percent. The government chief economist K. Y. Tang said the colony's economy could have been harder hit by the slowdown in domestic exports to the United States, Britain and Japan if not for continued strong growth in re-exports. A government statement said domestic exports in the third quarter continued to decline by about 2 percent in real terms over a year earlier while imports rose about 12 percent in the same period. However re-exports, goods assembled in Hong Kong of components made elsewhere, increased by about 14 percent in the third quarter over the same period in 1989, the statement said.

DOC.HEAD: California-based Pharmaceutical Firm to Merge with Yugoslavian Concern
DOC.TEXT: Yugoslavia's largest pharmaceutical company agreed to merge with California-based SPI Pharmaceuticals Inc. in one of the biggest East-West transactions in Yugoslavia since World War II, SPI officials said. Under the agreement announced Thursday in Belgrade, the assets of Galenika Pharmaceuticals would be transferred to a new joint company, called ICN Galenika. The combined company is expected to have annual sales of $370 million. SPI will own 75 percent of the new company and Galenika will own the remaining 25 percent, according to company officials. SPI is based in Costa Mesa and is an 89 percent-owned subsidiary of ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc.. The transaction will provide Galenika with capital to modernize equipment and improve its international marketing position, the company said. Galenika is the largest manufacturer of pharmaceutical and chemical products in Yugoslavia and serves markets throughout Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. Owned by the Yugoslavian government, Galenika will do an estimated $230 million in sales this year and employs 5,800 workers. SPI has estimated 1990 sales of $140 million. ``We expect significant marketing synergies to occur from the consolidation of our businesses,'' said Milan Panic, chairman and chief executive officer of SPI and its parent, ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc. The merger agreement is subject to final approval by the Federal Secretariat for External Economic Relations of Yugoslavia and the boards of SPI, its parent and Galenika. The consolidation was made possible by changes in Yugoslavian law in late 1988 permitting privatization of government-owned businesses, SPI said.

DOC.HEAD: Government to Close 11 Coal Mines Over Two Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to fix typos. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Eleven state-run coal mines will be closed over the next two years under efforts to streamline money-losing industries, the government says. Economics Minister Vladimir Dlouhy said Thursday that about 9,500 workers will be laid off at the mines, located mostly in the Ostrava region about 240 miles east of Prague. Dlouhy said the mines are unprofitable, but have been kept open to supply coal-fired electric power stations. Two major power stations and several smaller generators face shutdown over the same two-year period to reduce pollution, Dlouhy said. The 750-megawatt power shortfall resulting from the closures would be covered by an expanding nuclear power program, he said. Czechoslovakia already has two Soviet-designed nuclear plants in operation and two under construction. A 440-megawatt reactor at the new Mohovce station is scheduled to start up in 1991 and a 1,000-megawatt installation is slated to begin operating in 1992 at Temelin, a new plant near the Austrian border. Workers from the closed power stations will be relocated or retrained, Dlouhy said. Miners in north Moravia have been on strike alert all week, demanding better social conditions for themselves and their families. Dlouhy said the mines and power stations would not be dismantled, and could be reopened quickly if needed. Czechoslovakia and other East European nations are bracing for a harsh winter because of reduced Soviet oil imports and higher crude oil prices following the Persian Gulf crisis. Regular annual imports of 16 million tons of Soviet oil are expected to drop to 12 million tons next year.

DOC.HEAD: Lloyds Bank Says It Has Cut Staff by 2,000
DOC.TEXT: Lloyds Bank PLC said Friday it has cut 2,000 staff this year as part of an ongoing review of its banking operations. The cuts came mostly through natural attrition and early retirement throughout the company, including head office staff, it said. Lloyds, one of Britain's largest commercial banks, currently employs 55,000. Further job cuts are expected in the future, but the exact numbers haven't been decided, said a spokesman, who wasn't identified in keeping with bank practice. Other British banks also have been trimming staff and consolidating branch networks in a bid to reduce operating costs and bolster profitability.

The stock market was just starting its post-Thanksgiving session today when trading was halted by an unspecified power problem at the New York Stock Exchange. Most stock prices declined slightly in sparse early trading before activity came to a halt on the NYSE at 9:40 a.m. EST, 10 minutes after the opening bell. DOC.HEAD: Government Postpones Start of Capital Gains Tax
DOC.TEXT: The government on Friday renewed its decree for a capital gains tax, an issue which helped provoke a stock traders' strike earlier this week, but postponed implementation for two months. The Cabinet's action put off possible implementation of the tax until Feb. 15. It had to renew the decree because without action, the decree would have expired following Parliament's failure to approve it within the mandatory two-month limit. The capital gains tax applies to small investors. Companies and institutional investors already have to include capital gains on stock trading in their corporate earnings. But individual investors aren't required to include capital gains on their income tax filings. Italian stock markets reopened Thursday following a four-day strike by floor traders. The floor traders opposed the proposed changes in the capital gains tax because of the complicated way the tax would have been collected and the much higher tax rate. The traders have also been protesting the government's slowness in implementing long-awaited reforms expected to make the Italian market more competitive internationally. The reforms concern regulating public tender offers, securities trading companies and insider trading.

DOC.HEAD: Soybeans Higher, Grains Steady to Higher
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices leaped higher in thin trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade. The grains were steady to a little higher. The advance in bean prices extended Wednesday's strong performance, when bean futures gained nine cents a bushel. The markets were closed Thursday the the Thanksgiving holiday. The market has been oversold on disappointment over the lack of a grain deal between the United States and the Soviet Union, said Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago. He also said that weekly export figures released before the holiday were fairly positive for prices. Corn futures were a little higher, following the gains in soybeans, but wheat was basically steady. In early trading, wheat was unchanged to } cent higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.49 a bushel; corn was } cent to 2 cents higher with December at $2.21\ a bushel; oats were unchanged to { cent higher with December at $1.07{ a bushel; and soybeans were 4\ cents to 11} cents higher with January at $5.89 a bushel. At the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, cattle futures were mostly higher while the pork complex declined. Live cattle were up .05 cent to .07 cent with December at 79.22 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .12 cent higher with January at 87.90 cents a pound; live hogs were down .15 cent to .27 cent with December at 53.37 cents a pound; and frozen pork bellies were down .10 cent to .40 cent with February at 71.55 cents a pound. On Wednesday, livestock and meat were mostly higher.

DOC.BYLINE: Tight Lending, Low Bank Earnings Might Blunt Any Effect of Lower Rates
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Reserve has allowed short-term interest rates to fall moderately, but tight lending practices and depressed bank earnings could delay the move's effect on the economy. Normally, lower short-term interest rates take about a month to show up in a lower prime rate, lower adjustable rate mortgages and cheaper car loans, economists said. It might take another year to 18 months for lending activity to increase as more consumers decide to buy new houses and cars. ``But interest rates are only one element of credit availability. There's a credit crunch and homebuilders are having trouble getting financing,'' said Bob Villanueva, chief economist at the National Association of Home Builders. The Federal Reserve this past week confirmed what many borrowers already knew. Banks, under pressure from regulators, have become reluctant to make loans. Their caution has been chiefly aimed at commercial real estate borrowers, but has also affected typically safe large corporations and home buyers. Bankers and business owners complain that regulators are overreacting to the savings and loan debacle and discouraging banks from making reasonable loans. The Bush administration wants lower interest rates to mean easier credit. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady this past week urged bank examiners not to discourage banks from making loans. Also, an interest rate cut could move through the economy more slowly if banks try to bolster their weak earnings by delaying a cut in the prime rate and absorbing the lower federal funds rate. The lower fed funds rate, without a corresponding cut in the prime, increases the spread between the price banks pay for money and what they charge to lend it. Another source of money for banks, certificates of deposit, have yet to come down much. Moreover, some doubt the Fed has allowed short-term rates to fall enough and say it should move more aggressively to significantly strengthen the economy. ``The economy, which is certainly very sluggish right now, is not going to burst out of the shoot because the Fed allowed the fed funds rate to come down 25 hundredths of a percentage point in the past few days,'' said Ken Goldstein, an economist at the Conference Board. In 25 basis-point increments, the Fed has lowered the federal funds rate, the interest banks charge each other for overnight loans, twice in recent months, from 8 percent to 7{ percent. If the 50 basis point drop in the federal funds rate is translated into a half percentage point drop in the prime rate, the effects could trickle into consumer loans within weeks, Goldstein said. But for businesses to spring back to life and lead a resurgence in economic growth ``is just whistling in the dark,'' he said. If the lower interest rates find their way to a lower prime rate and is accompanied by easier lending practices by banks, a half percentage point cut could lead to about 40,000 new housing units in a quarter, Villanueva said. But a more meaningful and aggressive move to lower rates, rather than allowing them to fall, would be difficult for the Fed. The dollar already has weakened severely on world currency markets and if U.S. interest rates fall further, without corresponding drops in Japan and Germany, the dollar would weaken more.

DOC.HEAD: Ameritrust Cuts Dividend
DOC.TEXT: Ameritrust Corp., expecting a loss for the year, announced Friday it had halved the dividend on the banking company's common stock. Officials said they resorted to the cut - the first in the company's 96-year history - mainly because of problem loans linked to a lagging commercial real estate market. The Ameritrust board of directors declared a quarterly dividend of 16 cents per common share, down from 32 cents per share in the third quarter. The dividend is payable Dec. 10 to stockholders of record Dec. 3. ``The board's decision to reduce the dividend on the common stock was prudent in view of our expectations for financial performance in the near-term and general economic conditions,'' said Craig R. Smith, chairman and chief executive of Ameritrust. For the first nine months of 1990, Ameritrust reported a loss of $19 million. Smith did not say how large the fourth-quarter loss was expected to be. Ameritrust spokeswoman Terry Taylor said Smith's recommendation to cut the dividend was prompted by the size of this year's loss, and was a part of an overall effort to cut costs. Ameritrust has more than 200 commercial banking offices in Ohio, Indiana and Michigan, and a major trust subsidiary in Dallas.

For Release Monday Nov 26
DOC.HEAD: Now the Good News: Inflation Fears Ebbing
DOC.TEXT: With not much else to cheer about in the economic news, Wall Street has grown much more optimistic in recent weeks about the inflation outlook. In the forefront of the financial news, oil prices have fallen of late from the peaks they reached after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. But beyond that, analysts see other trends they describe as even more heartening. Some broad indexes of industrial commodity prices actually reached their peaks for the year before the oil upsurge. In recent weeks these gauges of inflationary pressures have declined steadily to their lowest levels since late last winter. ``The inflation picture is becoming less worrisome,'' said Jack Lavery, director of global research at Merrill Lynch & Co. ``Energy price increases are abating and are not spreading elsewhere. The economy is too weak.'' Amid this kind of encouragement, anxious talk about ``stagflation'' has died down in the financial world. A few months ago concern was rising that the economy was headed for a spell of double trouble - little or no growth, combined with persistent upward pressure on the cost of living. Operating under that script, the Federal Reserve would have hardly any maneuvering room to try to counter either problem, since a stimulative policy to counteract recession would only make inflation worse, while a militant anti-inflation stand would deepen the economic slump. Now, that perceived dilemma seems to have been resolved. Most analysts agree that ebbing inflation has made it possible for the Fed to adopt a less stringent approach in managing the supply of money and credit in the economy. The shift has been cautious and gradual, reflecting a style that has become familiar to Fed-watchers under the chairmanship of Alan Greenspan. The central bank has made no move as yet to change the discount rate, which has stood at 7 percent since it was raised to that level on Feb. 24, 1989. In the past, the Fed has often used changes in the discount rate - the charge it sets on loans to private financial institutions - to signal important monetary-policy moves. In many analysts' view, Greenspan has been sticking with a deliberate style in an effort to gain and keep the confidence of bond traders that he won't let his guard down on inflation. The letup in inflation fears has helped to ease what some observers view as a simplistic initial reaction to the sharp rise in oil prices. ``Even if we knew for sure at what level oil prices will settle, the consequences are not as predictable as might be imagined,'' said economists at H.C. Wainwright & Co. of Boston in a recent report on the subject. ``Inflation is a monetary phenomenon,'' they argue. ``No single commodity can drive the prices of all commodities up. Only the federal government, by depreciating the value of the currency, can do that. ``Indeed, an energy price increase works the other way. By absorbing a larger slice of the incomes of energy users, it makes the existing prices of other commodities less affordable. ``If, however, government intervenes to ratify, or `monetize,' an oil price increase, then inflation will result.''

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Rally
DOC.TEXT: Share prices rallied to close sharply higher on London's Stock Exchange Friday, managing to shrug off domestic and international uncertainty. The market was buoyed by expectations that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's successor would cut Britain's 14 percent base lending rate because of the pound's strength, dealers said. The Conservative Party is to vote on three leadership contenders Tuesday. Thatcher announced her resignation Thursday. A shortage of stock also was a factor in Friday's rally, traders said. They said fund mangers have been looking for quality stocks to boost their portfolios before the end of the year. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index closed up 42.6 points, or 2 percent, at 2,170.5. The Financial Times 30-share index closed up 40 points at 1,712.2. The Financial Times 500-share index rose 20.89 points to close at 1,145.18. Volume was 478.8 million shares Friday, compared to 498.2 million shares traded Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Bank President Dies
DOC.TEXT: Francis ``Buddy'' Kemp, president of NCNB Corp., died of brain cancer early Friday at his home. He was 50. Kemp had been chairman of NCNB Texas since July 1988 when the Charlotte, N.C., banking company expanded into the state. He had suffered from brain cancer for more than a year. ``We feel his absence intensely,'' said NCNB Chairman Hugh McColl in a statement. ``We have lost someone who is very special to us.'' Kemp, a native of Reidsville, N.C., joined NCNB in 1967 as a credit analyst and quickly advanced in the company. By 1972 he was a senior vice president and National Division executive. Kemp was promoted to executive vice president in 1975, took over the North Carolina Banking Group in 1977 and became president of NCNB Corp. in October 1985. He relinquished his day-to-day responsibilities at NCNB in November 1989 after undergoing brain surgery. Kemp is survived by his wife, Ginger, their children, Frank and Elizabeth, and by a brother, David Kemp of Reidsville. The funeral service will be at Myers Park Presbyterian Church in Charlotte on Monday, with a memorial service at the First Presbyterian Church in Dallas.

DOC.HEAD: Miners Demonstrate at Polish Parliament
DOC.TEXT: About 500 miners in hardhats and coveralls staged a noisy 90-minute demonstration in front of parliament Friday demanding increased government subsidies for financially troubled coal mines. A petition handed to the lower parliament house said a cut in subsidies under the government's radical economic reforms has made the mines unprofitable and cut the miners' living standards, the state PAP news agency reported. The demonstrators also demanded talks with the government on wages, PAP said. Miners, in a series of recent warning strikes, have demanded twice the national average of 1.2 million zlotys, or $130, a month in base pay. Traditionally in Poland, miners commanded much higher wages than other workers because of the importance of their industry and the difficult, dangerous working conditions. But Poland's post-Communist government wants to transform mining into a profit-making industry, and huge government subsidies are being cut back slowly while coal prices are allowed to rise. Many of the miners demonstrating were from the Communist-founded OPZZ trade union federation. Leaders met with Mieczyslaw Gil, head of the Solidarity-allied Citizens Parliamentary caucus, Senate Speaker Andrzej Stelmachowski and various deputies. Friday's protest came only two days before the country's first popular presidential election. ``I don't think it's an accident,'' Gil said on state television. Rajmund Moric, head of the OPZZ mining union, said representatives of parliament and the government would visit the mining region of Silesia on Dec. 1. A 31-year-old miner, Ryszard Chojnowski, collapsed during the demonstration and later died, PAP reported. The cause of death was being investigated, the agency said.

DOC.HEAD: Gardini Gets Well-Paid Exit From Chemical Joint Venture
DOC.TEXT: Raul Gardini, the chemical tycoon who advocates privatizing Italy's industry, is selling his stake in Enimont and leaving the troubled chemical joint venture to the state-controlled energy group ENI. Gardini, who had long sought to extend his control on Italy's chemical business through a takeover of Enimont, said Thursday he would sell his 40 percent stake for about $2.55 billion to Italy's state energy group. The stock is being sold to Ente Nazionale Idrocarburi, also known as ENI. ENI already owns 40 percent of Enimont. Its bid to buy Montedison's 40 percent stake and increase its holding to a controlling 80 percent ended a bitter 18-month battle between Gardini and ENI officials. ENI also offered to buy out minority shareholders to take complete control of Enimont. Gardini, meanwhile, announced his resignation as chairman of Ferruzzi Finanziaria, the key holding company of the agro-industrial and chemical groups of the Ferruzzi family. A statement said Gardini was leaving for ``ideological reasons'' and would no longer ``participate in any Italian company or business organization.'' ENI and Montedison formed Enimont in 1989 in an effort to restructure Italy's chemical industry, creating the world's 10th largest chemical group with annual revenue of about $13.6 billion. But squabbling over industrial strategy and managerial control doomed the effort.

DOC.HEAD: Philips Halts Picture Tube Plant in Michigan
DOC.TEXT: Dutch-based Philips Display Components Co. has postponed plans for a $116 million picture tube plant in Saline, blaming a sluggish U.S. economy. A statement Wednesday from the company's North American operations in Ann Arbor said the plant ``has been put on hold'' because of deteriorating economic conditions in the United States. Philips recently announced from Eindhoven, The Netherlands, that it had lost $1.3 billion in the third quarter and would lay off up to 45,000 of its 285,700 employees worldwide. The company had planned to build the picture tube plant on 117 acres and employ up to 400 people.

DOC.HEAD: Production Ending on Staple of Former East German Auto Industry
DOC.TEXT: The government said Friday it would end production of the boxey little car, fondly called a Trabi, that was the staple of former East Germany's auto industry. About 10,000 Trabant cars will be delivered to Poland under an existing agreement with the former East German government, the German Economics Ministry added in a statement. The tiny Trabant, made of fiberglass, is almost comic in comparison with the mighty Mercedes-Benz and BMW that race down Germany's autobahns. The Trabant's top speed is around 62 mph. Trabis became famous when East German refugees drove them into Bavaria as formerly closed borders began opening in September 1989. They were also used by East Germans who fled into West Berlin the night of Nov. 9, 1989, when the Berlin Wall was breached. Many former West Germans have bought used Trabis as keepsakes of their former easern neighbors, while former East Germans have purchased more luxurious Western models.
Stock prices were mixed today in a typically slow post-Thanksgiving session. Shortly before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 4.71 at 2,534.65.

DOC.HEAD: Close-Up View of Christmas Shopping Around the Nation
With AM-Christmas Sales, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a sampling of interviews with shoppers across the United States on the day after Thanksgiving, the unofficial beginning of the Christmas sales season, as compiled by the AP staff: --- OMAHA, Neb. - Shoppers didn't budget their shopping time Friday as they descended on department stores, but they budgeted their dollars. ``Nintendo is one of my top favorites,'' said Robert Connor, 13, who was playing a game at a display at a Sears store. ``They've got a lot of new games. I like the graphics.'' With five kids in the family, Connor's father, Dennis, said he's cutting down on the number of video games he buys each year. --- CHICAGO - While combing the outdoor State Street mall, 37-year-old Wisconsin resident Jan Liss vowed not to buy computer games for her three children. ``They're too addictive,'' she said. ``You get much more benefit from buying them books.'' --- BOSTON - Cold, wet shoppers trickled through Boston's Downtown Crossing in search of good buys in this year's tight economy, which has been particularly acute in New England. ``We've set a budget to work within and it's the same as last year,'' said Jim Bryan, who brought his wife and three daughters in from suburban Tyngsboro, Mass. The Jordan Marsh department store rejuvenated its Victorian enchanted village complete with grand hotel, bear-inhabited treehouse and bakery with authentic gingerbread scents piped in from the store's real bakery. ``Stores that offer something more than another sale another day will be the ones that do better this year,'' said store official Robert Gottlieb. --- PHILADELPHIA - Shoppers arrived in the rain as downtown stores opened. None said the gloomy economy and Persian Gulf uncertainty would bring any changes in shopping habits. Kathy Smith of Dover, Del., brought her two teen-age daughters and mother to The Gallery shopping mall downtown. The first thing they did was buy four big shopping bags. ``One of my daughters asked for a drum set. But it's not likely,'' Ms. Smith said. --- DEARBORN, Mich. - Barbara Palko said the clothing selection isn't what she hoped it would be. ``We're havin difficulty finding the special gifts this year,'' she said. ``The gadgets are out there, the electronics, but you know how you look for that special gift? We're disappointed this year.'' --- NEW YORK - Things might have been bonkers at Macy's and Bloomingdale's, but the busy shopping day was just another Friday along two of Manhattan's less upscale shopping strips. The stores along Canal Street and 14th Street, where merchants peddle goods ranging from discount stereos to imitation Gucci bags, were lacking crowds on a rainy day after Thanskgiving, although business usually booms on these streets on weekends. The majority of shoppers along Canal Street adjoining the Chinatown district were more interested in stores selling fresh fish and vegetables. --- MOBILE, Ala. - Bob Ingram, manager of Springdale Plaza mall, said he doesn't care about gloomy economic predictions in ``Philadelphia, New York or Chicago.'' ``I've got merchants here who are going into the season with a 50 percent increase in sales. Why would they fall on their face now?'' he asked. Across the street, Rod Taylor, who manages Mobile's Bel Air Mall, said some people might wait until the last weekend to shop because Christmas falls on a Tuesday. --- SECAUCUS, N.J. - The Calvin Klein outlet was having a hard time competing with sales at surrounding factory discount outlets Friday. ``Everyone's in other stores,'' said May Morales, a store saleswoman at Secaucus' hodgepodge of discount stores in the shadow of New York City. ``It's busy, but not that busy.'' The outlet had its holiday sale last weekend, so it didn't have any specials to pull in customers Friday, she said. --- DALLAS - Jesus Escobedo of San Antonio was visiting town with a weekend touring group that watched pro football's Dallas Cowboys thrash the Washington Redskins on Thanksgiving Day. He said he would spend about the same amount of money this holiday season. ``I think a lot depends on your personal situation more than the economy,'' Escobedo said. ``So I think about the same.'' --- PORTLAND, Ore. - The economic and political gloom aren't making a big dent in Karen Andrews' holiday budget. ``I'll be spending a little less than last year, but it's not because of the economy or the Middle East,'' she said. ``It's because I haven't paid last year's bills off yet.''

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Edge Lower
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices edged lower Friday in light trading in another shortened session. The Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond lost \ point, or $2.50 per $1,000 in face amount. Its yield, which rises when prices fall, edged up to 8.44 percent from 8.42 percent on Wednesday. Bond trading ended about two hours early on Wednesday in advance the Thanksgiving holiday which closed the markets all day on Thursday. Trading wound down early again on Friday as many traders took a four-day weekend. Prices were pressured by increases in the energy futures markets, where light sweet crude oil for December delivery was up about $2 a barrel at $31.75 shortly after 2 p.m. EST when bond trading closed. Bond prices are hurt by rising oil prices or other signs of inflation. ``In the absence of any positive news, we are sagging just a slight amount,'' said Steven A. Wood, economist for BankAmerica Capital Markets Group in San Francisco. He said trading volume was so light in the post-holiday session that many traders who showed up brought their families. ``There are probably as many children on our trading floor as there are traders,'' Wood said. Next week, investors will get more evidence on the state of the economy with the scheduled release of reports on durable goods orders and leading economic indicators in October as well as a revision of third-quarter gross national product data. Some analysts expect that the Federal Reserve will move to encourage lower interest rates by the end of the year to stimulate the economy. In addition, the Treasury plans to auction $12.25 billion in two-year notes and $9 billion in five-year notes next week. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, short-term maturities were unchanged to 1-16 point lower, intermediate maturities slipped 5-32 point and long-term issues were down as much as \ point, the Telerate Inc. financial information service reported. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, fell 1.11 to 1,173.88. Yields on three-month Treasury bills held steady at 7.23 percent as the discount was unchanged at 7.02 percent. Yields on six-month bills held at 7.31 percent as the discount was unchanged at 6.97 percent. Yields on one-year bills edged up to 7.24 percent as the discount rose 1 basis point to 6.78 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, traded at 7{ percent, the same as late Wednesday. The Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds was unavailable Friday because of the light dealings.

DOC.HEAD: Money Supply Down
DOC.TEXT: The two broadest measures of the nation's money supply fell in the week ended Nov. 12, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 fell to a seasonally adjusted $3,314.8 billion from $3,315.0 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, fell to a seasonally adjusted $4,082.0 billion from $4,084.4 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, fell to a seasonally adjusted $819.6 billion from $822.3 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The growth rate in M2 in the last 52 weeks was 4.6 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The growth rate in M3 over the past year was 1.8 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 1 percent to 5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,317.1 billion, a 3.9 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,090.1 billion, up 1.5 percent, while M1 rose 5.4 percent to an average of $820.2 billion. In other reports, the Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $154 million a day in the week ended Nov. 21, down from $263 million the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Up on Fears of Bloodshed in Gulf, Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices shot up more than $2 a barrel Friday as traders who were worrying about war in the Persian Gulf became even more jittery over a threat of violence in the Soviet Union, the world's largest oil producer. ``Gorbachev warned of bloodshed if the republics of the Soviet Union broke up,'' said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. The Soviet president's comments, made at a Moscow news conference, fueled the upward surge in a market that opened bullish in response to oil prices that had risen Thursday in London on news of a shutdown at a North Sea oil facility, she said. The facility was already being brought back on-line Friday, but the higher London prices boosted opening oil futures in New York. Crude traders then began focusing on war fears that were stirred up by President Bush's Thanksgiving visit to U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia. Bush told the soldiers that they might soon have to provide the solution to the Gulf crisis that began with Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in August. ``It heightened the sense that the possibility for war is strengthening,'' Hittle said. But volume was extremely light, as many participants were taking a four-day weekend in observance of Thanksgiving, so analysts said the market's big move was somewhat exaggerated. Ed Kevelson at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. said traders were also buying oil on the belief that the U.N. Security Council would soon be contemplating a resolution that would authorize the use of military force to push Iraqi troops out of Kuwait. The war fears were further whipped up by news that the British were sending more troops into the Gulf. ``People certainly don't want to be short going into next week,'' Kevelson said. Light sweet crude oil settled at $31.90 per barrel, up $2.27, for January delivery contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange. For the week, which was shortened by the market's closing on Thanksgiving Day, crude for next-month delivery rose $2.53 a barrel. The rising crude prices helped pull up futures contracts for refined petroleum. Wholesale home heating oil was up 3.42 cents at 88.66 cents a gallon on contracts for delivery in December. For the week, next-month heating oil contracts were up 4.24 cents a gallon. Wholesale unleaded gasoline rose 3.45 cents to 82.40 cents a gallon on contracts for delivery in December. Next-month contracts for unleaded gasoline were up 4.77 cents a gallon for the week. Natural gas prices fell .5 cent to $2.605 per 1,000 cubic feet on contracts for January delivery. For the week, next-month natural gas was up 37 cents.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Higher on Hopes of Soviet Trade
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices advanced at the Chicago Board of Trade Friday as a team of Soviet grain buyers prepared to come to this country next week. On other markets, petroleum futures were sharply higher; metals posted gains; cattle advanced; and pork futures were mostly lower. Renewed hopes of an emergency food deal with the Soviet Union and a report that Brazil had reduced its planting by 15 percent gave soybean futures enough of a jolt to send prices up by more than 11 cents a bushel in early trading. ``There seems to be a consensus in the market that eventually the Soviets and the U.S. will come to terms'' on emergency aid, said Joel Karlin, a grain analyst in Chicago with Research Department Inc. The Soviet team reportedly will be discussing export credits and their country's long-term grain agreement with the United States. How much attention will be given he Soviet Union's food needs for this winter was not known. Corn futures tagged along with the soybean complex, but wheat slumped lower. But some of the gains in soybean futures eroded due to commercial selling. Wheat settled \ cent lower to 1 cent higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.48} a bushel; corn was 1 cent to 2} cents higher with December at $2.22{ a bushel; oats were } cent to 1\ cents higher with December at $1.08{ a bushel; and soybeans were 3 cents to 4} cents higher with January at $5.82 a bushel. The prospect of a U.N. Security Council vote next week on using force to remove Iraqi troops from Kuwait was the latest Persian Gulf development to send petroleum futures sharply higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Prices opened higher following gains in London on Thanksgiving Day, when the Merc was closed. The price gains were sustained because of the Persian Gulf developments and the vague uncertainty produced by Margaret Thatcher's announced resignation as prime minister of Great Britain, said Brian Tagler, energy broker in New York with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. Then late in the day came word from the British foreign office that the U.N. Security Council may meet next week to take up the Persian Gulf crisis. Light sweet crude oil settled 75 cents to $2.27 higher with the January contract at $31.90 a barrel; heating oil was 2.10 cents to 4 cents higher with December at 88.66 cents a gallon; and unleaded gasoline was 3.30 cents to 3.54 cents higher with December at 82.40 cents a gallon. Cattle futures were higher while pork declined on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Cattle got a boost from the futures market's steep discount to cash prices and from stronger wholesale beef prices. DOC.TEXT: Stock prices declined slightly Friday, turning downward near the close of the quietest session in nearly four years. The paucity of business, which was typical of a post-Thanksgiving session on Wall Street, also stemmed from an unspecified power problem at the New York Stock Exchange that prompted a trading halt of more than an hour and a half. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 12.13 to 2,527.23, finishing the week with a net loss of 23.02 points. Declining issues outnumbered advances by a narrow margin in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 650 up, 680 down and 559 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 63.35 million shares, down from 140.66 million Wednesday and the lightest total since a 48.86 million-share day on Dec. 26, 1986. Most stocks declined slightly in sparse early trading before activity came to a halt on the NYSE at 9:40 a.m. EST, 10 minutes after the opening bell. The exchange resumed operations at 11:15 a.m. EST. The pace of business had been expected to be very light anyway on what is normally one of the quietest days of the year for the financial world. Analysts also said those traders who were present drew little inspiration from the oil markets, where prices rose sharply, and the credit markets, where interest rates edged upward. The price of crude oil for January delivery rose about $2.35 a barrel, to just under $32 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. In the bond market, prices of long-term government bonds showed small losses, nudging their yields up to the 8.43 percent-8.44 percent range. Energy stocks managed only a mixed showing in spite of the jump in oil prices. Exxon rose ] to 51[ and Texaco gained [ to 57[, but Chevron dropped \ to 68{ and Atlantic Richfield was down ~ at 125. MCA fell 3[ to 65] in active trading on reports that the company was nearing agreement on a merger deal with Matsushita Electrical for a price below what some market participants had discussed. British stocks showed gains as investors assessed the political outlook in the United Kingdom following Margaret Thatcher's departure as prime minister. British Gas rose 2| to 47] and British Telecom 1| to 57[. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 80.03 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $5.19 billion, or 0.18 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped .34 to 172.39. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell .97 to 369.71, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was down .93 at 315.10. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose .27 to 349.04. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 295.90, up .32.

DOC.HEAD: Animal Rights Activists Stage Nationwide Fur Protests
With AM-Christmas Sales Bjt
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Urging fur wearers to ``donate your dead'' and staging funeral processions for animals, activists around the country attacked the fur industry on Friday by taking to the streets on one of the busiest shopping days of the year. From Fifth Avenue in midtown Manhattan to a posh Denver mall to a shopping center in tiny Manchester, N.H., nearly 100 planned demonstrations filled high-fashion shopping spots in what has become an annual Christmas season ritual. The ``Fur Free Friday'' demonstrations held the day after Thanksgiving come at a bad time for the fur industry. The shopping season for retail stores is expected to be sluggish at best - dampened by the faltering economy that many merchants fear will keep buyers from spending on lavish gifts like mink coats. Protest organizers hailed what they called a growing awareness of Americans against fur garments, but a light rain diminished the size of Friday's largest march, in Manhattan, where police said 1,400 marchers participated vs. more than 2,000 last year. With organizers struggling to elicit loud chants from the crowd, the two-block Manhattan march gained momentum as it proceeded down Fifth Avenue. Led by a costumed grim reaper slowly banging a drum, two marchers clad in skeleton outfits wheeled a cart crammed with furs in what a placard called a ``free burial'' for those who would ``donate your dead.'' ``Get a feel for fur - slam your fingers in a car door,'' mocked another poster. Dangling at the end of hand-held stakes, stuffed toy raccoons, seals and other cute furry creatures peeped above the crowd. The New York protest was largely peaceful, except for a handful of demonstrators who organizers asked to leave the march because they ``were acting up'' by chanting offensive slogans, said Jane Seidlitz, co-director of Animal Rights Mobilization, which organized the demonstration. ``This is not a forum where we confront fur wearers,'' she said, noting that the group discourages protesters from throwing paint or slashing fur coats. Elsewhere in New York state, about 75 protesters from the Animal Rights Action League demonstrated outside the Macy's and M. Solomon stores in Colonie Center mall in suburban Albany. ``One of our messages is for people to open their hearts and include the animals in their circle of compassion this holiday season,'' said Charles Donath, the group's director. New York animal rights protesters also held demonstrations in Niagara Falls, Rochester, Syracuse and Binghamton. In Denver, animal rights activists from the Rocky Mountain Humane Society planned a march and a rally at the swank new Cherry Creek Mall in Denver. In a protest that was more symbolic than others, 16 people in Manchester, N.H. demonstrated outside a busy shopping center that has no furrier. In downtown Harrisburg, Pa., a costumed grim reaper led about 40 people chanting against the killing of animals for fur coats in an annual ritual in front of the Strawberry Square shopping center. Organizers contended that their annual campaign against what they call the inhumane killing of fur-bearing animals for luxury garments has put a palatable dent in sales. They say that because of their movement, some of the biggest department stores, including Nordstrom and Harrod's of London have decided to disband their fur boutiques, and that some leading fur makers are in financial trouble. Fur industry officials deny the protests have hurt sales and point to what they call a 10 percent increase in sales of fur products last year.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Higher in Very Thin Trading; Gold Jumps
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mostly higher against major foreign currencies Friday in extremely thin post-holiday trading. Gold prices rose sharply on strength in the oil markets and talk of Middle East war. The precious metal jumped $4.80 a troy ounce to $383.70 on the New York Commodity Exchange. Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $383.75, up $4.60 a troy ounce. The dollar also rose, but modestly, in a thin trading session that followed the Thanksgiving holiday. Analysts said traders largely ignored a rise in oil prices and intensified fear of war in the Persian Gulf. Heightening concerns about an armed confrontation in the Middle East, President Bush declared Friday ``the world is getting tired'' of Iraq's continuing occupation of Kuwait and said he was closing in on agreement for a U.N. resolution authorizing the use of force in the Persian Gulf. Traders speculated that senior-level currency investors who ordinarily would have responded to such news had taken the day off for a four-day weekend. Talk of war generally nudges up the value of the dollar, which is usually viewed as relatively safe-haven investment. ``Bush made some very very heavy statements today,'' said David Marshall, senior currency analyst at MMS International Inc. However, instead of being responsible for a sizable increase in the value of the dollar the war talk ``accounts for a nearly $5 rise in the price of gold, and oil went up as well.'' The dollar lost a bit of ground against the yen in New York, closing at 127.10 yen, down from Wednesday's 127.17. In Tokyo, markets were closed for Labor Thanksgiving Day, a national holiday. In London, the dollar was quoted at 127.35 Japanese yen, up from Thursday's close of 127.13 yen in Tokyo. In New York, one pound cost $1.9668, less expensive than Wednesday's $1.9670. In London, the British pound fell to $1.9670 from $1.9700 late Thursday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Wednesday's late rates, included: 1.4860 German marks, up from 1.4770; 1.2600 Swiss francs, up from 1.2472; 5.0115 French francs, up from 4.9800; 1,115.50 Italian lire, up from 1,109.00, and 1.1602 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1582. Other late dollar rates in Europe compared with late rates Thursday included: 1.4860 German marks, up from 1.4786; 1.2583 Swiss francs, up from 1.2490; 5.0075 French francs, up from 4.9890; 1.6760 Dutch guilders, up from 1.6670; 1,115.00 Italian lire, up from 1,109.50; and 1.1592 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1602. In European metals trading, gold rose in London to a late bid of $383.75 a troy ounce, up from $380.00 late Thursday. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $383.25 an ounce, up from $380.50 late Thursday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $1.16 an ounce to close at $379.25. Silver rose on the Commodity Exchange, closing at $4.218 a troy ounce, up 7 cents bid late Wednesday. In London, silver bullion rose to a late bid of $4.15 a troy ounce, up from $4.13 late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: To Fight, To Plead, To Squeal: Choices Mark Milken Saga
DOC.TEXT: About two years ago, Michael Milken had a chance to plead guilty to a couple felony counts and end the government's investigation before a single charge had ever been brought against him. He didn't. Milken could have fought his case at trial, bearing the pressure of lengthy public scrutiny but squarely confronting the government's claims, which he and his defense lawyers maintained were spurious. He didn't. The 44-year-old former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. financier also could have spilled his guts long ago, naming names and winning credit to earn a shorter sentence. He didn't do that either. Now critics are gloating that the junk bond whiz got his: 10 years in prison and three years of full-time community service. Just as Watergate closed out the 1970s, Milken's punishment is viewed as a headstone for the 1980s, the end of an era of greed. But while no one predicted the severity of the sentence handed down last week by U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood, legal experts are questioning Milken's strategy during his four-year confrontation with the Justice Department. ``The lawyer has to follow the client's instructions,'' said John J. Coffee Jr., a Columbia University law professor. ``Milken was not some wimp who was totally dependent on his lawyers' advice. He knows his own personal calculus. ``I think he probably estimated he might have served two or three years,'' Coffee said. ``Certainly no one predicted this as the likely outcome. But a man who lives with junk bonds knows there are risks out there.'' The general post-mortem in the legal community is that Milken and his high-priced defense team led by Arthur Liman may have miscalculated at various points. Among them: -Balking at a deal with prosecutors about two years ago that would have allowed Milken to plead guilty to two or three felony counts. Milken sources contend the government wanted an admission of insider trading, which Milken found unacceptable. -Loudly criticizing the government's investigation, indictment and tactics, and trumpeting Milken's innocence. After the plea deal, Liman argued strenuously that Milken was guilty only of technical violations. In the end, Milken appeared to get little if any credit for settling the case. -Pleading guilty to six felony counts - ``an unheard of amount,'' Coffee said. Liman may have wrongly assumed the judge would discount the number of counts if she found they were minor breaches. But Wood sentenced Milken to consecutive two-year terms on each of five counts. On count six, conspiracy, he got probation. -Letting the government raise additional charges before sentencing. When the defense contested the claims and Wood couldn't square the pictures, she held a hearing. The judge didn't find Milken had committed the substantive charges, but she did find he obstructed justice during the federal probe, a serious violation in judges' eyes. -Delaying cooperation until after sentencing. Wood toughened the sentence because Milken had not assisted the government. Milken long had refused to cooperate. Now he faces a Catch-22: He has to snitch to qualify for a reduction, but if his genuine assistance proves of little value, he gets no credit. Milken's strategy did yield a few benefits. He avoided the humiliation of a long trial that would have kept him and his family in the public eye for years, and the government agreed to drop all charges against his brother, Lowell. But several defense lawyers and legal scholars agreed that Milken's approach during the four-year ordeal was indecisive. ``If you're going to rattle sabers you're better off going through with it,'' said an attorney with a client involved in the Milken case, who asked not to be named. ``If you're going to go in and try to cooperate you do it in a quiet, meek way. If you're going to grovel, you grovel.'' Milken did none of those. ``You can't cooperate halfway,'' securities lawyer Ira Sorkin said. ``Either you go 100 percent or zero. By saying you're really sorry, feel terrible, you hurt people, but not telling the government more - she perceived that as non-cooperation.'' In fairness to Milken, the second-guessing is pinned to the lengthy term, which no one had anticipated. ``There are all sorts of factors that went into that decision to plead guilty that we will never know about,'' criminal defense lawyer Judd Burstein said. ``You just can't look and say he made a bad decision because he got 10 years.'' Under his plea agreement, Milken now must answer any questions posed by the government. Judge Wood said she would consider reducing the sentence based on a recommendation from the government praising Milken's cooperation. Under federal law, the defense has 120 days to request a reduction in sentence. The U.S. Attorney's Office would have to support the request if Milken were to have any chance for a quick reduction. Before the government agrees to spring Milken early, he likely would have to provide information leading to other indictments. A main focus is expected to be fraud in the collapse of the nation's savings and loans, which bought about $10 billion in risky high-yield bonds from Drexel. Bringing other types of cases is expected to be more difficult because federal law bars prosecution for crimes committed more than five years ago, and many of the deals Milken already are older than that. Congress last year extended the statute of limitations for S&Ls to 10 years. While 120 days isn't much time, Milken could file the motion to reduce sentence and Judge Wood could delay it for months while he cooperates. But that still might not be long enough to develop enough cases to satisfy prosecutors. Milken's next choice is how much to cooperate. ``It sounds to me like she's laying out the red carpet for him,'' said Alan Bromberg, a securities law professor at Southern Methodist University. ``How far down it he can go and how much good it will do is very hard to predict.'' ``All I've heard is he's not a tattletale type. It will go against the grain for him,'' Bromberg said. ``Michael is a basically loyal human being,'' said a defense lawyer for a former Drexel trader who testified against Milken. ``He has been very opposed to telling anything in regard to those people with whom he has dealt.'' Whatever Milken's cooperation produces, his sentence seemed to satisfy those who viewed Milken as the embodiment of Wall Street greed, despite a modest, generous lifestyle that contrasted with that of his main accuser, inside trader Ivan Boesky. The handful of letters sent to the judge by people who don't know Milken suggested life in prison or physical torture. Liman said the requests ``would probably stagger the secret police of totalitarian regimes.'' The anger toward Milken was great, but many people on Wall Street said it was misdirected. ``He was this era's target,'' one defense lawyer said. ``We are a society that likes to blame someone.'' Said Sorkin: ``The only conclusion that can be drawn is that there was greed before the 1980s and there will be greed after the 1980s. If you look at what the stock market was like in the first 40 years of this century, what Boesky and Milken and the rest of them did would pale by comparison.''

DOC.TEXT: Consumers began a Christmas shopping season that many retailers fear will be their worst in years due to the twin grinches of a weak economy and the Persian Gulf crisis. In keeping with a tradition that's as much a part of Thanksgiving weekend as leftover turkey, shoppers queued early on Friday, some standing outside in the rain before stores and malls opened. By midmorning, many an aisle was crowded, from midtown Manhattan's swank department stores to the State Street Mall in Chicago to the shops that ring San Francisco's Union Square. But many of the shoppers were only browsing, not buying. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The federal government opened fiscal 1991 with a $31.5 billion deficit in October, the first month of what is expected to be a record year for red ink, the Treasury Department said. The budget gap was 21 percent higher than the $26.1 billion deficit of October 1989. The increase reflects the buildup of U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf and the escalation of the savings and loan bailout, officials said Friday. --- NEW YORK (AP) - The New York Stock Exchange halted trading for more than 90 minutes because of a power disruption at the nation's largest stock market. The disruption Friday, which NYSE officials called the first in recent memory, shut down the exchange at 9:41 a.m. EST, 11 minutes into the start of trading. NYSE spokesman Richard Torrenzano said the problem was power-related but that the exchange hadn't identified its exact cause. ---

Urging fur wearers to ``donate your dead'' and staging funeral processions for animals, activists around the country attacked the fur industry by taking to the streets on one of the busiest shopping days of the year. From Fifth Avenue in midtown Manhattan to a posh Denver mall to a shopping center in tiny Manchester, N.H., nearly 100 planned demonstrations filled high-fashion shopping spots Friday in what has become an annual ritual. --- PHILADELPHIA (AP) - If you're singing the blues about the cost of Christmas presents, be thankful your true love isn't asking for the complete catalog of gifts in ``The Twelve Days of Christmas.'' J. Patrick Bradley, that literal-minded chief economist at Provident National Bank, has once again toted up the sales slip for the items listed in the old carol, from a partridge in a pear tree to twelve drummers drumming. This year's total: $15,231.72, up 4.34 percent from last year, he said Friday. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Thailand has agreed to legalize the import of American and other foreign cigarettes. In exchange, the government is ending its 18-month investigation of unfair trade charges against the nation. U.S. Trade Representative Carla A. Hills said announced the actions Friday. The investigation, which could have led to U.S. trade reprisals against Thailand, was in response to a 1989 petition by the U.S. Cigarette Export Association. --- MILAN, Italy (AP) - Raul Gardini, the chemical tycoon who advocates privatizing Italy's industry, is selling his stake in Enimont and leaving the troubled chemical joint venture to the state-controlled energy group ENI. Gardini, who had long sought to extend his control on Italy's chemical business through a takeover of Enimont, said Thursday he would sell his 40 percent stake for about $2.55 billion to Italy's state energy group. The stock is being sold to Ente Nazionale Idrocarburi, also known as ENI. --- MADRID, Spain (AP) - Major carmakers in Spain plan hundreds of layoffs in coming months because of drooping sales. Economists say the moves are a clear signal the nation's economy is slowing down. A spokeswoman for Germany's Volkswagen AG Spanish subsidiary, SEAT SA, said Thursday that the company will cut production by 120 cars a day and lay off 700 temporary workers because of a sharp decline in sales in Spain this year. --- DALLAS (AP) - Francis ``Buddy'' Kemp, president of NCNB Corp., died of brain cancer at his home. He was 50. Kemp had been chairman of NCNB Texas since July 1988 when the Charlotte, N.C., banking company expanded into the state. He had suffered from brain cancer for more than a year before his death Friday. ---

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Shortages Driving Soybean Futures
DOC.TEXT: Each day, it seems, there's an announcement about the Soviet Union reaching agreement for food aid with another Western nation. Meanwhile, the U.S. farm sector watches these multibillion dollar deals from outside, its nose pressed to the window. Yet, hope persists, despite repeated disappointments. ``The European Community can't provide soy oil and meal'' and the United States is about the only source for these commodities now, said Joel Karlin, a grain analyst in Chicago with Research Department Inc. Wheat can be bought cheaply enough from Canada or Argentina, and barley can be substituted for corn if the United States is cut out of any extraordinary deals this fall with the Soviets. In the past month, Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev has arranged for $10 billion in emergency food aid to help his country get through the winter. As these deals were announced, corn and wheat traders at the Chicago Board of Trade became more resigned to the belief that there won't be much, if anything, left over for U.S. exporters of these commodities. The Bush administration has indicated that it is looking for liberalized emigration laws in the Soviet Union before it's willing to talk export credits. Futures traders and grain analysts say they think Bush will be more willing to help if Gorbachev is firmly lined up with the U.S. in dealing with Iraq. This line of reasoning sent soybean prices sharply higher a week ago before the meetings in Europe between Bush and Gorbachev. The gains were quickly lost when no grain deal was announced, but quickly went back up again when Gorbachev said the issue of force should be decided by the U.N. Security Council. By week's end, prices were back up on reports that the Soviets were about to codify liberalized emigration laws. Further, the market began talking about the arrival in Washington on Monday of a grain-buying team from the Soviet Union. How much this team will focus on long-term trade arrangements and how much on immediate aid for this winter remains to be seen. ``There seems to be a concensus in the market that eventually the Soviets and the U.S. will come to terms'' on emergency aid, Karlin said. He noted that legislators and farm groups have become increasingly vocal on the need to give agricultural exports a shot in the arm. U.S. soy oil and meal presumably are on the Soviet shopping list. Cooking oil is one among many food staples reported in critically short supply there and soybean oil is about the cheapest oil available. And abundant supplies of soy meal make it the obvious choice for animal feed. Nonetheless, said Karlin, if the Soviets don't get credit, they probably won't buy. ``So, if we don't so anything, we're going to be left behind,'' he said.
